PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FAMILY AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 25 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Family and Other Measures) Bill 1997 . The committee is considering amendments Nos 9 and 10 on sheet 654 moved by Senator Neal. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

—These amendments relate to rental assistance, and we spoke at some length about them on the last occasion that we were in the Senate. Essentially, the argument was that those people who are living with families within public housing, where their income is taken into account for the purpose of determining the rent, should still be entitled to rental assistance; that to take away rental assistance, while also taking into account their income for the purpose of assessing their rent under the state's assessment of their rent, would be inequitable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the adjournment of the debate on Thursday, Senator Neal asked me a question about the proposition which I raised in debate: that those who are subletting in public housing often pay more than the total rent that is payable. You asked me some questions about that, if you recall, Senator Neal.

SPEECH.PARA: My statement was based on anecdotal evidence that my department has gathered across its network that this is a fairly common occurrence, but it is not the only basis on which that statement was made. I understand from my department that the information that many subtenants pay more rent than the main tenant pays to the state housing authority comes from pilot review activity. In preparation for the introduction of measures such as these, the department does preparatory work, pilot studies and reviews. This review found that 100 per cent of those claiming rent assistance claimed more than the rent which would be paid to the state housing authority by a couple on a social security payment with a dependent child or would be paid by a sole parent with a dependent child.

It is important to understand that, irrespective of whether the subtenant pays more or pays less than the total rent that is payable on the house, that household is receiving a double subsidy if they receive rent assistance at all. Some people will not be paying any rent to the head tenant and they will not be getting any rent assistance, so there is only one subsidy there. They may be paying only a very small amount of rent, and there will be no entitlement to rent assistance there.

I can give some examples which I think indicate the people who will be caught by this measure and the rationale for their being caught up in it. If you have a single, unemployed social security customer who is over 21 living with a parent in public housing, she will be receiving a maximum newstart allowance of $160.75 a week. As a result of declaring the daughter's income, the parents' rent would increase by an amount depending on the different rules in each state. I understand that my department has circulated to the parties a table which demonstrates—

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't received anything yet.

—I understood that it had been circulated. I am sorry if you have not received it, but I can give you the information that I wanted you to have. In New South Wales, Victoria and the Northern Territory, the rent will increase by 20 per cent of the daughter's income, if it is declared, of course. If the state housing authority have the increased income declared to them, the rent will increase by 20 per cent of the daughter's income in New South Wales, Victoria and the Northern Territory. In Western Australia, it is 25 per cent, but in Queensland, South Australia and the ACT it is only 10 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: If, for example, parents were charging their daughter $70 a week, which is not an unusual amount, certainly in several states, for the rent of a room, the maximum rent assistance of $24.90 per week is payable. The household will be receiving a subsidised rent, but the daughter will also be receiving $24.90 a week. So there are the two subsidies. In Queensland, South Australia and the ACT, the rent assistance of $24.90 which the daughter receives exceeds the increase in rent that they will be charged of $16 a week. So the household will get $9 more a week in rent assistance than they are asked to pay in additional rent. That surely is inequitable to the taxpayers, and it is inequitable to renters because renters in the private market receive no subsidised rent and then only receive a percentage of their rent in rent assistance.

I gave an example in which $70 a week might have been charged. If the daughter pays $60 a week in rent, she will get $18 a week in rent assistance. Parents living in New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia would pay $32.15 in extra rent and, therefore, the family rent would go up by a net $14. But, in the same case in Queensland, South Australia and the ACT, the family rent would in fact go down by a net $2, and that is the difference between the extra rent and the rent assistance. I am trying to demonstrate why it is an equitable and a reasonable measure—

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't know why you haven't provided this already.
—I am sorry if it has not come to you.
—It's too late to be sorry. It has given us no opportunity to scrutinise it.

—Nevertheless, I am giving it to you on the Senate record, Senator Neal. I have noticed that problem when I get opposition amendments at the very last minute, so I sympathise with you. But this was not intended to deceive you.

SPEECH.PARA: The circumstances in which these changes were proposed by the government in its most recent budget are fair and equitable as between taxpayers and those who receive taxpayer's assistance, and as between tenants in private and public rental. It is surely not unreasonable that two subsidies should not be payable into the same household for the same purpose—namely, housing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I really find it quite extraordinary that the minister was scratching around last week unable to find supporting evidence and so used the term `anecdotal'. Any of us can race out and claim that someone said to us that this was the situation. But that certainly is not evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister now claims to have made this second pilot study available but, despite having had the whole weekend to make it available to the opposition for proper scrutiny, she has not done so. Certainly, I would like to examine the methodology of this survey: what it really shows, where it was taken, what the sample was, whether it indicates isolated examples which support the minister's particular prejudiced view or whether it shows that this is the case as a more general rule. I must say that the failure of this minister to provide that survey for examination or scrutiny in any reasonable time scale seems to indicate that it may not hold up under any sort of scrutiny. I would suggest that it really does not bode well for the democratic processes of this chamber to see this occur in this way.

Looking briefly at the example which the minister provided, it seems quite extraordinary that, having searched all the possible examples of these types of circumstances, the worst example which the minister can come up with is one that shows this unemployed young person living in a family where people are either on social security or are in very low income situations, and who could be potentially $8 worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine dollars better off.

—That is right; that is what you alleged. I really feel that the minister, for all the evidence that she claims she had last time, is not building a very good argument if all she can show is that, on a worst case analysis, a person could be $9 better off. I suppose it does allow us to look at the opposite view. If the reverse were true then, by my calculations, the whole household will be $9 better off but, in a situation where this comes into effect, it appears to me—and maybe the department could confirm this—that the household would in fact be approximately $16 worse off. Is that correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already given those figures but I will go through them for you again, Senator, if you like.
—I'm just asking you to confirm them, not to read them out again.

—Clearly, I had better read them out again. In the case where a daughter pays $50 a week to her parents, the rent assistance payable will be $10.50 a week. If she pays $60 a week, the rent assistance payable will be $18 a week. If she pays $70 a week, the maximum rent assistance of $24.90 a week is payable. In Queensland, South Australia and the ACT, the rent assistance of $24.90 which the daughter receives exceeds the increase in rent of $16 a week. So, the household receives $9 a week more in rent assistance than they are being asked to pay in additional rent.

—You support exactly my argument. Under your example, because that daughter was living in the household, it would have to pay an additional $16 rental. But if this proposed amendment put by the government is carried, she would no longer receive rental assistance. So, as a result of this change, a low income family living in public housing—hardly the high fliers of the Australian community—would be $16 worse off under your example.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —No. The rent assistance which the daughter receives exceeds the increase in rent of $16 a week. So they are a net $9 a week better off. Yet the taxpayer is paying twice for that household.
—Minister, if your change comes into effect, that person in that situation would no longer receive rental assistance. That is the situation, isn't it, Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course that is right, because we do not believe that it is equitable that people should be receiving subsidies from the taxpayer for the same housing twice over, and they do not get twice over in private rental. The majority of people on low incomes—people on social security—are renting in the private sector. So if the same daughter was paying that amount of money to the same parents in private rental and all the circumstances were the same, there would not be that second subsidy. Why should it be payable when they happen to be renting a public house?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the ALP, I am not convinced by the figures that have been put before us. I find it extremely unlikely that somebody on newstart would be contributing $70 a week rent to a household under those circumstances. I can imagine that that $70 might be handed over to the family for board and other matters but I think it is extremely unlikely that it would be a contribution to rent.

SPEECH.PARA: My question to the minister is: how many people were part of the pilot review which was conducted? Is it possible to provide the Senate with details of the findings of that review? Also, has there been a chance now for the government to re‐examine what I understand were savings of $57 million associated with this change? I have been talking with a number of housing advocacy groups who say that, at most, they think this is likely to be worth at least $4 million.

One again, as I said in my speech on the second reading, this seems like a sledgehammer approach to matters. It is by no means clear that what is turning out to be a bit of a witch‐hunt is actually going to expose any rorting at all. I just ask the minister if she could perhaps confirm some details about that pilot review and let the Senate know what was in it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the departmental officials that this has been under review by the department. It has involved several hundred people. I doubt whether it will be possible to make it available because we would be in breach of the privacy rules in terms of individuals' privacy. It is a review of individuals, Senator.

—Is it not possible to get copies of the general outline of the review, including the number of people, without providing details of names? I do not think the Senate is looking for that. I think this was what was asked for some time ago—real case studies, real examples and some statistics which would allow us to consider this legislation a bit more carefully.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that we could depersonalise the information. It might take us a little while. It would mean requiring us to adjourn this debate again. If the Senate would require that, we could provide it.

—The second part of my question was about the savings likely—the $57 million in the budget as a result of this measure. Has there been a chance for a review of that? Are we really going to save that much money? How many people will be affected? Is it not more like a much smaller sum?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you were to look at the initial few pages of the explanatory memorandum, you would find details of schedule 19, entitled `Rent assistance for people living with public housing tenants'. The financial impact in 1997-98, which has been estimated by my department, in conjunction, as always, with the Department of Finance, is that there would be $21.068 million in savings. In 1998-99, there would be $58.090 million in savings and in 1999‐00, there would be $59.825 million in savings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to run through this example again because, even though the minister went through the example, she does not really seem to appreciate the impact of it. The example that you have given was of a young woman aged 21 living at home and receiving an income of $160. Because she is living in that household in public housing, the family is required to pay an additional $32 in rent.
—In some states.

—In New South Wales, where most public housing tenants would come from. Bearing in mind that she only earns $160, it would probably be pretty difficult to earn much from rental assistance. If she paid $70—that is, almost half her income—she would receive a maximum of $24.90 rental assistance. That means that, even on your example, that household would be receiving less in rental assistance than they are paying—$7.10 less.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have to look at the reverse side of the coin. That is what I was trying to emphasise earlier, Minister. If you achieve the measure that you are proposing, a family in the example that you have provided would still be paying an additional $32 in public rental housing and would not be receiving any rental assistance. So they would be $24.90 worse off.

That is where the sting in the tail is of all this. It does bring about budget savings. We save $57 million by what is proposed to be done by this government, but that $57 million comes straight out of the pockets of low income families who are struggling to keep their families together and who usually have young people with them who are struggling to get work, so they can provide them with moral support, and to some extent financial support as well. That is a pretty poor proposition. I think it is reasonable, where they are losing money and paying additional rent because of their income, that they also receive rental assistance.

While I am on my feet I would like to deal with one other issue that was raised by the minister late in debate last week. This was the view that this measure was justified because some people acted fraudulently and did not declare the income that they were earning. I must confess that my view is very much that, if there is fraud occurring, fraud should be pursued and rooted out. But I do not believe that people who honestly apply for the benefits that they are entitled to should be punished because of the minister's anecdotal view that there are people committing fraud.

I am sure there are some people who commit fraud. You can always find some in the system. But I do not believe that the way to deal with fraud is to punish those who are acting honestly, which is exactly what this measure does. I certainly am of the strong view that we should not be double punishing those people who stay together in families, even in a situation where older children are living at home and the total rent payable by the family has increased. I believe that they are still entitled to rental assistance and that to take away this measure would be totally unfair and un‐Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the review found that 24 per cent of people in public housing dwellings were receiving rent assistance. Extrapolated across the portfolio that has meant that it has been estimated that 44,000 people are receiving rent assistance in public housing dwellings, which I think goes to what Senator Allison was after earlier, but which I was not able to give her from the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose we have a basic disagreement with the opposition because they propose an amendment which would continue what we believe is an inequitable situation. It is inequitable that two amounts of public subsidy should go to somebody who is fortunate enough to be able to access public housing. The three times as many people who are renting on low incomes but who pay high rents in the private sector have no opportunity for the taxpayer to call twice with their subsidy. Our proposal is fair because it ensures that all low income renters receive assistance. The private tenants receive rent assistance and the public tenants receive subsidised rent. We do not believe it is equitable that public tenants should get the benefits of two subsidies on their housing. We do not think it is fair to the taxpayer to be paying two subsidies on the one house. Therefore, I commend the government's direction. I have tried to provide the extra information that was required. If Senator Allison still requires further information I will try to get it but it would mean adjourning the debate. But if that is required I will do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I think we probably have the picture now. I do not know that further is information required. I think you put your finger on this whole debate in what you have just said, and that is that somehow there is an unfair advantage going to people who are in public housing. This kind of thinking has driven this whole debate about housing so far. It is most unfortunate. It suggests that housing in this country should be along the welfare lines approach—that only those who are the most desperate should have access to public housing and that somehow they have to be punished for the fact that there is not enough to go around for those in the private sector. It is a great pity that the government sees things in those terms. The Democrats will be supporting the ALP amendments.
—Minister, I ask you to table the pilot study that you were previously quoting from.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not quoting from a pilot study. I was telling the Senate about a pilot study. It was a pilot review preparatory to this legislation coming before the parliament. It was reviewing customers, as we normally do constantly throughout the year for a variety of reasons. I have made the important point, I thought, to Senator Allison that I could not possibly bring a review which involved people's private details on to the floor of the Senate for good and proper privacy reasons. But I did say that if the Senate chose to adjourn this debate we would then work to depersonalise the review outcomes and bring them to the Senate. I have offered that already. But I was not quoting from a pilot review; I was telling you that a pilot review prior to this measure coming forward was done to estimate the incidence of people being subtenants in the public sector and getting rent assistance.
—Are you assuming that 24 per cent of people who claim rent assistance in public housing are cheating, or are they doing it within the rules?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the officials did not really understand your question. We cannot assume that they are cheating at all, and I have made no such claim. I would like that to be very clearly on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made it clear that inevitably there will be some people cheating—some people who say that they are paying, say, $70—getting a receipt for $70, not declaring it to the housing department and in fact getting a lower rent than they otherwise would have had to pay on the total dwelling and also getting rent assistance from the taxpayer for rent that is not paid. I am not claiming that 44,000 people are doing that but I am saying that there will be an incidence of that because it is human nature. Wherever you might like to look—whether it is in the parliament or in social security—people do try to access payments to which they are not entitled. Would you suggest that it was any different for the subtenants of public housing?

TALK.START.PARA: —You made the claim, based on this review that you cannot table, that there were people who were paying more in rent to their parents or to the main tenant than was actually payable in increased rent. You claimed earlier in debate that a certain number of persons living as subtenants in public housing were paying more in rent to the main tenant than the rent was increased by. What was the size of the sample that that was based on?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the review—that precise item—that you are speaking about was based on a sample of 60.
—Minister, do you feel quite secure making decisions on policy for the whole of Australia based on a one‐off example involving a sample of 60 people?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I tried to make it clear to the senator that that is not the totality of this measure. When you are talking specifically about people who are getting more than they are in fact paying, then we are talking about a sample of 60. Other reviews, as I said earlier, have been covering several hundred people. The 44,000 are not deemed to be cheats—some will be. A proportion of them will also be getting more than they are entitled to. You have confused the pilot of 60 with a wider ranging pilot.
—Minister, what were the profiles of those 60 people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I for one would be assisted if we were to postpone the consideration of this clause until we obtain the information that has been requested, and is obviously being requested, by Senator Neal. It is probably difficult for the committee to take things on the run. I know that that is not the minister's intention. It would assist the committee, particularly considering the substantial nature of this particular provision which is being sought to be amended, and I for one would appreciate the opportunity to study the matter further once the minister comes back with details of the review, the state housing authority's approach to this and the net amount of increase that may occur in housing department rents.

SPEECH.PARA: Another aspect is that the minister mentioned the question of double dipping, and I would certainly like to have another think about all of that.
Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Margetts moved by way of an amendment:

At the end of the motion, add "and the Senate declares that, in spite of anything contained in these bills, it expects and requires ministers to ensure that, as far as practicable, when senators request representatives of a body in receipt of money appropriated by the Parliament or subject to any direction or control by the Commonwealth, to attend before any committee considering estimates or annual reports, such representatives will attend as requested".
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.STATE: (Western Australia ‐ Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table supplementary memoranda relating to these bills.

SPEECH.PARA: AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1996
The bill.
Motion by (Senator Ian Campbell) proposed:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Clause 15, page 10 (after line 10), at the end of the clause, add:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) For the purposes of this section, an Agency is taken not to include any persons who are employed or engaged under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 and who are allocated to the Agency by regulations for the purposes of the definition of Agency in section 5 of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 .

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be reasonable for the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer to give us some explanation of what the amendment is about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to do so. The proposed amendment has been distributed for some time. It removes any obligation on the Auditor‐General to undertake performance audits of the staff of members or senators. It is not removing anything to do with the financial side of the auditing of members' or senators' offices. It particularly removes our performance audits. The government's view is that the performance of members and senators is audited by the Australian electors once every three years. For an Auditor‐General to seek to audit performance is another matter that is outside what is required.

—I am not sure that that entirely explains why that was in the act in the first place or why it should be removed. My understanding is that it was included because of an anomaly in relation to a media body—they were not quite parliamentary staff and they were acting independently.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is to deal only with staff under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act and does not seek to deal with any other categories of people.

—The National Media Liaison Service, otherwise known as aNiMaLS, was part of that and was an anomaly. What guarantee do we have that there will not be that kind of anomaly? Why can't we continue to have legislation that looks at that area, which, as you will recall, was always a problem in the past? Why can't we cover that contingency if necessary?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Media Liaison Service was established under the previous government, and most people in this chamber know that we abolished that organi sation. Apparently the staff of the National Media Liaison Service, I am advised, was employed under the MOP(S) Act. This government has made its policy clear in relation to that body—we have abolished it. You have sought an assurance as to why this would not happen in the future. It is this government's policy that that structure not be re‐established. That was our policy before the election, and it was put into action straight after the election.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as giving an assurance that something looking like the NMLS will not appear at some stage in the future of Australia, I cannot do that. Certainly, the policy of this government is not to have a media liaison service in the shape of the NMLS, which you have drawn attention to.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 18, page 12 (lines 8 to 11), definition of Commonwealth public sector , omit "(other than GBEs)" (wherever occurring).

This is our preferred amendment. It is our first option, which of course is our preferred option, to delete the qualification `other than government business enterprises' from the definition of Commonwealth public sector in section 18 subsection (4) of division 2, performance audits.

As honourable senators would probably be aware, there are four categories of audit in division 2. The first, in section 15, gives the Auditor‐General the ability to conduct a performance audit of an agency at any time. The second and third categories relate to Commonwealth authorities and subsidiaries and Commonwealth companies and subsidiaries. Sections 16 and 17 outline the Auditor‐General's power with regard to performance audit of these bodies. Whilst there is an exclusion in subsection (1) of both sections preventing the Auditor‐General from conducting a performance audit of a government business enterprise at any time, subclause (2) in both sections gives the responsible minister, the Minister for Finance or the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit the ability to request such an audit. As indicated in my speech on the second reading, I will be watching the operation of these sections with considerable interest.

The fourth category of audit relates to a review or examination of a particular aspect of the operations of the whole or a part of the Commonwealth public sector. Unfortunately, the definition of Commonwealth public sector excludes government business enterprises, and I think this is totally inappropriate. If you are going to conduct the whole of government or sectoral examination, you will in many cases need to incorporate the activities of government business enterprises to enable a proper perspective on the issues, particularly given the proliferation of government business enterprises in recent years.

My amendment 1 on sheet 659 therefore seeks to omit the qualification `other than government business enterprises' from the definition of Commonwealth public sector. The theme will come up again and again that the government is tending to take a managerial approach to government business enterprises. My concerns are that the more at arm's length you are from an enterprise the more accountable, not less accountable, it needs to be.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 18, page 12 (lines 8 to 11), definition of Commonwealth public sector , after "GBEs" (wherever occurring), insert "accepted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit as GBEs with significant private sector financial ownership".

As my amendment No.1 was not supported, we do have a compromise position, which is consistent with an amendment moved by Senator Short during debate on the Auditor‐General Bill 1994. In this amendment, the exception `other than government business enterprises' in the definition is qualified by inserting the words `accepted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit as government business enterprises with significant private sector financial ownership'.

This is not my preferred position, but it was one put up by the then opposition in 1994. This amendment therefore continues to allow the inclusion of government business enter prises that are largely or solely owned by the taxpayer in wide ranging performance audits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition, as I am advised, has amended this piece of legislation to empower the JCPA to request such an audit, and we think that is the appropriate way to pursue the matter that the then Senator Jim Short raised in that debate. We think that covers it, so we will not be supporting this further amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 15 (after line 12), after clause 23, insert:
(1) If, in preparing a report under this Part (other than a report under section 20):

TAB.TAB: (a) the Auditor‐General becomes aware of an arrangement between an Agency, a Commonwealth authority or a Commonwealth company and any body or person (including another Agency, Commonwealth authority or Commonwealth company) for the provision of goods or services to, or on behalf of, that Agency, Commonwealth authority or Commonwealth company; and

PARA.TAB: (b) the arrangement includes a requirement that any information in connection with the arrangement be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence information;

(c) appropriate in the circumstances; and
(d) necessary to prevent unfairly prejudicing the commercial interests of any body or person; and
(e) in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The Auditor‐General must include particulars of a determination under subsection (1) in the report, together with reasons for making the determination.
(3) In making a determination under subsection (1), the Auditor‐General must take into account:

TAB.TAB: (a) whether there is any legislative basis for the requirement that information be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence information; and
(b) whether the risk of prejudice to the commercial interests of any body or person outweighs the public interest in disclosure.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) In this section:

TAB.TAB: arrangement includes a contract.
Commonwealth authority includes a Commonwealth authority that is a GBE.
Commonwealth company includes a Commonwealth company that is a GBE.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment refers to the assessment of commercial‐in‐confidence claims. As Labor senators well know from the committees on which they have had a very active participation, the whole area of outsourcing, privatisation, contracting out and tendering is starting to worry parliament and its committees, the Senate and its committees, very much. Questioning at various committees and hearings has indicated an alarming and unnecessary increase, in our view, in the exclusion of government expenditure and contracts from parliamentary scrutiny through the device of commercial‐in‐confidence claims. Government agencies are now adopting the practice of automatically offering commercial‐in‐confidence protection without even being requested to do so by tenderers and contractors. It is a process and protection that is extravagantly used and widely abused.

Members of the Senate may know that I have considerable business experience and considerable negotiating experience, and it is profoundly foolish for anybody in that situation to offer up something which gives away something on your side when it is unnecessary to do so. Persons in the public sector, some of them quite senior, are, in all innocence sometimes, thinking that they are being helpful in the process of generating interest and responsiveness in this area when in fact what they are doing is severely curtailing the ability of the parliament to examine commercial‐in‐confidence matters.

Senator Lundy and I were absolutely astonished to hear at a committee hearing the persons responsible for putting out indications of interest on computer matters saying that they had automatically sent out a notice that those responding could get commercial‐in‐confidence and that they would be protected across the whole range of things. This is an extremely dangerous process that is starting to become a practice, and this amendment is designed to deal with it. The amendment of clause 23A will set in place a system whereby the Auditor‐General, who is the important public accountability agent of the parliament, will be responsible for determining whether or not information should be subject to public release.

Under this amendment the Auditor‐General and not the Attorney‐General, who is a politician as well as a legal officer, will be responsible for determining either that information not be disclosed in order to protect the commercial interests of any body or person or that the information is in the public interest and must be publicly released and presented to parliament.

This amendment clause also requires that the Auditor‐General give reasons for his or her decision in their report. This is consistent with administrative principles well established under the previous government, which requires that reasons for decisions be provided. It also acts as a check on the Auditor‐General's actions as it demands that the auditor focuses his or her mind on the basis for their decision and that their decision must be backed by the requirement set out in the amendment.

My amendment refers to all audits done by the Auditor‐General under part IV but excludes reports under section 20, where the Auditor‐General may enter into an arrangement on a fee for service basis. Where the Auditor‐General encounters a commercial‐in‐confidence clause in any arrangement between a Commonwealth entity and any other body or person, including another Commonwealth entity for the provision of goods and services to or on behalf of that entity, the Auditor‐General must include in the report an assessment of the commercial‐in‐confidence requirement. We as a Senate must have that information. We as a parliament must have that information on behalf of the people. We cannot be locked out in the process of private sector to bureaucracy to executive with us last and excluded.

Government business enterprises are included among the bodies whose arrangements may be scrutinised under this clause. There is no power in my amendment provisions for the Auditor‐General to make recommendations about how parliament might deal with commercial‐in‐confidence material. It is up to parliament to determine its procedures, and that is quite proper. We have, within parliament, the ability to hear matters in confidence, in camera and in a manner which protects people, institutions, companies and persons appropriately. There are arguments about commercial‐in‐confidence which are frequently pitted against an individual's rights once competitive tender arrangements come into play. But, frankly, we as a Senate must err on the side of the public. We must err on the side of public interest, not on the side of private interest, mateship and persons who benefit from exclusion, secrecy and connivance.

It is important that there is a broader transparency of the service standards expected from the contractor. The New Zealand experience also provides a useful precedent in contracting out in commercial‐in‐confidence clauses. In 1989, when their state owned enterprises, which are the equivalent of our government business enterprises, were established, the administrative package of the ombudsman, freedom of information, privacy and the Auditor‐General was extended to cover activities of these new enterprises. The New Zealand experience has shown this to be important in the maintenance of public confidence in and the probity of these activities. Significantly in New Zealand, all contracts are public documents with only the detail of the schedule of costs being omitted. The operator must be able to prove commercial prejudice if it does not wish to disclose such details.

The public interest in transparency is primary. Our role as a Senate is to protect the public interest; that is what this is about. It is fundamental that the public are given worthwhile information about how the public's money is being used and its affairs conducted, subject only to statutory restraints and exceptions.

I am not aware of how Labor are to vote but I want to publicly record my thanks to Senator Lundy who, on behalf of Labor, has been pursuing these kinds of matters with some energy and some determination and I think that is very helpful in this process. I commend to you my amendment on sheet No. 607 to clause 23A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think commercial‐in‐confidence is becoming the mantra of the 1990s. It is going to be tried on more and more as more and more government services are outsourced and government goods and services are produced by private enterprise. As I mentioned before, that should mean more accountability rather than less. The amendments put by Senator Murray are helpful in this regard. In the end it means that if there were a challenge to the ruling it would fall back perhaps to the Australian Administrative Appeals Tribunal and that is probably an appropriate way for that to happen.

SPEECH.PARA: In the way things are operating now, private companies providing services and business entities associated with government simply have to throw up the words `commercial‐in‐confidence' and it is not challenged. In reality the definition that is accepted by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is quite specific and many of the throwaway lines and statements not just by companies and by government business enterprises but also by government when they do not want to give information to the Senate would well be challengeable under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

We simply cannot have a situation where we are moving in one direction, where much more of taxpayers' money is being allocated to the private sector to provide services and where those simple words, commercial‐in‐confidence, are stopping the accountability of how that money is being spent. It is simply not enough to suggest that waiting to perhaps review a contract is going to be good enough; it is not. It is not clear and it is not accountable. I am very keen to see what the Labor Party will be doing on this amendment because it links into the kinds of things we are doing in this bill as well, which are very important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment of Senator Murray touches on an important issue in accountability: that of commercial‐in‐confidence information associated with government activity. There has been, as Senator Murray has referred to, a significant increase over the years in the practice of governments claiming that information cannot be provided, for example to Senate estimates committees, due to its commercial nature. While this is no doubt necessary and proper in many cases, it can lead to the impression that full disclosure has not been made.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment proposes that, where the AG is aware of an arrangement between the Commonwealth and a commercial body and that arrangement includes a requirement that some information must be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence, the AG must make a decision about whether or not the information should be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence and include such information in the relevant audit report.

Again the amendment which covers an important area imposes strict conditions on the AG we note without any concrete outcome. The amendment forces the AG to come to an opinion about whether information should have been considered to be commercial‐in‐confidence, but not granting the AG any additional powers into whether or not the information should be published.

We have come to the conclusion that this provision may impose a massive workload on the AG without actually securing any increase in public disclosure of information. Therefore, we will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (1.31 p.m.)—The coalition will not be supporting the amendment. I think Senator Sherry has raised the concern that we have that this requires that, if the Auditor-General becomes aware of such an arrangement, then he has no alternative but to spend time considering that arrangement, even if the arrange ment turns out to be not germane to the main object of his audit.

SPEECH.PARA: It may well be an unintended consequence of what Senator Murray is seeking to do, but it is worth pointing out that the Auditor-General already has an unfettered access to all of these accounts and records. So, if he finds such an arrangement, it will not be hidden from him and he even has the right to use that sort of analysis that he might find in these arrangements as the basis of parts of his report.

There is no doubt in the government's mind that, should the Auditor‐General be required to do this by the legislation, it would create an enormous burden which, as Senator Sherry has quite rightly said, is unlikely to improve the outcome from the parliament's point of view.

I know Senator Murray is thorough in these things, but I am not sure whether he has discussed it with the Auditor-General. I would imagine that he may have. If he has not, I would be fairly certain that the Auditor‐General would regard this as not a way to increase his powers or increase the information he is able to provide to the parliament. In fact, quite the contrary; that it would adversely affect the implementation of his duties and would create an enormous burden upon what are necessarily restricted resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very convenient excuse. The reason I say that is that often governments and the executive of government makes that decision. I am sure senators have heard the debate in this chamber as to why the Auditor-General cannot be asked to conduct an audit. The chamber cannot do it because it will involve commercial‐in‐confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: I would think that these amendments are seeking to remove that excuse so that you will not have somebody who does not go through that process making that decision, as has happened with ANL and other government business enterprises during the term of the previous government. The executive government off the top of its head, and without going through this process, made the decision. They threw back to the chamber that the reason why these audits could not be done was because of the commercial‐in‐confidence element.

Basically this amendment is saying that the Auditor-General should be allowed to handle that and here is a process by which they can do that. We no longer have an excuse that the executive government is making that decision about what is commercial‐in‐confidence, without even having a process by which they must be accountable in that decision making process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (1.34 p.m.)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that there is absolutely nothing in this amendment or in the legislation that fetters the Auditor-General in any way in relation to his access to whatever accounts or records he needs. He can look at all of these matters. The government cannot direct him where not to look. He can look at all of these matters. He can look at commercial‐in‐confidence documents, accounts and records wherever he needs to do so. I do not think Senator Margetts' argument is based on the right premise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I might be one of few people in the chamber today—although there may be persons outside—who has actually had experience as an auditor. Amongst the many things I have done, this is one of them. I was an auditor for the government, although not this government.

SPEECH.PARA: We should have a look at the fallaciousness of the arguments against this amendment proposed so far and perhaps proposed in a little bit of ignorance, rather than through any desire to score points. The amendment states:
If, in preparing a report under this Part—

What happens with any auditing process is that very few auditors anywhere, because of sheer volume of work to be examined, do a complete and thorough audit of every single aspect of the entity under the microscope. They do a sample, indicative or test audit in those areas in which they think there may be a concern or a need to have a look at the information before them.

BREAK.PARA: The auditors are doing that and, as a matter of course, they will then come across contracts, arrangements, memorandums of understanding or any other form of commercial agreement between the government and the private sector as an example. They are going to report on that. In other words, they have already looked at that contract. This is not a new exercise. This is not going out and examining every single contract there is. They have looked at the contract. In doing so they will have formed an opinion, because that is what auditors have to do; they have to form an opinion.
What the amendment says is that if, in reporting a report—
. . . the Auditor-General becomes aware of an arrangement—
in other words, they have looked at a document and become aware of an arrangement and—
. . . the arrangement includes a requirement that any information in connection with the arrangement be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence information;—
in other words, in the normal carrying‐out of their duties they have identified the contract and within the contract they have identified that there is a commercial‐in‐confidence clause—
. . . the Auditor-General must determine whether in his or her opinion, the requirement that information be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence information is:
appropriate in the circumstances;

So they have been doing the normal audit; they have seen the contract; they have looked in the contract and seen the commercial-in-confidence clause; and they say to themselves that it is or is not appropriate, that it is or is not necessary to prevent unfairly prejudicing the commercial interests of any body or person and that it is or is not in the public interest. There is no extra work, Senator Sherry; no extra work, Senator Campbell. That is what auditing is. I see the parliamentary secretary shaking his head. I am fairly certain that, in his varied background, he has not been an auditor, and I have. The amendment goes on:
(2) The Auditor-General must include particulars of a determination under subsection (1) in the report, together with reasons for making the determination.
(3) . . . the Auditor‐General must take into account:
(a) whether there is any legislative basis for the requirement that information be treated as commercial‐in‐confidence information; and
(b) whether the risk of prejudice to the commercial interests of any body or person outweighs the public interest in disclosure.

Yes, there is some extra work at that stage of the process but not in the auditing stage. It is in the reporting stage that the extra work is there. We are not requiring them through this process to examine every single contract and every single piece of paper between government and the private sector.

I concede that Labor has already declared its hand here and I understand what the parliamentary secretary has said. Generally speaking, I expect government to reject automatically just about everything that comes before it. But it is a great shame that the government has not thought through this process and has not accepted its responsibility for the public interest, which I believe is being abrogated as a result of new practices which are emerging from the intensified focus on tendering, on contracting‐out, on privatisation and on all the additional interactions with the private sector that have been occurring over the last few years.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I wonder whether it is possible to make a slight change to the order of amendments on the running sheet. If Senator Murray puts his next amendment first, an element of it might need to be changed if my amendment subsequently is agreed to. It might work better if the Senate agrees to deal with the amendments in the other order.
—Nobody seems to be objecting, Senator Margetts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 37, page 23 (lines 18 to 25), omit subclause (3).

Greens (WA) amendment 3 on sheet 659 deals with what we believe is one of the most fundamental elements of this package of bills. It is my belief that clause 37, subclause (3), is a major challenge to the independence of parliament and the ability of parliament and parliamentary committees to determine how sensitive issues are handled. This is a challenge to the parliament's ability to effectively scrutinise activities of government and to keep them accountable.

This particular subclause also implies that the parliament cannot be trusted. You have to understand that we are entrusted to make laws. We are entrusted to change the way companies operate in Australia, the way resources are dealt with and the way education, and so on, is dealt with. Somehow or other, that subclause is saying that parliament cannot be entrusted to deal with issues that deal with accountability where that accountability moves into the company sector.

When read in conjunction with subclause (2) of clause 37, subclause (3) becomes extraordinarily broad. It means that sensitive information such as issues of national security, cabinet deliberations, Commonwealth-state relations, or commercial interest, or issues associated with possible judicial proceedings—let us face it, it could be anything—can be withheld from the parliament by the Auditor-General.

It is interesting that we had this debate a very short while ago on Senator Murray's amendment. Suddenly we said, `The Auditor-General can't be forced to do this.' Senator Murray argued very well, I believe, that this would be a normal part of an Auditor-General's role anyway. We want to make that very clear.

Whilst I have serious concerns with the broad nature of many of the reasons for excluding information contained in subclause (2), I am prepared to accept that some of those categories are valid reasons for excluding information from a report of the Auditor-General. However, to then take that question one step further by incorporating a clause that says that the Auditor-General cannot be required, and is not permitted, to disclose to the parliament or to a parliamentary committee information that is prohibited from being included in public reports is a major attack on the rights of parliament to scrutinise the executive, and it displays a major lack of trust in the ability of parliamentary committees in particular to be able to handle such information in a sensitive manner. I trust that the Senate will see fit to support my amendment, which omits this subclause entirely from the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Margetts to omit subclause (3) of clause 37 be agreed to.

—I find it interesting and I also find it hard to understand why there is no response at all in relation to this amendment—and, as we have said before, this has been part of controversial bills over time—from either the government or the opposition. It might be embarrassing, because these are the kinds of things they might say when they are not in government. But perhaps Labor are thinking, `Well, we might be in government again at some stage and we would like to be able to rule by executive government.' I just do not see why there is no response at all at the moment in relation to this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will say a few words. One reason is consideration of time. Labor has taken a position on this package of legislation consistent with our position in government. I went through that extensively, Senator Margetts, in my comments during the second reading debate. Labor did develop the package of legislation that we are dealing with. It is not substantially different from the position we took in government. We see no good reason to vary our stated position from that time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just add, Madam Temporary Chair, that just because the government does not get up and respond to every single suggestion that the Greens make does not mean that there is some conspiracy of silence. This matter has been the subject of, I think, something like—
—It is eight years.

—Eight years. It has been to the JCPA two or three times, to two other committees a couple of times, and to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Committee at least once. Most of these issues have been sawn until the sawdust is tiny. Just because we do not stand up to respond to every single suggestion that the Greens might happen to make, I do not think it is fair to say there is some sort of conspiracy of silence. We will respond to the things that seem to require some sort of substantive response. But we would like to see this package, after eight years, move into law without much further delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Madam Chair: I think that is a little offensive to the minor parties, Senator Campbell. The minor parties are not able to hold up legislation or to introduce legislation to this chamber. It is determined by the government what legislation shall be before the chamber, and it is determined by the two major parties how it will proceed and on what basis it will proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would draw your attention to the fact that this Auditor‐General Bill 1996 only has six amendments to it, and those six amendments relate to serious matters with which the Senate is properly concerned. I really do not think it is appropriate for you to have a swipe at Senator Margetts in the process. She is raising issues that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —She had a swipe at us.
—She had a swipe at us just because I was silent.

—But the fact is that she would like to know your response to her concerns, and I thought that was legitimate. We are not here to push this thing into any further delays. We have had six amendments; four have been dealt with in a very short period of time, and there are two to go.

—One of the reasons why this is of particular interest to me right at this stage in the debate is that, in the previous amendment, when we talked about whether or not the Auditor-General could make decisions in a clear process about what needed to be kept back from parliamentary or public purview, it was the minister who stood and said, `What Senator Margetts is not acknowledging is that the Auditor-General has the right to access all of the documents once they get access to the audit.' This is exactly why I believe it was necessary to at least have this debate. Here we have what puts the shackles on the ability of that information going out to be in the public arena in any way, including through parliamentary process in confidence, if that is necessary.

BREAK.PARA: It seems ridiculous that just a few minutes ago the minister was suggesting that it would be okay, providing the Auditor-General has access to these documents when they get access to do an audit; and if they cannot do anything with it, that is okay. That really puts quite a conflict in relation to this, if the Auditor-General cannot be required and is not permitted to disclose to the parliament or to a parliamentary committee information that is prohibited from being included in public reports.

Therefore, we are saying that you do not want the Auditor-General to make the decision based on a clear set of guidelines; you do not want to leave it to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; you would like to keep it with executive decision making—and not only would you like to keep it with executive decision making but so would the ALP. The ALP are looking at their watches, tapping their feet and thinking, `Well, who knows what will happen with an election.' If there is an election, due to whatever reason—double dissolution or whatever—they might find themselves in the same position of wanting executive government to be able to restrict that kind of information not just from going out to the public, but even from going into the parliamentary processes by which we can know whether or not we can exclude perhaps misappropriation from a process.

It is all very well for the government to say, `Everything is aboveboard, trust us, but we can't show you because there are certain elements to it'—and they would include just about anything, as I say, including cabinet deliberations. All I can say is that it is a real problem and it will be an ongoing problem with those people who truly do believe that parliament should not be able to have accountability with the expenditure of public money and that executive privilege, if you like, is suitable in deciding whether or not such issues should, in fact, ever get to the parliamentary process for parliamentary scrutiny in any way, shape or form.
Progress reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is with pleasure that I inform the Senate that Senator Alston has been sworn in as Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. I also wish to inform the Senate that Mr McGauran has resigned from the ministry and Mr Moore has assumed Mr McGauran's responsibilities. These changes do not alter representations in this chamber.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's statement last Friday that he had been informed by his department that some weeks ago there had been discussions between the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet regarding the cover‐up of Mr Sharp's travel claims. Minister, have the relevant officers in the two departments been identified and asked to give details of the conversation and the background to it? Has a search been made of the relevant files in both departments to establish whether there are any written or electronic records which refer to the Prime Minister's office having been briefed on the Sharp affair? Are there any such records and, if so, will you table them?

—I am not sure what Senator Faulkner is referring to in his reference to `some weeks ago'. Certainly the Prime Minister made a statement in the House of Representatives last week in relation to this matter. He made mention of the fact that certain statements had been referred to the Auditor‐General. I believe the Auditor‐General subsequently issued a statement, and I think it is likely that the Prime Minister will make a further statement on the matter. With regard to the detail that is raised within Senator Faulkner's question, I will refer that to the Prime Minister and see what information can be made available.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I think many will find it extraordinary that you are not aware of the statement the Prime Minister made last Friday in relation to the discussions between the Department of Ad ministrative Services and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It has been the subject of much press speculation and comment. Minister, do you accept that the government has an obligation to demonstrate rather than to simply assert that the Prime Minister was not involved in the attempted cover‐up of Mr Sharp's travel claims? Do you accept that the parliament and the public have a right to know the answers to these questions? What action is the government taking to ensure that these questions are answered and that the answers are made public?

—I have not seen any suggestion that runs counter to the Prime Minister's statement to the parliament that he had no personal knowledge of these matters. I have seen no evidence that would suggest otherwise. If Senator Faulkner is claiming some knowledge on his part, perhaps he will put that on the table and that can be pursued.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Will the minister advise the Senate of the growth in superannuation assets and contributions during 1996-97? Does this growth refute the accusation that government superannuation policy has damaged confidence in the superannuation system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that question, Senator Watson. As all senators will know, Senator Watson has a very longstanding interest in the superannuation industry and possesses a great deal of knowledge. I can report that it has been a super year for super both in terms of asset growth and growth in contributions. This has been one of our best years for superannuation.

ANSWER.PARA: Total superannuation assets grew by some 20 per cent during 1996‐97 or a very impressive $1 billion per week. Superannuation assets have crashed through the $300 billion mark for the first time—a very dramatic figure indeed and a very dramatic achievement. Contributions rose by 12 per cent to about $29.5 billion and, on average, I am advised that Australians put more than $500 million into superannuation every week during 1996-97. Member contributions rose by 17 per cent and employer contributions rose by 10 per cent.

These statistics that I have indicated verify the feedback that I have been getting from the industry and funds during my contact with them in recent months. I generally ask how the year has been, and the answer from these practitioners always ranges from `good' to `very good' to `excellent'. I am aware that there have been accusations that government policy has damaged confidence in superannuation. For example, I think one of the most extreme and probably silly comments in this regard came from Senator Sherry, who is on record as saying that every action the government has taken has had the effect of wrecking confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—That's right, says Senator Sherry, despite this magnificent growth in superannuation. I am glad that remark by Senator Sherry is recorded in the Hansard .

ANSWER.PARA: Senators will recall that Senator Sherry made a comment, apparently on the advice of his hairdresser, about the government undermining confidence in super. I do not know whether that hairdresser was based in Burnie, Hobart or on the Gold Coast—it could have been in a range of places. Senator Sherry went on to say, `He has been cutting my hair for 18 years.' I do not know who it was, whether it was Stefan or Johann or whoever, but Senator Sherry said that his hairdresser's confidence in the superannuation system was undermined. Clearly, Senator Sherry should go further afield to get his advice. I think we can say, Senator Sherry, that they may have given you a nice haircut, but they gave you lousy advice on superannuation.

Senator Sherry talked about `wrecking confidence'. Surely, in the light of the statistics which have come out today, even Senator Sherry could not believe those words. Since this government came into office in March 1996, superannuation assets have grown by some $58 billion or virtually 25 per cent. Senator Sherry was wrong, and is wrong again. People are not losing confidence in superannuation, but they should be losing confidence in Senator Sherry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you confident of the future strong growth in superannuation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for his question. The future for superannuation is very bright; it is a great industry. The prospects are there and the support that it is getting from the Australian community and, indeed, from this government, will ensure that the prospects for the industry are very bright.

ANSWER.PARA: The relentless attack on the super industry by Senator Sherry—the allegations of wrecking confidence—were all designed to convince his party to oppose the superannuation surcharge. If we look behind the advice that Senator Nick `don't tax the rich' Sherry gave to caucus that the superannuation surcharge was going to have an adverse affect on superannuation, we see that the reality is that nothing could have been further from the truth. The caucus was very poorly advised by Senator Sherry, and the outlook for superannuation is very bright. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, I refer to the Prime Minister's continuing refusal to table the statement provided by Mr John Sutherland in which he revealed that he had briefed the Prime Minister's office on the Sharp travel allowance affair. I ask: can you confirm that the Auditor‐General has refused to examine this aspect referred to him? How does the principle of sub judice apply in this matter, given that the Auditor‐General will not be considering the matter? Why will the government not table Mr Sutherland's statement?

—I think the statement was not tabled because it relates, obviously, to only one side of the events which we have been referring to. The Prime Minister believed that a more appropriate course of action was to refer it to the Auditor‐General, who was to look at matters that were relevant to what was included within the statement. Since then, I have seen the Auditor‐General referring to the fact this his inquiry really is an efficiency audit into aspects of DAS.
—Is that right?

—I think he has put that on the public record, Senator Carr. You might not read the public record but, if I can help you, I am always pleased to. The Auditor‐General has said that he could take such other evidence as relates to that inquiry. So he is able to seek evidence to enable him to complete the requirements of that efficiency audit. I have to say, for the benefit of Senator Carr, I thought his statement was somewhat ambiguous as to exactly what evidence he could seek to fulfil that responsibility, and I guess that will evolve as time passes by.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I understand that the issue applying in this matter is not sub judice any longer; it is the fact that the statement relates to only one side of the events—a most unusual excuse, I might say, for not tabling such a document. Minister, was there any other minister mentioned in Mr Sutherland's statement, apart from Mr Sharp? Is that the real reason why the Prime Minister has refused to table the statement?

—I have given the real reason and I would not think that there is anything extraordinary in it at all. The point is that the Prime Minister clearly did not want in any way to prejudice the inquiry that was to be undertaken by the Auditor‐General and there was some concern that to put one side of the story on the public record might do so. That is not considered to be appropriate. I would have thought that a rather cautionary approach would be something that Senator Faulkner would applaud.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment. The minister would be well aware of the devastating fires in South‐East Asia—fires which have been covered so well on television and which were possibly a complicating factor in the Garuda crash over the weekend—the loss of life and the great environmental damage. Is there anything Australia can do to assist in this? Is there anything Australia is prepared to do? Have we received any requests from other governments to come to their aid in this matter?
—Stop logging the forests for a start.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some rather ignorant reports attributed to Senator Bob Brown on this matter, Senator MacGibbon. They were unhelpful and unconstructive as usual. The point is that Australia, particularly through me, did make inquiries of the Indonesian Environment Minister the week before last as to whether there were ways in which Indonesia believed that Australia could help address what is a very serious environmental disaster and maybe a very serious health issue as well arising in South‐East Asia.

ANSWER.PARA: Just to answer the interjection I heard to the question, the fires largely result, as I understand it, from Indonesia making available rather more than usual degraded forest to be converted into plantations this year. That process of clearing and burning, which is the traditional way of providing for plantations, has coincided with really extraordinary weather conditions. The two combined have resulted in the condition that is being experienced in the region at the moment.

The fires nevertheless having occurred—there is no doubt that the Indonesian authorities have taken action to try to ensure that further fires are not started in this way; in fact, I think there may also be prosecutions against those who illegally started these fires—the real issue now is how they can be put out as quickly as possible.

Minister Sarwono said to me that the areas in which he felt Australia might be able to assist related to satellite imagery and interpretative facilities that we might have which could give them a better capacity to predict early on the direction of fires and the commencement of fires. If we had that material, he asked whether we could make it available to them. He also said that they would appreciate any information that our Bureau of Meteorology might be able to give on short and medium‐term weather predictions. He said that in the longer term, they would also appreciate advice from our forest management experience in order to help re‐educate from the traditional way of clearing forests for plantations in the region which does lead to these very large forest fires.

As a result, I can advise the Senate that the Australian Bureau of Meteorology has been in direct contact with its Indonesian counterpart and is providing immediate assistance. The National Meteorological Operations Centre in Melbourne is providing smoke trajectory information from weather and satellite data that is being analysed by Australian forecasters. We are providing the Indonesians with weather forecasts to assist in the fight against these fires. The bureau is examining the possibility of providing fire hot spot information using high‐resolution satellite imagery. The bureau has offered to send two officers to Indonesia as part of a short-term mission to assist with a more definitive assessment of medium and long-term needs.

In the longer term, we will also be able to assist in relation to the forest management practices that I referred to and which Indonesia would wish to update. I understand that as well as the Commonwealth government assistance the Victorian and New South Wales governments have offered to provide firefighting manpower and expertise. A response is being awaited from Indonesia. That was specifically put to me at least the week before last. It was not provided by the Indonesian government at that time. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Is the minister aware of suggestions that bushfires in Australia may have contributed to this? Given the prevailing westerly winds in that region, is there any basis for that allegation?

—There were some suggestions of that. I made inquiries and there is no doubt that the consequence of Australia's savanna fires can be experienced in places far distant, but there was no evidence to suggest that these really mild heat fires in northern Australia are contributing to this problem at all. These are forest fires. They are very intense and present a totally different sort of challenge to authorities.

BREAK.PARA: I am pleased that we are offering to do whatever we can to assist because it is very much a regional, if not international, problem and I think all states with the capacity to help should be offering to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. Given that Mr Sharp, Mr Scott and Mr McGauran made secret repayments of travel allowance accrued from 11 March 1996, can you assure the Senate that no other minister in that period made repayments that have been secretly processed?
—I will have to seek advice from the acting minister on the issue of repayments. On the basis of that advice, I will see what information I can provide to the Senate.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Can the minister give us an indication that he thinks that advice could at least reach this chamber in the next two days, rather than never? I am sure he will; he has a record of doing that. Secondly, would he like to explain to us what the principle is when Senator Macdonald, Senator Minchin and other ministers repaid money that was legally claimed at the time and legal now and had their repayment publicised, yet people who illegally claim have it secretly processed? What principle is the government operating in this area?

—I think there was a very large assumption in that question, which Senator Ray has failed to demonstrate. There are a lot of questions that are being asked in relation to travel allowances. I am rather surprised, given the concern of Senator Ray on this matter, that no questions have been raised in relation to the very large claims that have been made by Senator Sherry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer you to a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald which indi cates that the government is attempting to prevent a submission by the Australian Law Reform Commission being given to the Native Title Committee despite the commission's view—

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Abetz interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Excuse me, I wrote it myself. This is despite the commission's view that the legislation falls squarely within its role. Will the minister confirm that the submission warns that the 10-point plan is unconstitutional, breaches international law and is racially discriminatory? Did the acting secretary of the Attorney-General's Department ring the president of the ALRC and inform him that the Attorney-General was strongly opposed to this submission? Did the acting secretary threaten to gag the ALRC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Kernot for that question. I am advised by the Attorney-General that he denies suppressing any submission by the commission, as alleged. In fact, the advice from the Attorney-General is that the ALRC made a submission to the Wik task force on the same subject some time ago.
