ANSWER.PARA: What the Attorney-General has raised with the ALRC is whether it should be making submissions to inquiries and committees on subjects on which the commission has no reference. Under its act the commission acquires references only from the Attorney-General and can perform its functions only in relation to references. It has a reference on adversarial litigation which was given by the previous Attorney-General. It has another reference on the Archives Act which was given to it by the present Attorney-General. At the moment the Attorney-General is considering a new reference.

The commission has no reference on the question of native title and it has no reference on copyright licence matters, although it recently made submissions to different bodies on those subjects. The Attorney-General has stated that the ALRC has done valuable work but it does not have unlimited resources. The Attorney-General has stated that it should focus its resources on references given to it by the government. It is worth noting that in 1994 the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, chaired by the member for Banks, Daryl Melham, examined the role and function of the ALRC. The committee recommended that the Attorney-General continue to have sole power to make references to the ALRC and that the commission only has a right to make suggestions to the Attorney about those references.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the point. It is nowhere near the point.

—Labor clearly have a selective memory. I hear from the comments from Senator Bolkus that he is complaining about this, but this came from one of his colleagues. I am not aware of any contact by the secretary of the department to the ALRC as mentioned by Senator Kernot and I repeat that the Attorney-General denies having suppressed any submission as alleged.

—I ask a supplementary question. On the matter of a reference, minister, it is the commission's view, I understand, that it has an interest in native title legislation through formal references to report on customary law and on adversarial legal processes and, more broadly, through an obligation under its act to take into the account Australia's international human rights obligations. Do you disagree with that? Will the Attorney-General be allowing the commission to submit evidence before the inquiry? Is the minister aware that an instruction not to give evidence constitutes a serious contempt of this parliament? Is this not the government of freedom of speech? You have made a big issue of that. Isn't this the government of respect for the institution of parliament?

—The matter dealing with customary law, I understand, may have been referred in, I think, 1986. As to further detail on that, I am not aware. I repeat that there has been no suppression by the Attorney-General in this matter. In relation to any appearance by the commission I will have to take instructions from the Attorney-General.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer and minister representing the Acting Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Kemp. Minister, what protection exists for staff employed under the MOPS act if their employer directs them to prepare a detailed list of unsubstantiated or false expense claims? Can the minister assure the Senate that only the senator or the member concerned would be charged under the Income Tax Assessment Act and not the staff member? Given the claims made by Mr Paul Lyneham on the 60 Minutes program last night, will the minister ask the Treasurer to request the Australian Taxation Office to re‐issue previous determinations on eligibility for electoral allowance deductions for tax purposes?
—A number of questions were put forward there. In relation to all questions the government will always act with the utmost propriety—
—Oh, really?

—Yes, absolutely. Unlike the Labor Party's record in this, the government—let me assure you, Senator Faulkner—will act with the utmost propriety. In relation to the third question, regarding the tax ruling, I will raise that matter with the Treasurer.

—I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister ask the ministers he represents in this place the answers to the questions I have asked. If he cannot answer them without notice could he take them on notice and supply an urgent response? That would be appropriate in those circumstances. I would also like to ask you, minister, whether you or the ministers whom you represent in this place will draw these determinations to the attention of the coalition member concerned.

—In relation to the first part of the question, I am happy to take those questions on notice and see whether there is any particular information that I can provide to you. But I do underline the principle that, unlike the Labor Party, this government will act with the utmost propriety.

—Look at the hopeless record of your party on this—an absolutely hopeless and pathetic record, make no mistake. In relation to the last part of the question, I am not aware of this matter, but I will look closely at the question you have asked.

—As I ask this question could I indicate that in my last question I referred to `Senator Macdonald'. It should have been `Senator Ian Macdonald'. Given the reaction on the other side, I should restress that Ian Macdonald's claims are totally legal. I direct my question to Senator Kemp in his role as minister representing the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. Minister, is it a fact that in the nine months from March to December 1996 National Party ministers expended a total of $239,720.39c on air charter travel, averaging per minister $47,944 compared to their Liberal Party counterparts, who averaged only $5,200? Minister, can you guarantee that on each occasion where this travel occurred the relevant National Party minister was on the plane?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I will draw your question to the attention of the relevant minister and provide the information that he is able to give. It is very easy to go around quoting figures seeking to disparage people. Senator Ray, there is a particular senator on your side from Tasmania who has chalked up a truly remarkable record in relation to travel. Given your interest in these matters, you may well wish to look closely at this. For example, in the last 20 months of the Keating government this senator claimed travel allowance for 136 days at a cost to the taxpayer of close to $30,000. In the entire ministry only ministers Kim Beazley and Senator Bolkus claimed more in allowances than this particular parliamentary secretary from Tasmania. More than half the nights for which travel allowance had been claimed were for Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights.

ANSWER.PARA: There are some very interesting figures. Senator Ray, you have a particular interest in this. In your comments you have implicitly raised accusations—do not shake your head—against the National Party. I wonder, Senator Ray, whether you are as interested in looking closely at the performance of your own colleagues on the front bench? Given your former experience as a minister for administrative services, I would have thought that you would have taken a particular interest in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I take it that you are taking the question on notice. I did not expect an immediate response. But, now that you have raised other matters and you have referred to Senator Sherry, Minister, would you like to put on the record now which night over the last two years Senator Sherry has misclaimed?
—Great question! Really great question!
—You're next if you do not watch out.

—Senator Ray is getting very aggressive and very defensive—and he is quite right to be defensive. You have made a practice in this parliament of slagging off at as many people as you possibly can. Oh, that is different, he says.
—You can't name one night.
—Senator Ray has embarked on a course of attacking people. He would expect that other questions will be asked and, Senator Ray, it is quite possible that all will be revealed in good time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Minister, under the Howard coalition government, resource development is moving into an exciting phase. Last week, Minister, you briefed the Senate on the new resource projects that are under way in Western Australia. Could you now advise the Senate of new resource developments in South Australia which, incidentally, happens to be the home of the victorious Adelaide Crows?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I thank Senator Ferguson for that question. He quite rightly states that under the Howard coalition government resource development in Australia is moving into an exciting phase. Of greater excitement is the fact that we are now seeing a great move to downstream processing or value adding, which is something that people have aspired to in this country for a long time.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the specific question about South Australia, the federal government is facilitating the development of South Australia's mineral resources through the regional minerals program, our project facilitation arrangements and the construction of the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link. The highly prospective Gawler Craton region in South Australia is one of the three areas we have selected under the regional minerals program, which aims to encourage the development of new mines, mineral processing and related infrastructure. It is a cooperative effort between the federal government, the state government of Mr Olsen and the industry itself.

Earlier this year the government awarded major project status to a major iron ore plant in South Australia, called the South Australian steel and energy project. The plant has the full backing of the Olsen government, which, incidentally, is a part shareholder in the project. The project seeks to produce pig iron directly from South Australia's extensive iron ore and steaming coal deposits using Australian‐owned smelting technology. South Australia has extensive known iron ore deposits, which amount to some 100 to 200 million tonnes of high grade ore. It is entirely possible, Senator Ferguson, that the state could become a major new world iron province with inferred and indicated iron ore resources exceeding one billion tonnes. The state has about 15 billion tonnes of low‐ash steaming coal in the Archaringa Basin.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is it actually going to happen?
—The project uses the Ausmelt process, a 100 per cent Australian‐owned technology that is derived from CSIRO research that was carried out early in the 1970s.
—That was announced six months ago.

—Senator Schacht keeps interjecting. He was the one who kept knock ing CSIRO about when he was the minister. The technology is now used at 20 commercial plants around the world. Aren't you interested, Senator, that this CSIRO technology is used at 20 plants around the world? The first stage of the project, which is under way now, is the design and development of a demonstration plant close to BHP's Whyalla steelworks. The Olsen Liberal government is contributing up to $1 million to the demonstration plant.

ANSWER.PARA: The second stage is the construction of a $3 billion commercial pig iron plant south of Coober Pedy. The commercial plant aims to produce 2.5 million tonnes of pig iron per year and could create up to 400 new direct jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it goes ahead!

—The plant would—if it goes ahead, Senator Schacht—generate annual exports valued at around $500 million a year. I can tell you, Senator, that if you were in government it would not go ahead—that is for sure. The plant would also co‐generate 150 megawatts of surplus electricity, which would represent a seven per cent increase in South Australia's installed electricity capacity.

ANSWER.PARA: The project will benefit greatly from the flexibility that will be provided by the Alice Springs to Darwin rail link. The Howard government is providing $100 million to assist the construction of the rail link, which would create 2,000 jobs in the construction phase and 200 jobs in the operational phase. You are obviously not interested in that, Senator Schacht. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Could the minister detail to the Senate the reasons for the resurgence in South Australia's resource sector?

—One of the key reasons for the resurgence of South Australia's minerals sector is the interest and commitment of the Olsen state government. The Olsen government is promoting the state's mineral prospectivity. In 1997‐98, the state is spending more than $3 million on measures such as geological mapping.
—That started under us, you dope!

—Mineral exploration in South Australia is at its highest level since 1986—no fluke, Senator Schacht. The Olympic dam expansion highlights the clear difference between the coalition and the South Australian Labor Party. The $1.5 billion expansion of Olympic dam has created a thousand new construction jobs and will create 200 direct permanent jobs. It is as well to remember that the proposal to develop Roxby Downs, which is one of the great success stories in South Australia, was opposed by—guess who?—the Labor Party.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. What are the ministerial guidelines where a minister makes a demonstrably false statement on a significant policy issue? Is the minister required to publicly repudiate his previous demonstrably false statement? Isn't it more important for good governance for such a minister to take that action or be disciplined by the Prime Minister? Isn't it more important that that be done than disciplining, perhaps, ministers who may have inadvertently made mistakes in respect of their travelling allowance?

—Madam President, I think I am going to have to wait till the supplementary to find out the full tenor of this question, but I do not have to peruse the ministerial guidelines to be able to say to Senator Harradine that ministers should not mislead. They particularly should not mislead in this place. But on issues of interpretation of policy, I suspect there will always be some room to debate, Senator Harradine. Perhaps, if you can give me further details in the supplementary question on the particular policy issue that you are talking about, I might be able to say something a little more authoritative.
—Would the minister please table the guidelines in the Senate in respect of this matter?
—That was a bit softer than what I was expecting. They have already been tabled at least once, but I will be happy to table them again.
—I welcome to the chamber a distinguished former Western Australian senator, Mr Peter Walsh. I hope you will enjoy your visit here.
—Hear! Hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, I ask whether your attention has been drawn to comments by a spokesman for the Minister for Family Services, who, in claiming that the minister was `squeaky clean' financially, went on to state:

QUESTION.PARA: she's one of only two Ministers in the Howard ministry to not put her snout in the trough for overseas trips at taxpayer expense . . .

Minister, given that you have made six `valuable' overseas trips, will you reject this view of the value of overseas travel by ministers? What action will you take to have this staffer disciplined? Finally, Minister, who was the other minister to have missed out on an overseas trip?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do think I can say that there are trips and trips. I have to say that the one I took to Indonesia the week before last, when I stayed in Jakarta for one night, fitted within the second category of those trips. I will try to find out the identity of this person and bring to that person some facts of political life—and that is that travel is an important part of this job and in fact you cannot do the job effectively without it, and that applies to both domestic and overseas travel.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer the minister to the Telstra share price range announced by the government today of $2.80 to $3.30 a share, which values Telstra as a whole at $36 billion to $42 billion and the one‐third float at $12 billion to $14 billion. Are you aware that the value that the government places on Telstra is $10 billion to $15 billion less than the value placed on it by prominent stock market analysts like HSBC James Capel Australia using valuations like the earnings ratio of Telecom New Zealand? Are you aware that your sale price is $15 billion less than the value ascribed by Economics Professor John Quiggin, based on the full cost to the public sector of losing Telstra's profit stream?

QUESTION.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you don't care about. Does it mean that the government is prepared to sell a third of Telstra at up to $5 billion less than it is worth, delivering up to $5 billion of value from public ownership of all Australians to a private windfall gain to mostly wealthy individuals? And don't beat up the mums and dads argument—we know who is really buying Telstra.

—Senator Kernot's question relates to the Telstra share offer and makes a number of fairly bold statements, not substantiated, I think, to any extent. Can I say that the price range for the Telstra share offer was set after long and detailed consideration by the government. The consideration was based on the comprehensive professional advice of global coordinators for the float and endorsed by the government's financial adviser to the sale. The government has accepted the recommendations, I am advised by the Minister for Finance, of the global coordinators. The price range itself is entirely consistent with the overwhelming majority of market valuations of Telstra undertaken by the world's leading investment analysts. The Minister for Finance concludes his advice by saying that these analysts have spent over 12 months examining Telstra in preparation for the float.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I remind him that the Commonwealth Bank was undervalued by $2.3 billion, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories by $220 million and Qantas by $150 million.
—That is absolute rubbish.

—Even if you allow two million people to buy 600 shares at $2.80 each—that is $3.4 billion—who benefits from the other $9 billion? How does this government propose to make up the $5 billion lost to public revenue: $300 million worth of new taxes, or do you not really care about what the rest of Australians are losing out on in loss of public ownership of a profit stream as long as your public relations campaign aimed at mums and dads is seen to work? Who is going to make up the $5 billion, Minister?

—Senator Kernot did not listen to the first part of the answer. That is the truth. On the figures she is throwing around, I do not believe they have any basis whatsoever. Senator Kernot, this Telstra float, I believe, will be widely welcomed by the public. It fulfils the government's election commitment, which you have opposed from day one. This is just another attempt by you to vent your spleen on an important public policy measure which has been widely welcomed by the community.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it a fact that in the 285 days between 11 March and 18 December 1996 the Minister for Veterans' Affairs claimed travel allowance on 230 of those nights and spent a further nine nights overseas, for which he was paid an incidentals allowance, thus leaving only 46 of the 285 nights in that period unclaimed? Given that the minister aspires to promotion to cabinet and has had five days in which to check his record of claims, can he guarantee that all his TA claims since 11 March 1996, other than those which he has already repaid, are valid?
—I think that it is a matter of detail which I should refer to the minister concerned and get back to the Senate when I have the specifics.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps you can also ask the minister, Senator Newman, to confirm that on 3 June 1996 he took a charter flight which terminated at Cunnamulla and on the morning of 4 June 1996 com menced a charter flight out of Cunnamulla. If so, why did he claim TA for the night of 3 June 1996 in Quilpie? You can also ask him to confirm that on 17 June 1996 he was not in parliament but in Townsville. If so, why did he claim TA for the night of 17 June 1996 in Canberra? You perhaps could also ask him to explain why charter records indicate that he flew Brisbane‐Dalby‐Chinchilla‐Brisbane on 25 September 1996, yet other records indicate that he claimed a TA for an overnight stay in Dalby on that night. Given the seriousness of these issues, I ask you to report back to the Senate at the earliest possible opportunity.
—I am not aware of whether the question results from an article which appeared in the Sunday Telegraph . Did it come from that?
—Just get on with it.

—Madam President, can we have a bit of courtesy in this chamber? I was endeavouring to give a more speedy answer than otherwise by asking the source of the information, whether it came from an article in the Sunday Telegraph .
—No, it was not from that article.

—If it was not from that article, I will have to refer it to the minister. I thought I might have had something here which might have helped the opposition, but obviously they are not interested in that.

—My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer to the recent launch of Australia's first tribal group mining policy, developed by the Jawoyn Association in the Northern Territory. This group has indicated that their policy will be a path to economic independence for their people. How does this policy help encourage economic independence for all indigenous Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ferris for the question. The Aboriginal Jawoyn Association, based in Katherine in the Northern Territory, has just launched the nation's first comprehensive mining policy by a single Aboriginal or language group in Australia. I would like to congratulate the Jawoyn Association for continuing to strive for economic independence for their people.

ANSWER.PARA: The government supports their efforts and hopes that other indigenous groups will be able to use the Jawoyn as a model for their own developments. After 13 years of Labor, indigenous people are being encouraged to and are now taking control of their own destinies.

TALK.START.PARA: —When do you think the Jawoyn achieved their success? Use your brain.

—This government has set a new agenda of economic independence for indigenous Australians, and the Jawoyn Association, Senator Collins, as you know, is leading the way. Earlier this year I attended the launch of the Jawoyn's five‐year plan. This mining policy is another step in their moves towards self‐empowerment and it marks a new approach to the mining industry. The Jawoyn mining policy outlines to government and the mining industry the group's stance on mining of 34,000 square kilometres of land in the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: The Jawoyn people have had a long association with mining. Jawoyn Association executive director Robert Lee states in the introduction to the policy that the mining policy is part of a planning process for the Jawoyn as they move towards economic independence. He says that as a planning instrument for the association the mining policy is important in itself, but that it also provides information and direction to government and industry over an important element of the Jawoyn's strategic thinking. He states that the policy may be used by other Aboriginal groups in the Northern Territory and elsewhere.

The Jawoyn Association is already a significant player in the regional mining industry and mining is, and will continue to be, a vital aspect of their activities. Once again I would like to commend the Jawoyn Association for their dedication to their goal of economic independence. They are already providing an excellent role model for other communities to follow.

The government will continue to honour its commitment to greater economic independence for indigenous Australians and the result will be improved living conditions, jobs and a brighter future for indigenous people, something the previous government failed to deliver after more than a decade in power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How does the coalition's policy on this matter contrast with that of the previous government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I know this is important to the Aboriginal people. After 13 years the record of Labor in Aboriginal communities is appalling. Their health deteriorated in that 13 years of the Labor government's control. We have even had that announced by the Governor‐General and it is the fact, so opposition senators should not criticise any comment on Aboriginal health in this country because it went downhill under the Labor government. We are emphasising that health, housing and employment will be the criteria that will influence us and there are still numerous social problems and high unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: Labor kept promising, but it has been well documented that they failed to deliver. You will remember the previous health minister going up there saying that it was appalling. What did he do about it? Nothing—and he had the power to do something. Labor encouraged dependency on government welfare and did little to stimulate business enterprise and economic development in indigenous communities. Labor ignored the problems for too long. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Will the minister confirm that in the first six months of the financial year 1996‐97 the Minister for Veterans' Affairs claimed $26,570 in travelling allowance, excluding that repaid, and yet was listed for the total financial year as only having claimed $29,080? Did the Minister for Veterans' Affairs only claim $2,510 in the second half of the financial year? Can the minister explain why, when one adds up the refunded travelling allowance circumstances as admitted, the figures only come to $1,540 when the Minister for Veterans' Affairs repaid $1,715?
—As I said in response to the previous question, I will get the details of an answer, if I can, from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

—My question is to the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs. The minister would be aware of current concerns about the safety of certain chemical levels in PVC products, including children's toys. Could the minister inform the Senate of what action the government is taking to address this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crane for his question. I am aware of these concerns and indeed I met with the Plastics and Chemicals Industries Association and the Australian Toy Association last Friday and discussed this matter with them. This matter has been around for some time. There is concern that phthalates could be linked to endocrine disruption or interference with the human hormonal system. It is believed that endocrine disruptors could be linked to problems with organs such as kidneys and, because of this concern, the government will assess developments very carefully. When the issue was first drawn to my attention some weeks ago I immediately referred the matter to the relevant specialist federal government agencies. In the case of PVC products, including toys, I made a referral to the therapeutic goods administration in the Department of Health and Family Services. I also made a reference to WorkSafe Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that research into human endocrine disruptors, including phthalates, is internationally at a developmental stage and as yet there are no generally accepted testing measures for this group of chemicals. Efforts are currently under way at an international level to coordinate research efforts and to define the extent of any possible impact that endocrine disruptors might have on human and environmental health. I can assure the Senate and consumers that the therapeutic goods administration is monitoring the developmental research work which is taking place overseas into endocrine disruptors and will continue to keep me informed as information comes to hand.

The Australian Government Analytical Laboratory have advised that they do not have a standard test for phthalates in PVC products and they are not aware of any other laboratories in Australia having such a test. I understand that this matter is also on the agenda for discussion at the annual conference of endocrinologists in Australia later this year.

This matter has gained some publicity over recent days due to a media campaign by Greenpeace both here in Australia and in the United Kingdom and the United States. I understand that Greenpeace has suggested that the dominant phthalate in toys has been shown to be toxic when ingested by animals. A study published this year entitled The oestrogenic activity of phthalate esters in in‐vitro environmental health perspectives was quoted by Greenpeace in support of its concerns. I should point out to the Senate that the study went on to make some comments that Greenpeace did not include in its statements last week, and I quote:
The scientific and regulatory communities have not developed credible strategies for designing mixture studies—
such as those which I am currently referring to. The study goes on to say:
Moreover, we do not know how to best analyse the available data or how to package the information for use in risk assessment.

So we have the experts quoted by Greenpeace in its media statement telling us that they are having difficulty analysing available data. They clearly say they do not know how to package the information for use in risk assessment.

This claim by authors Messrs Harris, Henttu, Parker and Sumpter clearly tells us that there are difficulties with information and that adequate analysis of current data is a problem. That is why I have referred the matter to the therapeutic goods administration and the key federal body investigating the issue of endocrine disruptors, and that is why I will be monitoring matters closely. It is important to note that research into these issues involves complex and often extremely technical issues, and it is appropriate that we assess the results of scientific research and investigations—(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. As the minister has raised his awareness and concerns about chemicals that could affect the human hormonal system, is he also aware of recent concerns over chemicals which may be used in the manufacture of some cosmetics?

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Cook interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook might not worry about the safety of consumers, but this government certainly does. I can tell you that I am aware of concerns that a group of chemicals which may be used in the manufacture of some cosmetics might cause endocrine disruption. Senator Cook might like to know that half the population which is female might be interested to know a bit about this.

ANSWER.PARA: Some weeks ago I instructed my department to contact Worksafe Australia and request that this group of chemicals be declared priority existing chemicals under the national industrial chemical notification and assessment scheme. This referral allows sources of potential exposure to these chemicals in Australia to be documented while research into endocrine disruptors is being developed.

I might add that the Australian Consumers Association have in the past raised these issues directly with my office and I have undertaken to keep them informed of developments. I would re-emphasise the need to deal with complex scientific matters such as this in a responsible fashion and to base any action on factual scientific information. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Council on Smoking and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday, 28 September Senator Lees asked me a question without notice about legal aid for a smokers' class action. I said I would obtain further information for her. I now have this information and seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

On 25 September 1997, Senator Lees asked whether the Australian government would reverse its previous decision not to grant legal aid to the Australian Council on Smoking and Health to pursue a smokers' class action? She further asked whether, if the government is not prepared to fund the class action by ACOSH, will the government itself initiate action?
ANSWER

There exists a long-standing practice, endorsed by successive Attorneys-General, to treat applications for financial assistance in confidence. This practice extends to neither confirming nor denying that particular applications have been received and accords with the requirement of the Privacy Act 1988 and the general law of breach of confidence.

However, as ACOSH has elected to publicise its application for assistance, I can confirm that the Commonwealth did receive an application for funding. I can also confirm that the application was refused because it did not meet the guidelines for assistance under the Commonwealth Public Interest and Test Cases Scheme.

The applicant has requested a review of that decision and the Government is not prepared to give an undertaking to reverse the previous decision on the basis that there is a legal aid review process under way.
Future questions on legal aid funding should be directed to the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ray today, relating to the travelling allowance claims of senators and members.

What we have had in the Senate and in the House of Representatives this afternoon—in the Senate from Senator Kemp—is a particularly weak and spineless display. What we had in the House of Representatives today at question time was a particularly inaccurate and over‐the‐top set of nonsense from the Treasurer of this country, Mr Costello, in his usual arrogant and inaccurate style.

In respect of Senator Kemp, all we got through question time were some vague references and innuendo about my travelling to Hobart. Senator Kemp should come back here. Where are your accusations? Over the past 3½ years I have claimed an average of just over three nights TA in Hobart for carrying out my duties and responsibilities, first as Parliamentary Secretary to the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and now as the shadow finance minister in this country. It is not unreasonable that, as a senator who owns a house in Burnie, I should spend three nights in Hobart in Tasmania, the capital of the state. Why would I spend three nights every month in the state capital of Tasmania? That is not an unreasonable position. Hobart is the capital. The statewide media are located there and most of the major organisations are located in Hobart, the capital. Why wouldn't I have been in Hobart carrying out my responsibilities as shadow finance minister and as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy?

The year 1995-96—and my Tasmanian colleagues know this—was a particularly busy year. Have you forgotten the forestry industry dispute? Have you forgotten the quarantine dispute in the salmon industry for which I had very major responsibilities—and I attended to those responsibilities very diligently. Anything my minister, Bob Collins, asked me to do, I did for him, no matter what it required.

Look at the requirements of a minister for primary industries and energy. Let us have a look at Senator Brownhill. He has very similar responsibilities to those I had. What has Senator Brownhill been doing? He lives in a regional area of New South Wales. It is interesting. He spent 48 nights in Sydney, his state capital, from 11 March last year to 28 February this year. That is more nights than I spent on average in the last 3½ years. Senator Brownhill clocked up 213 nights in his first year. I clocked up 192 nights. Senator Brownhill has exactly the same sorts of responsibilities and duties as I had.

What we have here is a spineless and gutless government that go up to the press gallery and put out dirt sheets but not making any specific allegation. Where are the specific allegations? What do we get from people like Senator Kemp and Mr Costello? It might be slightly amusing, but Mr Costello suggested that I should own a house. I do own a house; it is in Burnie. It is there right in front of that whacking great woodchip pile. It is right by the national highway. I spend the majority of my time in Burnie and I travel as required.

Senator Robert Hill said it all today. He said in his response, `You can't do your job properly unless you do travel both domestically and overseas.' I will match the work that I did in primary industry for those three years any time with that of Senator Brownhill. Ask Senator Brownhill what the same sorts of organisations that he deals with today as I dealt with then think of me. Ask Senator Brownhill or Senator Collins. Senator Brownhill is my best reference as to what I was doing when I was parliamentary secretary for primary industries and energy. Ring Senator Brownhill or go and ask him, because he has been doing exactly the same thing as I was doing when I had that set of responsibilities. Let us have some facts and stop the innuendo. Why don't you be honest for once and stop covering up what happened last week? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —What an interesting summation. Obviously, Senator Sherry does not know his own record. In terms of this particular debate, I think it would be worth putting it on the public record because he does not know his own record. Senator Sherry was the highest claiming parliamentary secretary for travel allowance in the last 20 months of the Keating government.
—Correct.

—Yes, least responsibility, highest claiming. In the last 20 months of the Keating government, Senator Sherry claimed travel allowance for 136 days at a cost to taxpayers of $29,590. Have a listen to this: for the entire executive, only ministers Kim Beazley and Senator Bolkus claimed more in travel allowance than Senator Sherry. He even claimed more than the minister he was representing, Senator Bob Collins. Does that mean he was overclaiming or does that mean the minister he was representing was underperforming? They are the questions you have to ask on that particular aspect while Senator Sherry was travelling around having a wonderful time.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get a bit further into his record: between March 1993 and February 1997, Senator Sherry has claimed travel allowance for 143 nights in Hobart at a cost to taxpayers of $40,700. But listen to the rest of it: of those 143 nights, there were 22 Mondays, 15 Tuesdays, 16 Wednesdays, 18 Thursdays, 29 Fridays, 28 Saturdays and 15 Sundays.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question he has to answer is: how many of those nights was he there on genuine parliamentary business? More than half the nights on which travel allowance has been claimed have been Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights—72 of the nights.
—Parliament sits Monday to Thursday, you dill!
—I know precisely when parliament sits. I have to come here occasionally.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Can I have some order on my left please. I know this is a vigorous debate but a bit of order and silence would be appreciated.

—From these figures we can see that Senator Sherry made a rather remarkable effort of claiming for 15 Sunday nights in relation to his job as parliamentary secretary. I would put it to you, Senator Sherry, that you are not being entirely honest in your particular claims.

BREAK.PARA: One could well ask: have you rented out this home of yours up in Burnie? That is the only way it would get any use. How often do you go home? This is quite remarkable: Senator Sherry has stayed overnight in Hobart on more Fridays and Saturdays than on any other night of the week. How do you relate that to doing your job?

There are other places besides Hobart right around the country. Senator Bob Collins is well aware that there are other places in Australia besides Hobart. There must have been some mystical attraction down in Hobart to get anybody down there on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays. But I have to say I have not noticed that mystical attraction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does Senator Newman live? Where's Senator Newman?
—That is absolutely irrelevant to this particular debate. It is Senator Sherry who is making the accusations across the place.
—No, I am not. Senator Kemp is making the accusations.

—Oh, yes, you have. You and your colleagues have been doing it for quite some time. Could I note finally that, between March 1993 and February 1997, Senator Sherry also claimed travel allowance for 30 nights in Launceston at a cost to taxpayers of $4,660. Maybe I will suggest it is too far for you to drive in a day all the way from Hobart to get to your home in Burnie. In terms of this particular situation, Senator Sherry, you have just exposed yourself.
—No, he hasn't.
—Yes, he has.
—That's a criminal offence. He wouldn't do that.

—It is. He has totally exposed his parliamentary performance. Senator Bob Collins, there is one point to make in terms of the carrying out of your functions as minister: when your parliamentary secretary spends more nights in Hobart on the weekend than you do, you have not done your job. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a big build-up this weekend. All around the gallery were all the scandal sheets saying that the Liberal Party were going to come in the chamber today and they were going to do over Nick Sherry.
—With their big hitters.

—You wonder where the big hitters are, because I am looking at them right now. I think both of them looked at the brief and said, `We might give this one up to someone else.' Over at the tactics meeting in the coalition they thought, `Who would be mug enough to come in on this? Who would be so dumb to come in and actually put it on the record?' Senator Roderick Kemp was the nominated person. But what did Senator Kemp do? Did he actually accuse Senator Sherry of misclaiming travel allowance? No, he did not—not once. When challenged with the supplementary question, `Can you name one night that Senator Sherry claimed for; can you put one on the record and substantiate all your boasting to the gallery about how you were going to take a scalp today?' he could not.
—Do it now, Rod.

—He can follow me in this debate and he might like to say, `On 25 April or on 14 December, Senator Sherry claimed in Hobart and he was really in Gympie or somewhere else.' But they brought not one substantive accusation. They have done it all by way of innuendo and smear. They say, `Well, you do that.' That is rubbish. Every detailed allegation we made against Mr Sharp, against Mr McGauran and today against Mr Scott have been backed up by research and cross-referencing. That is why three ministers have gone and a fourth one is on the road to going this week.

SPEECH.PARA: The real judgment that has to be brought to bear here is not where the mistakes are being made. We are not jumping up and down today demanding that the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), Mr Forrest or Mr Hawker resign because they made a mistake. We know that mistakes will occur both ways in travel allowance claims.

BREAK.PARA: Something we should put on the record for everyone to listen to is that some members and senators around here want to get reaudited five times because they have made a great profit out of it. They have actually come out a mile in front on the audit. We should say, `Somewhere around eight mistakes a year is not exceptional'—they go both ways. It is only when there is a repeated pattern, an absolute pattern of mistakes going into the 20s, 30s and 40s, that the believability of inadvertence has to be questioned and tested. We should at least put that benchmark down before we all get too carried away.

If we are going to debate Senator Sherry or anyone on this side or anyone on your side, it has to be on the basis of evidence, not on the basis of the sorts of cowardly assertions that have been made. I am not saying that even anyone in this chamber made up the assertions in the gallery over the weekend. But the anonymous sheets were there.

For instance, they said that Senator Sherry had attended the Gold Coast on nine occasions. Did anyone ask him to check his diary? He has checked it. The fact is that nine apple and pear grower conferences and all those sorts of official functions were in the diary.

I know that on the surface if Senator Ray, as defence minister, went up to the Gold Coast four times it would be suspicious. But if you knew that the Canungra base was there and that I would naturally go there for the various staff get-togethers once a year you would understand it.

By all means, be the macho people on that side and come in here and slug it out. But I warn you: slug it out on the facts. Come in armed and prosecute your case. As I, unlike others, have said on many occasions before: if we have a case to defend, we will defend it.

I know we are discussing serious matters today, but I thought we might just end on a light note. If you are looking for the quote of the year, here it is. It was given on Friday morning and is about this matter. Senator Julian McGauran said, `My brother has got his problems but I am confident. I am backing St Kilda on Saturday, Manly on Sunday and Peter McGauran on Monday.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me address the issue that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) was not willing to discuss in question time today. Not only do we have this spineless attempt on the part of the government not to front up but to just give a broad brush smear of Senator Sherry, but we now have available to us the document from Mr Sutherland, tabled at long last in the House of Representatives today by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard.

SPEECH.PARA: The document demonstrates that the Prime Minister's office was involved in a massive cover-up about the repayment of travel allowances by conservative members of parliament, by government ministers. Mr Sutherland, in his memorandum to Mr Jull, said:

I recall that I expressed the view as Minister Sharp's advice was voluntary and as the data to be tabled had to be accurate that the corrected data should be tabled and that annotation seemed inappropriate.
In other words: annotate the former ex‐Labor ministers—annotate any particular moneys that they were only morally obliged to repay—but do not annotate Mr Sharp. He went on to say:
Whilst I had reservations about raising this matter with Fiona—
That is Fiona McKenna—

in the first instance I know I was eager to obtain guidance and I informed McKenna that two Ministers had identified errors in their claims for travel allowance and that one was significant. I informed her, as she pressed me to know more, that the Ministers were Sharp and Scott.
Mr Sutherland continued:

My recall of a subsequent discussion with Morris, and I believe McKenna as well, is sketchy . . . but I believe I made Morris aware of the facts as I knew them, advised him of my earlier view about how the schedules should be tabled and sought his guidance.
In other words, the cover-up was in the Prime Minister's office. The fix was in the Prime Minister's office. Mr Sutherland said:

At this time my best recall is that Morris said, that as the corrections were voluntary, there was nothing to lead one to the conclusion that Sharp had acted improperly and that the situation was different to the ex‐Labor Ministers, he considered that the proposed method of tabling was right.
We now know that the decision to cover this up was made in the Prime Minister's office.

It is reinforced by a minute on letterhead of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, from Philomena Bisshop of the government section. She recalls a telephone conversation that apparently was made in June. She asked whether any government members were paid incorrectly. Carolyn Hughes, from DAS, said:
A couple/few, but it was decided not to include them.
Philomena Bisshop asked:
Whose idea was that?
Carolyn Hughes replied:
Over the lake . . .
In other words, it was up here in the minister's office. Philomena Bisshop then asked:
The Minister, or his staff?
Carolyn Hughes said:
The Minister.
Philomena Bisshop asked:
Does the Prime Minister's office know?
Carolyn Hughes answered:
I believe there have been discussions.
Philomena Bisshop said:
Well I'm not going to tell them how to do their job. But I hope Jull is prepared to explain why he's misled the parliament.

The fact is that we now have documentary evidence—two documents—which proves categorically that a cover-up occurred in the Prime Minister's office. That is the issue and it has been proved beyond doubt.

The next issue is: did this cover-up include the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Howard? The only way that that can be satisfactorily proved as far as I am concerned—I am sure as far as the people of Australia are concerned—is to have a full judicial inquiry into this matter. Let us get these characters in here on oath—Mr Jull, his staff member Mr Sutherland and the Prime Minister; all those involved—so that we can have a full, open and transparent judicial inquiry. This is a cover-up in the highest office of the land and nothing less than that can let this weak Prime Minister off the hook.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any need to respond to the nonsense that Senator Faulkner has just regaled the Senate with. Madam Deputy President, the biggest cover-up you have to look at is that of 13 years ago, when these events started. And I thought the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) explained that very, very well indeed. I listened to Senator Ray with great interest because the Labor Party is very sensitive on these matters, and rightly so—
—To smearers like you.

—and rightly so, Senator Ray, very sensitive indeed. I was intrigued by Senator Ray's view that, in his personal attacks on people, he always stands up here with hard evidence. I recall the casino inquiry—hard evidence? Nothing was ever produced. You got up here day after day after day and defamed large numbers of people. Senator, the reality is that, prior to the defeat, Robert Ray's rules, as I understood them, were `Ten yards to courage'. That was Robert Ray mark 1. Robert Ray mark 2 is to get into the chamber as fast as you can, and see what you can do to slur and defame people. That is Robert Ray mark 2—and that is exactly what you have done.

SPEECH.PARA: Robert Ray did say—and I agree with him—that he is not speaking about any sorts of trivial errors; he is looking at where there has been systemic abuse. That is what you are looking at. The reality is, Senator Ray, that of course you would expect us to look at what has been happening in relation to travel claims on the Labor side. We have noted, first of all, the very substantial claims which, over a long period of time, have been made by Senator Sherry—virtually more than all of his colleagues. We have noted that.

But the second thing we have noted is the extreme sensitivity of the Labor Party. Senator Sherry got up with this contrived anger; he was throwing his arms around, as he always does. Senator Sherry, the reality is that you are a record maker: your claims are just outstanding compared with those of virtually all of your colleagues. Senator Sherry, you would not be surprised that people look closely at this. We note the large numbers of claims—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your evidence? Where is your evidence about impropriety?
—Oh, Senator Mackay! I will try to stop being diverted by Senator Mackay.
—Senator Kemp, you might like to address the chair.
—Then we note, Senator Sherry, the large numbers of claims that have been made for weekends. Senator Sherry, we hope that you will be able to substantiate all those. Senator Sherry, you are a person—

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The killer punch, I can assure those opposite, is the vast number of claims that Senator Sherry has made. I can understand the sensitivity on the Labor side about this. But the piousness of Senator Sherry, getting up and attacking people and getting so sensitive! Senator Sherry, just cast your mind back to last week and the aspersions you made on a colleague of mine on this front bench.
—Order! Senator Kemp, you might like to address the chair, thank you.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I am noting the sensitivity of Senator Sherry, who has made a practice, along with Senator Ray, of attacking people and imputing motives to them. I would have to say to you gentlemen that, if you head down this road, do not be surprised if it comes back and bites you; do not be surprised.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether you are prepared to stand up and say that you believe Senator Sherry can substantiate every claim he has made. But what we know is that Senator Sherry is a very big claimer. Senator Sherry is one who, over a long period of time, has chalked up—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your evidence?

—The evidence is that he has chalked up massive amounts of travel allowance. I would have to say to you that, in this context, it is not surprising that these matters are being raised, and it is not surprising that questions are being put to Senator Sherry. If Senator Sherry feels a little bit sensitive about it, that is just too bad. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not imagine that Senator Kemp's colleague the assiduously hard working, might I say, Senator David Brownhill will forgive Senator Kemp for the attack which, by implication, he has just made on him. Senator Kemp referred to the `massive claims' of Senator Sherry during his time as parliamentary secretary in the portfolio of primary industries and energy.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know all of the detail about Senator Sherry's claims as, frankly, I do not know all of the detail about anyone else's claims in here, other than my own. But what I do know is the work that Senator Sherry did while parliamentary secretary in the portfolio of primary industries and energy. I am completely unsurprised that the amounts of money claimed by Senator Sherry during that time and the amounts of money that are claimed by Senator David Brownhill, who is acting in precisely the same role, are almost exactly the same.
Senator Crane interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —So, Senator Crane, if you want to accuse people, falsely as it happens—and I know this—of making massive claims as parliamentary secretary on travelling allowance, then you will have to make those same accusations against Senator David Brownhill. Madam Deputy President, when I say that `you' will have to make those claims against Senator David Brownhill, Senator Crane, it is because I would not. I know—
—Nor would I.

—Precisely, Senator Sherry. Senator Brownhill, as it happens, is responsible for the same area of the portfolio as Senator Sherry was when he was parliamentary secretary. And that is the area of horticulture. Horticulture, as Senator Boswell knows full well—and as Senator Crane should, and probably does, know—is the most diverse area of the portfolio. It involves those primary producers in Australia who grow cut flowers; it involves those primary producers who grow all of the various kinds of fruit and vegetables.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of those growers have their own individual organisations that are devoted to nothing except that particular commodity. For example, potato growers and apples growers have their own peak bodies. The grape growers of Australia are part of the horticultural industry. The wine industry in Australia, one of the most dynamic and successful value adding export industries in this country, I am pleased to say, is part of the—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about sugar?
—The sugar growers are not part of the horticultural area, as you know full well, Senator Boswell. But they are doing very well too.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no surprise to me to see the global amounts claimed by Senator Sherry, representing that area of the portfolio, as it is no surprise to see the claims made by Senator David Brownhill. In fact, in terms of those `massive claims', there is a $2,000 difference in the total amount—$2,000. The amount of money that Senator Brownhill has claimed as parliamentary secretary is almost exactly the same as the claims made by Senator Sherry.

As I said by way of interjection during this debate, pick your mark a little bit better, Senator Crane. If you are going to go for the rorters, and you should—and there are a few sitting not too far away from you on the back bench—go for the rorters on both sides of the parliament but leave the workers alone. The ones who have actually worked, who have done the job and who have legitimately claimed their travelling allowance should be left alone, Senator Crane. As I said before, I do not imagine Senator Brownhill will thank you for typifying his claims as being in the same order as Senator Sherry's—massive. They were simply legitimate claims made for work performed. This is not something I have ever said publicly before, because I do not want to give Senator Sherry a big head, but the cold hard facts are that—

BREAK.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the appropriate occasion to put it on the record, because I know that the leaders of the peak industry bodies that I am referring to will, if they are asked, publicly support, if necessary, what I am about to say. That is, not only was Senator Sherry an extremely hardworking parliamentary secretary in an area of the portfolio of primary industries that requires it; he was also a parliamentary secretary who had the praise of the industry that he was serving. I got absolutely nothing but praise from the leaders of the peak bodies of the Australian horticultural industry for the way in which Senator Sherry carried out his job.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented in relation to a question that I asked at question time.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Lest it be thought that my question, which referred to a demonstrably false statement by a minister, was referring to any of the ministers who have resigned, I wish to make it clear that I was not referring to any of those ministers. I was referring to the Attorney‐General of the Commonwealth. He knows it, and I have stated it briefly here before.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
2. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate your petitioners' appreciation of the vital role the ABC plays in the development of Australian culture and in the provision of quality news and information services, including in regional Australia.
Proposed alterations to the ABC charter and cuts to its funding and staff levels will have an extremely adverse effect on the ABC's performance of these roles.

Your petitioners express their grave concern that the Government proposes to break its unequivocal election promise to maintain current levels of ABC funding and proposes to redefine the ABC's role so that it has a narrower focus and is more politically acceptable to the Howard Government.

Your petitioners request that the Senate ensures the current ABC charter, funding and staffing levels are maintained so that the ABC retains its independence and viability as an effective national broadcaster.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide composting and soil remineralisation programs and the planting of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

BREAK.PARA: The statement read as follows—
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 SPRING SITTINGS

PARA.XREF: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INCOME MEASURES) BILL 1997

BREAK.PARA: Purpose of the proposed Bill: The Bill gives effect to changes to the taxation of foreign source income that were announced in the 1997-98 Budget.

Reasons for urgency: The proposed changes will largely apply from I July 1997 and draft legislation giving effect to the changes was released for public comment on that date. To provide greater certainty it would be desirable if final legislation could be enacted at the earliest opportunity.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senators Payne, Schacht, Allison and Crowley and me, I ask that general business notice of motion No. 775 standing in the names of Senator Lees, Senator Payne, Senator Schacht, Senator Allison and Senator Crowley for today, relating to population planning and community development programs in Thailand and Vietnam, be taken as formal.
—Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?
—Yes.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Contingent motion (by Senator Lees, at the request of Senator Kernot) proposed:

That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kernot moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 775.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't this marvellous? We have a motion to suspend standing orders to deal with a notice of motion which, if adopted, will result in our being accused of agreeing to gross violations of human rights. We had Senator Lees saying that she wants this motion to be taken as formal so it can be voted upon without discussing it at all. Now she wants us to suspend standing orders. The motion to suspend standing orders has to be sustained on the basis of the urgent necessity of the business for which the suspension should be held. What is that business? That business is, according to Senators Lees, Payne, Schacht, Allison and Crowley, that the Senate recognises the dedication of the Thai and Vietnamese governments as they work towards achieving their—that is, the governments'—population and community development goals.

SPEECH.PARA: The target‐driven population control program in Vietnam is almost as bad as that in the PRC, where there are forced abortions and sterilisations. Let me refer to some of those. It has been suggested that we deal with this matter. If we do, we would be accused of supporting the violations of women's rights in this regard.

I have here a recent report relating to Vietnam's population control program. It says that women who give birth to a third child were fined an average of 10 months income in rice. They were also denied land to grow crops and the child was not registered. We are being asked by these people to endorse that sort of policy and program. Yes, they were denied crops and the child was not registered, which would exclude it from any later privileges offered by government, including education and land.

There is plenty more. If you look at the resolution on population and family planning of the Communist Party of Vietnam's central committee—I am speaking from an original document—you will see that there are targets established by the Communist Party of Vietnam which are to be imposed with rigour on their people.

We are being asked to deal with this particular motion as a formal motion without debate. What I am saying to members of the Senate is that it is entirely inappropriate to deal with this matter in this way. It is entirely inappropriate for Senator Lees to get up and say that we will suspend all standing orders when I guarantee that very few people around this chamber have had an opportunity to have a look at this matter and examine the ramifications thereof.

I strongly oppose the motion to suspend standing orders. I believe that this matter does deserve to be fully considered so that we know what we are doing. Let us be given time so that all of the evidence is put before us. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —What a performance. The honourable senator gets up and says that we are being asked to deal with this issue without debate. What hogwash! Senator Lees is initiating a process to get a debate on this issue. Senator Harradine does not want a debate at all.
—That's a lie.

—If he wants a debate, let us move on with the process. Let him support the suspension of standing orders, which will lead to the debate. From the other side we get the argument that it is not urgent and from Senator Harradine: `We need more time.' We have been through this before. This is an effort to stall a legitimate motion from being debated in the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is as legitimate as others that get the nod for debate in here. The truth of the matter is that Senator Harradine does not endorse the content of this motion, which is supportive of the programs of family planning in countries to our north, because he does not believe in family planning programs. He does not believe in education programs which allow people to plan families of their own liking, to have some self-determination of their destiny, to have some control in their lives, and allow women, in particular, to have access to education and contraceptive advice so that they can reshape their future. The best thing to do is to put it under the carpet, suppress it, not debate it.

Senator Lees is simply saying that here is an opportunity to endorse a different point of view in this place. For goodness sake, this motion talks about supporting the preventative measures in Thailand against the scourge of HIV. On the last figures I saw, three million people in that country are carrying the virus. It is an enormous cause of death and suffering, not least among young people and not least among young women in Thailand. `But let us not debate it,' says Senator Harradine, `Let us put it off.' He does not agree with the process here. This is an urgent matter if you are in Thailand and it is an urgent matter if you are one of the three million people there carrying the virus. This is a matter where you should expect some support from a nation like Australia, which has had some success in turning around the scourge of this virus.

This is a legitimate debate. It is a proper process that Senator Lees is following. Let us have the debate. If not—and Senator Harradine has had his opportunity—what is the alternative he gives to Senator Lees? When does he want it debated? He simply wants to put it off into the wild blue yonder so that the matter does not get a fair airing here. We know what his program is. It is suppress, ignore, turn your back on the horrendous population problems that exist to the north of this country. This is an entirely legitimate procedure. I would expect as a Democrat that Senator Harradine will support the suspension of standing orders so that we can have a debate in this chamber on this motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting the motion for the suspen sion of standing orders. We believe that there are very important issues, which Senator Brown and Senator Harradine have agreed on, that do require attention and do require debate, but the government does not believe that this is the time for that debate. There are other opportunities to have this debate. General Business on a Thursday afternoon is another time. There is clearly support from within the coalition and from within the government for the sentiments of the motion and for the importance of the motion, as can be witnessed by the people who have put their names to the motion. But I do not want to delay the Senate any further. We do not believe this is the appropriate time for that debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not have an interest in wasting the time of the Senate. I want to make that absolutely clear. I understand that there have been discussions around the chamber on this matter. I understand that the opposition has given a commitment to support the substantive motion, which I understand was the position shared by the government. The government can correct me if I am wrong in saying that.
—I said that.

—Senator Campbell accepts that that is the case. I understand also that the opposition, in the event of bringing the motion forward, has indicated that it would support the suspension of standing orders. That is the position as I understand it. I am well aware of the fact, having listened to the debate, that the likelihood is that standing orders will not be suspended. But certainly it is not our intention in voting this way to bog processes down in the chamber on this matter. The opposition had entered into this in the spirit that there was likely to be a vote on a proposal for this General Business notice of motion to be made formal, which was our preferred course of action, the preferred approach of the opposition. As that is the not the case, we will honour the commitment that I understand we have made to senators that we would support the suspension.
