BREAK.XREF: PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 353 entitled An advisory Report on the Public Service Bill 1997 and the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 , together with submissions and transcript of proceedings, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate takes note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard .
Leave granted.

Madam President, the Public Service Bill is a very significant piece of legislation, because it introduces new public service legislation after 75 years; it redefines the nature of public service legislation, and it embodies a new conceptual framework for public sector management.

While the JCPA supports the need for the 1922 Act to be replaced, and favours simplification, modernisation and the more accessible format of the Bill, the review has identified a number of areas where improvements can be made. Madam President, I will briefly highlight some of those areas.

Firstly, Madam President, let me say that the Committee strongly agrees with the commitment given by Minister Reith in his second reading speech that merit will remain a cornerstone of public service employment. In support of this, the Committee believes that the definition of `merit' should not be relegated to subordinate legislation as is proposed, but should be enshrined in the Bill itself.
Madam President, the Committee is pleased to see that APS Values have been spelt out in the bill. In some cases, however, the values do not go far enough.

For example, the Values require that advice given by APS employees will be timely. The Committee believes that advice needs to be more than timely. It needs to be frank, honest, comprehensive and accurate, as well as timely. The Committee therefore recommends that reference to these qualities be included in the Values clause.

On the issue of workplace diversity programs, Madam President, the Committee has made a number of recommendations about the reporting requirements for workplace diversity programs, which we believe will ensure that the programs fulfil their goals of ensuring that the APS is free from discrimination, and recognises the diverse backgrounds of APS employees.

Madam President, on the issue of protection for whistleblowers, the Committee believes that there are considerable limitations to any whistleblowers protection scheme being based within the Public Service Bill.

The Committee is concerned that APS employees may not be prepared to make reports if they believe that adequate protection is not available. The Committee has therefore recommended that the Government should consider introducing whistleblowers protection along similar lines to that which already exists for the public sector in other Australian jurisdictions.
Were such legislation to be introduced, the whistleblowers clause should be removed from the Public Service Bill.

Perhaps the most contentious clause in the Bill, Madam President, was clause 33, which entitles an APS employee to a review of any APS action which relates to his or her employment. The Committee found a high level of dissatisfaction with the proposed regulations as set out in draft subordinate legislation.

This dissatisfaction stemmed partly from the very detailed nature of the draft Regulations, which were considered by many witnesses to be confusing, and partly from the role given to the Public Service Commissioner.
There is a perception the Commissioner lacks independence in reviewing APS employment decisions.

Madam President, a review mechanism which builds on the current model of a separate statutory officer within the structure of the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission may offer a more independent review process than is proposed. In the JCPA's view, such a separation seems a sensible solution to a complex issue.

I should mention that the review revealed a number of issues on which JCPA members have not been able to agree. These differences of opinion, which were the result of fundamentally divergent policy approaches, are highlighted in the report for the information of Senators and Members.
Madam President, I commend the Report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled An advisory Report on the Public Service Bill 1997 and the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 is a slap in the face for the government. Mr Reith took the initiative to refer the Public Service Bill 1997 and its accompanying Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the expectation, I am sure, that the committee on which the government has the numbers would give it a big tick. To its credit the committee has not given the Public Service Bill 1997 a big tick. It has given it a big question mark. The committee members were persuaded by the vast majority of witnesses who appeared before it that there were serious defects in the bill that must be remedied if the Public Service is not to be irreparably damaged. The committee made 20 recommendations going to these defects. Regrettably, a number of them are rather minimalist. I signal now that the opposition will be going much further than the committee recommendations in the amendments that we will be moving to the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Service Bill 1997 seeks to simplify the Public Service Act 1922 and incorporate into the public sector the government's industrial relations changes. But it goes much further. It is, in fact, radical reform in the guise of evolutionary change. The committee was rightly concerned that many of the government's proposals carried with them a high degree of risk of undermining the qualities and traditions that have made the Public Service one of our great national institutions.

The Australian Public Service is very well regarded nationally and internationally. It has served governments of both political colours exceptionally and equally well. But most importantly, for a public service, it has served the country well. It has a fine tradition of apolitical professionalism. It is not as though it is in need of a radical shake‐up. It is an institution that a government tampers with not only at its own peril but also at the nation's peril.

The concerns that emerged so strongly through the submissions that were made to the committee and from the many witness that appeared before it were not surprising. These concerns are identified in the committee's report on page 17, as follows:
. . . the Bill would:
. change the APS from a public service to a government service;
. destroy the APS as a career service;
. erode the quality of advice provided to Government;
. increase the risk the APS would be politicised ;
. destroy the cohesion of the APS;
. result in a loss of public service values ;
. ignore the qualities of people who choose public service as a career; and
. significantly weaken the parliament .
The committee's recommendations are aimed at limiting the risk of these consequences.

The committee has recommended that the bill explicitly recognise the Public Service's accountability to government, parliament and the public. It is recommended that the values include not just timely advice but frank, honest, comprehensive and accurate advice. It is recommended that employment decisions in the Public Service continue to be based on merit and that merit be defined in the bill itself. It is also recommended that agency heads not be required to advertise all positions openly but to have some discretion in this regard. It is proposed that the provisions relating to workplace diversity programs be strengthened and that the remuneration of agency heads and the Public Service Commissioner continue to be subject to public scrutiny. It is recommended that mobility between the Public Service and the parliamentary service and between the Public Service and employment with ministers and members of parliament be encouraged rather than discouraged.

Perhaps the most contentious area of the bill and the one which drew almost universal criticism is that relating to the review of employment decisions, which the committee deals with in chapter 9. The Public Service Bill 1997 repeals the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act and with it all of the current mechanisms for review of employment decisions affecting APS employees. The government is proposing to replace them with procedures that are basically in‐house.

The committee concluded that, on the basis of the evidence to its review, there is a clear need for a revision of the current grievance and appeal mechanisms which exist under the 1922 act. But it expressed concern about the level of dissatisfaction with the proposed new procedures. That concern focused in particular on the absence of an external, independent, binding appeal mechanism. The committee observed that the Public Service Commissioner is not well placed to exercise independence in reviewing APS employment decisions and noted that a review mechanism which builds on the current model of a separate statutory officer within the structure of the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission may offer a more independent review process than is proposed in the current version of the regulations. Independent external and binding appeal mechanisms are important in their own right, but they assume even more importance in the light of the changes to the Public Service which the government is proposing.

The government is seeking to create a public service that is more responsive and beholden to government. Agency heads will rely on the ministers not only for their employment but also for their salary and conditions. SES officers will have a similar dependence on their agency heads and will not even have recourse to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act. Agency heads will also have the power to hire and fire and set salary and conditions for agency employees.

BREAK.PARA: Notwithstanding the government's protestations to the contrary, these changes will encourage patronage, favouritism and politicisation. If the government is serious about not wanting to move in this direction, and I doubt its sincerity, it must at the very least allow APS employees to appeal to an independent, external arbiter with the power to reverse an unfair employment decision.

It is fair to say the committee was not persuaded by the rationale for the proposed changes, which was put forward by some of the government witnesses—that is, that the Public Service is suffering from a grievance mentality. The committee's recommendation in regard to review of actions is disappointing, and I regret that the committee was not prepared to go further than just recommend that the government re‐draft the regulations in a way that is at least simple, clear and concise. The re‐drafting needs to achieve a lot more than that. The opposition will await the re‐draft of regulations with interest but, if they fail to provide for an appeal mechanism that is truly independent and binding, we will seek to achieve this through amendment to the bill.

In conclusion, while I doubted the minister's motives at the time of the bill's referral to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and I also had doubts about the thoroughness of the scrutiny that the bill was likely to receive, my doubts on the latter at least have been dispelled.

I congratulate the committee on the comprehensive and professional way that it went about its work. I want to record my appreciation for the work of the committee's secretariat. It was certainly not an easy task to produce a report that accurately reflected the concerns that were brought to our attention and which translated those concerns into concrete recommendations that both government and opposition members could sign off. I am sure that the government members would have wanted less remedial action while the opposition members certainly wanted more, but in the end we have a report that we are all able to support. I hope that fact adds to the impact of the report and causes the government to give this report its very serious consideration. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1997
This bill implements one of the Government's important reforms to the review of immigration decisions.

The provisions of the bill comprise measures relating to judicial review of immigration decision‐making. The bill gives legislative effect to the Government's pre‐election policy commitment that we would restrict access to judicial review in migration matters in all but exceptional circumstances.

That commitment was given in light of the extensive merits review rights in the migration area and arose from concerns about the growing cost and incidence of, and delays resulting from, migration litigation.

This bill introduces a new judicial review scheme to cover decisions under the Migration Act relating to the ability of non‐citizens to enter and remain in Australia. The key mechanism in the new scheme is the privative clause provision at new section 474.

The privative clause, and the related provisions, will replace the existing judicial review scheme at Part 8 of the Migration Act. Unlike the existing scheme, the new judicial review scheme will also apply to the High Court and not just the Federal Court.

In the Minister's Second Reading Speech on Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1997, the Government set out how the need for the new judicial review scheme had been clearly demonstrated. The Minister looked at the history of the existing scheme, how it was operating today and what would happen in the future if it were left untouched.
Some of the key points that the Minister made were:

. the current judicial review scheme for visa decisions introduced by the previous Government in 1994 has not met that Government's intention of reducing the volume of cases before the courts— in fact, recourse to the courts is trending upwards despite full and open access by many applicants to heavily subsidised independent merits review by tribunals;

. the high level of litigation, particularly by twice refused asylum claimants, cannot remain unchecked—increased litigation leads to increased costs and delays, and, for those in detention, to a significantly longer period of detention; and

. it is hard not to conclude that there is a substantial number of individuals who are using the legal process primarily in order to extend their stay in Australia, especially given that just less than half of all applicants withdraw from legal proceedings before hearing.

As the Minister stated in the other place, in the migration area litigation can be an end in itself. There is a high incentive for applicants refused permanent residence to delay removal from Australia for as long as possible.

Some may seek to gain time to establish ties within the community which they may hope will yield entitlement to a visa through another pathway. The incentive to delay removal from Australia is increased if the refused applicants are enjoying privileges such as work rights and access to Medicare.

The advice the Minister received about achieving the Government's policy objective of restricting access to judicial review was that the only workable option was a privative clause. That advice was obtained from the Attorney‐General's Department and eminent lawyers in the private sphere.

As senators are aware, section 75 of the Commonwealth Constitution gives the High Court original jurisdiction to consider challenges to the actions and decisions of Commonwealth officers. As a result, access to the High Court cannot be legislatively restricted without a constitutional amendment.

While access to the Federal Court, and the scope of judicial review it can exercise, can be changed by legislation, to simply restrict access to the Federal Court in migration legislation matters, would in practice deflect many cases to the High Court. That would have the potential to erode the proper role and purpose of the High Court.

The legal advice the Minister received was that a privative clause would have the effect of narrowing the scope of judicial review by the High Court, and of course the Federal Court. That advice was largely based on the High Court's own interpretation of such clauses in cases such as in Hickman's case , as long ago as 1945, and more recently in the Richard Walter case in 1995.

Senators may be aware that the effect of a privative clause such as that used in Hickman's case is to expand the legal validity of the acts done and the decisions made by decision‐makers. The result is to give decision-makers wider lawful operation for their decisions and this means that the grounds on which those decisions can be challenged in the Federal and High Courts are narrower than currently available.
In practice, the decision is lawful provided the decision-maker:
is acting in good faith;
had been given the authority to make the decision concerned (for example, had the authority delegated to him or her by the Minister, or had been properly appointed as a tribunal member); and
did not exceed constitutional limits.

The options available to the Government were very much shaped by the Constitution. Whilst the Minister accepts that the precise limits of privative clauses may need examination by the High Court, there is no other practical option open to the Government to achieve its policy objective.

Although the measures in this bill will limit judicial review, it does not affect the existing access to independent merits review by the Immigration Review Tribunal, its successor the Migration Review Tribunal, the Refugee Review Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INCOME MEASURES) BILL 1997

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Income Measures) Bill 1997 will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to give effect to proposed changes to the rules for taxing foreign source income that were announced in the 1997‐98 Budget.

While the Government considers that the broad structure of the system for taxing foreign source income is appropriate, it has become evident that there are problems with the list of countries used for providing exemptions.

These problems have arisen because the current list of countries has been used for two distinct purposes that would have been best served by separate lists. The list has been used for the purpose of determining when income should be exempt from accruals taxation under the controlled foreign company and transferor trust measures. The list has also been used to determine when dividends and branch profits derived by resident companies should be exempt under the foreign tax credit system.

The current list, comprising over fifty countries, is unsuitable for the purpose of providing exemptions from accruals taxation because there are many countries on the list that do not consistently levy tax on a comparable basis to Australia.

A more robust list of closely comparable tax countries is required for the purpose of providing exemptions from accruals taxation. The accruals taxation rules apply to amounts derived from investments that are likely to be significantly influenced by taxation considerations. Amounts derived from these types of investments are treated as "tainted" and include interest income, royalties and certain amounts derived from arrangements involving related parties. Accruals taxation of these tainted amounts is crucial to ensure investments offshore are not favoured over similar investments in Australia for purely taxation reasons.

To address the problems with the current list, the bill will create a new list of seven "broad‐exemption countries" for the purposes of providing exemptions from accruals taxation under the controlled foreign company and transferor trust measures. The list will comprise Canada, France, Germany, Japan, New Zealand, the United Kingdom and the United States of America. These countries will be designated in the Income Tax Regulations as broad‐exemption listed countries.

A shorter list will also make the task of designating tax concessions more manageable. Efforts to designate tax deferral opportunities in listed countries have had only limited success and are made more difficult by the large number of countries that must be monitored. The risks to the revenue associated with not designating a tax deferral opportunity are significant because tainted income by its nature can be diverted to take advantage of the opportunity.

The current list of countries is also to be updated and will continue to be used for the purposes of exemptions under the foreign tax credit system. The current list is still considered suitable for the purposes of providing exemptions under the foreign tax credit system because the exemptions apply to amounts derived from investments that are less sensitive to taxation considerations.

Countries that are listed for the purposes of the foreign tax credit system and not for accruals taxation purposes will be designated in the Income Tax Regulations as "limited‐exemption listed countries". Countries on either the limited‐exemption list or the broad‐exemption list will be treated as listed for the purposes of the foreign tax credit system.

The bill will also modify the existing exemption under the foreign tax credit system for amounts derived by a branch in a listed country so that it can continue to apply to amounts derived through a branch in a limited‐exemption listed country. The exemption will generally continue to be available for branch income other than tainted income.

An active income test will be provided for branches in limited‐exemption listed countries to help reduce compliance costs. The test will allow branches in these countries to derive up to 5 per cent of gross turnover as tainted income and still receive a full exemption for branch income.

An exclusion from tainted income will also be provided for banking income derived by branches of Australian financial institutions in limited‐exemption countries. This exemption is broadly consistent with the exclusion from tainted income provided under the controlled foreign company measures for subsidiaries of Australian financial institutions.

There will be no changes to the treatment of branches in broad‐exemption listed countries. These branches will continue to be generally exempt on amounts that have been taxed at full rates in those countries.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Measures to help reduce compliance costs

SPEECH.PARA: Another feature of the bill are amendments to help reduce compliance costs under the controlled foreign company measures. The amendments will help keep compliance costs for legitimate business operations offshore at a minimum and are largely made possible by the creation of a new list of broad‐exemption countries.
The amendments will make the following changes to help reduce compliance costs:
. the more generous active income test for controlled foreign companies in unlisted countries will be extended to companies in listed countries;
. the thin capitalisation and debt creation rules will no longer apply when calculating the attributable income of a controlled foreign company;
. the transfer pricing rules will no longer apply to non arm's length transfers involving controlled foreign companies resident in the same broad‐exemption listed country;
. the rules for making elections under the controlled foreign company measures will be relaxed; and

. amounts derived by a controlled foreign company from an associated controlled foreign company resident in the same country will generally not be treated as tainted services or tainted rental income.

PARA.EMPHASIS: General maintenance of the rules for taxing foreign source income

SPEECH.PARA: The other amendments made by the bill are required for the general maintenance of the system for taxing foreign source income.
Transitional rules will apply to deal with uncertainty arising from the dissolution of a number of listed countries. These rules will operate from the time of dissolution of the countries.

Amendments will also operate to reduce the extent to which taxpayers may be disadvantaged by changes to the lists of countries. In this regard, the Czech Republic and Vietnam are to be added to the list of limited‐exemption countries with effect from 1 July 1997.

The bill will also repeal the exemption in the foreign investment fund measures for approved country funds. The exemption was originally provided to allow portfolio diversification in emerging markets that do not allow direct investment by Australian residents. There is now little justification for the exemption following recent reforms in emerging markets that have resulted in substantial investment liberalisation.

The new two list approach will generally apply from 1 July 1997 for the purposes of exemptions under the foreign tax credit system. To avoid the need to calculate attributable income for a part period, the two list approach will first apply for statutory accounting periods of controlled foreign companies and years of income of transferor trusts commencing after 30 June 1997. In some cases this will defer revenue collected from the changes by up to twelve months.

The measures to help reduce compliance costs under the controlled foreign company measures which are made possible or are required because of the creation of a short list for accruals taxation purposes will apply for statutory accounting periods of controlled foreign companies commencing after 30 June 1997. The measures to reduce compliance costs that are not linked with the creation of a new list will apply prospectively from the time the amending bill receives the Royal Assent.

The transitional rules dealing with uncertainty arising from the dissolution of a number of listed countries will generally apply from the time of dissolution of the countries. The exemption from the foreign investment fund measures for approved country funds will be repealed with effect for notional accounting periods of foreign investment funds commencing on or after 1 January 1997.
There have been two rounds of public consultation on the proposed changes.

The first round was on policy issues following the release of an information paper by the Treasurer on 24 December 1996. Submissions were also invited on measures to reduce compliance costs under the controlled foreign company measures whilst still meeting the Government's objectives for taxing foreign source income.

The views expressed in submissions on the information paper were taken into account in settling the changes announced in the 1997‐98 Budget. The measures in this bill for reducing compliance costs under the controlled foreign company measures were adopted following consideration of the submissions.

The second round of consultation was on legislation giving effect to the changes that was released in draft form on 1 July 1997. The bill currently before the House is essentially the same as the draft bill.

The likely annual revenue gain from the changes made by this bill is estimated to be $125 million in the 1998‐99 financial year and $100 million for subsequent years. It is expected that a significant proportion of the revenue will arise due to changes in investment behaviour and be collected under the general provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 rather than directly under the controlled foreign company or transferor trust measures.
Full details of measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1996
Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Auditor‐General Bill 1996 and amendment No.3 on sheet 659 moved by Senator Margetts. The question is that the amendment be agreed to. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 37, page 22 (line 23) to page 23 (line 2), omit subclause (1), substitute:

(1) The Auditor-General must not include particular information in a public report if the Auditor-General is of the opinion that disclosure of the information would be contrary to the public interest for any of the reasons set out in subsection (2).
(2) Clause 37, page 22 (lines 26 to 33), omit subclause (4), substitute:

(4) If the Auditor-General omits particular information from a public report because of subsection (1), the Auditor-General must state in the report that that information (which does not have to be identified) has been omitted from the report .

(4A) If a request for information is made to the Auditor-General by a body or person mentioned in subsection (3) and the Auditor-General declines to accede to that request because of that subsection, the Auditor-General must provide to the body or person making the request a statement of reasons for the Auditor-General not acceding to the request .
(4B) For the purposes of the Auditor-General forming an opinion under subsection (1):

PARA.TAB: (a) the Auditor-General may consult with the Attorney-General;
(b) the Attorney-General may make a submission or provide advice to the Auditor‐General.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing again with clause 37 of the Auditor‐General Bill. Clause 37 runs from page 22 to page 24 of the bill and is headed `Sensitive information not to be included in public reports'. It depends, of course, whose definition of sensitivity that is. The Auditor‐General, in our opinion, has always taken care with sensitive information and will continue to do so. The amendments I have put before the committee in fact require the Auditor‐General not to include particular information in a public report if the Auditor‐General is of the opinion that disclosure of the information would be contrary to the public interest, for any of the reasons set out in subclause (2) of the original bill. The original bill said that the reasons were:
(a) it would prejudice the security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth;
(b) it would involve the disclosure of deliberations or decisions of the Cabinet or a Committee of the Cabinet;
(c) it would prejudice relations between the Commonwealth and a State;
(d) it would divulge any information or matter that was communicated in confidence by the Commonwealth to a State, or by a State to the Commonwealth;
(e) it would unfairly prejudice the commercial interests of any body or person—
note that one, please; it is extremely dangerous—
and
(f) any other reason that could form the basis of a claim by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth in a judicial proceeding that the information should not be disclosed.

So we have accepted right at the outset that the Auditor‐General should not disclose particular information if it would be contrary to the public interest, but the choice is by the person in that office. The Auditor‐General is not political; the Auditor‐General is not partisan; the Auditor‐General is not subject to potentially improper benefit as a result of the exercise of executive or government power. The Auditor‐General is the watchdog, the person who protects, on behalf of this parliament, on behalf of the people, our institutions of accountability and democracy, particularly with relation to financial affairs.

Our proposed amendments to clause 37 of the bill are unashamedly intended to reduce the extension of the powers of the executive, as provided under the bill in its current form. By passing clause 37 unamended, parliament will seriously erode the powers and privileges granted to it under the constitution. Passing clause 37 unamended will permanently—for those of you out there listening—weaken parliament and its powers of review. Clause 37 is a serious threat by the executive to overrule parliament in an important respect.

Despite welcome improvements to many aspects of the independence of the Auditor‐General under the new bill, the auditor will remain, by virtue of clause 37, subject to the directions of the Attorney‐General, who in turn is subject to the dictate of the cabinet. That is the nub of the problem: that the Auditor‐General will be subject to the directions of a political person who is in turn subject to the dictates of a cabinet. All the good that has been done by this improved bill will be undone by that one single act. This is the sort of issue that members of the government should cross the floor for. This is the sort of issue that divides those who believe in accountability, democracy and the people from those who believe in the dominance of our parliamentary and democratic processes by the executive—by those in power.

It is clear from the evidence which was given to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee that no set of events provokes a need for the executive to assume this power. The Auditor‐General should have the power to decide to omit sensitive information from his reports in the public interest but the Auditor‐General must be protected by parliament from government interference.

I know that both the department and the minister and, no doubt, the government will shortly argue that this kind of provision has been hidden in the Audit Act, section 48, since 1979. But such a provision was forced through a compliant parliament which buckled under an executive. It was brought through in an era when accountability was not the feature that it is today. It was brought through in an era that preceded the huge privatisation, contracting out and tendering that go on today—the huge interaction between private and public interests. It was brought through in an era when our administration, our bureaucracy, was identifiably more independent than it is today.

The Victorian assault on the Auditor‐General is an example of a style of ideology which pursues executive power to the detriment of the people. The question before us today is whether the parties other than those in the government will choose public accountability over executive power. Passing clause 37 unamended will mean that the government will be responsible for diminishing the independence of the Auditor‐General and the ability of that office to act as an effective public accountability agent. In our system of government, the Auditor‐General's responsibilities relate directly to protecting the public purse and therefore the Auditor‐General must remain outside the control of government and be answerable only to parliament.

It is in the interests of protecting parliament's most powerful accountability agency that these amendments be agreed to in this place. My amendments do preserve the Attorney‐General's right to influence the Auditor‐General where appropriate, but not to direct him or her. We have not said that the government may not speak to the Auditor‐General about issues in the public interest. Item 2, which would be clause 37(4)(b), says:

For the purposes of the Auditor‐General forming an opinion under subsection 1 the Auditor‐General may consult with the Attorney‐General and the Attorney‐General may make a submission or provide advice to the Auditor‐General.

A non‐partisan, independent Auditor‐General appointed in the public interest will not act against the interests of Australia. Such a person will be sensitive to the interests of Australia but they will be sensitive on a non‐partisan and independent basis, not on a partisan and political basis.

We object to the nature of clause 37 because it jars with the rest of the bill. Under subclause 37(1)(a), as it is at present, the Auditor‐General must not include particular information in a report to the parliament if the Auditor‐General is of the opinion that disclosure of the information would be contrary to the public interest as set out in subclause 37(2). Under subclause 37(1)(b) the Auditor‐General must not include particular information in a report to the parliament if the Attorney‐General issues a certificate to the Auditor‐General stating that, in the opinion of the Attorney‐General, disclosure of the information would be contrary to the public interest.

Let me repeat, the Attorney‐General in this government is a junior cabinet minister. The Attorney‐General is subject to the dictates of the cabinet. The Attorney‐General is a political officer before he is a law officer. It is not something that the Senate and the parliament should permit.

We note the consistent and persistent comments of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills that, by passing this clause unamended, parliament will seriously erode the powers and privileges granted to it by the constitution. I sit on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I believe I am privileged to sit on that committee. The people I have spoken to who have sat on that committee in the past all feel a pride in having sat on that committee because that committee attempts to pay attention to the fundamental issues of rights and liberties, and it attempts consistently to do so on a non‐partisan basis. My understanding is it has an excellent record in this place for fulfilling that duty. I tell the Senate here today that that committee has, seven times under different governments, said that this kind of clause should not go through this parliament unamended. This kind of clause, they have said, seriously erodes the powers and privileges granted to the parliament under this constitution.

Our own clerk, who serves this Senate without fear or favour, whatever government is in power, has said the same thing, that this clause 37 is dangerous and should be rejected or amended. You can see his words if you look at the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report into this expressed in both the majority report and my minority report. Senator Cooney, the Chairman of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee—this is not any minor senator—in a minority report said that that clause 37 must be amended.

I plead with you—those of you who value the accountability processes of this parliament—to accede to the amendment that I have put before you which preserves the powers and institutions of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I should state the opposition's position on this amendment. May I just provide a brief preamble to our position and that is to pay regard and respect to Senator Murray. He has espoused an obviously passionately held and strongly reasoned case in support of his own amendment. Unfortunately, while I respect his opinion and have great admiration for his integrity, this is not an occasion when I actually agree with the argument that he has put. I want to state my argument in opposition, while not in any way reflecting on him or the approach that he has taken on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating here quite an important issue. There is no question about that. There is a collision of two principles. There is the principle of an independent auditor and the fearless auditing of the books of the Commonwealth of Australia so that the citizens of this nation can be sure that public moneys raised by taxation are spent as they were intended to be spent and are efficiently spent. The auditor's report comes out in order to establish that, and it is open to the scrutiny of this parliament or any citizen of this nation. Principle one: that should be done fearlessly.

Principle two—and this is where the collision of the second principle with the first occurs—is that nations have secrets and if you endanger those secrets you may endanger the nation. Public exposure of those secrets by way of an auditor's report may carry with it the greater danger of endangering the nation. Which of the two principles do you follow: the endangerment one or the right to know one? When you have a clash of two substantial principles like this, you have to find a sensible way of reconciling the issue so that the principles can both stand. One should not dominate the other. What this bill does—and what we support is the bill and not the amendment—is to enable both principles to stand in a reasonable way.

When I say `nations have secrets' let me give you an example of what I mean. I have to say that this is not a true example, it is a fictional one, because I am talking about national secrets. If Australia had a spy in Baghdad spying on Saddam Hussein's regime making nuclear weapons, should that spy be required to submit his overnight TA for auditing so we know where that spy stayed and who he had dinner with, for the sake of getting down a true and accurate accounting of the expenditure of public moneys raised by taxation? Or would publishing where that spy stayed and who he had dinner with endanger the national interest and inhibit us in discovering whether or not Saddam Hussein was preparing an attack with nuclear weapons? It is a fictitious example, I know, but that is the sort of problem we get into here, and it needs to be approached carefully because there has to be a reconciliation about the importance of both.

What the bill does—and this is the reason we support it—is essentially to say to the Auditor‐General, `Go for your life. Go and audit everything,' except if the Attorney‐General—in this case representing the national interest—says, `Excuse me, Auditor‐General, I don't want you to audit this specific thing' and issues a statement requiring him not to. The Democrat amendment would prevent the Attorney from doing that. The first law officer of the Commonwealth would be prevented from issuing that certificate in those circumstances and, in my fictitious example, the TA, potentially, of the spy staying at the Baghdad Hilton, looking at the nuclear weapons issue, would be revealed and his or her role compromised.

I know that is a slightly exaggerated example, but the issue is: there is still public scrutiny here because the parliament calls the Attorney to account. The issue is not that something has been prevented from being audited by the Attorney; that has occurred, but the Attorney is still under scrutiny by this parliament for his or her actions in so issuing that order.

BREAK.PARA: This parliament has a committee structure which would enable sensitive information to be passed in certain circumstances—I have to say immediately, not in all. This parliament has an informal structure where, as happened in the Gulf War, the Prime Minister may call in the Leader of the Opposition and brief him in advance as to what is going to happen, because you want a national response and not a party political response. So you get that type of interchange.

For example, as the shadow Minister for Trade, I have been invited to the office of the Minister for Trade tomorrow to talk about a sensitive national issue concerning the United States and a challenge that they are going to make in the World Trade Organisation against Australia. The opposition and the government may well have a common view here, but I am being briefed by the trade minister at his initiative—and I acknowledge that—in order that I may be aware. If I then, as the opposition, disagree with him, I will take the argument publicly, but there may well be a national interest issue where I do not do that and actually support the government.

So, in matters of national security, there is a case where the informal mechanisms of consultation also work as some sort of brake. That is imperfect. It is not set down who says what to whom nor whether it is the whole story or part of the story—all those things are open for scrutiny and debate, of course. Nonetheless, I note there is that informal, practical and very useful interchange that goes on which, in an adversarial system of parliamentary democracy, does not seem to occur on the surface but, in fact, is one of the glues that hold the institution together.

I say to the Democrats on this occasion that I understand exactly what they are proposing. I have sympathy to a point but I cannot extend my sympathy the whole distance, because there are such things as national secrets and, by their very definition, national secrets need to be protected. But there has to be a reconciliation as to how we deal with national secrets that affect public expenditure. I think this bill effectively does that.

My concern is not so much that the bill provides a way of reconciling them sensibly— because I think it does—my concern is the concern that you have on all occasions where an event like this occurs. The most common rejoinder is: what happens in the event of abuse? Sure, this may run smoothly on the surface among well-conducted people with honest intent and integrity concerned only about the national interest, but what happens if a roughie comes along who wants to invoke national security protection for something that clearly is not? Is there sufficient means of balancing against that type of wrongful behaviour?

Let us look at this bill further. Under clause 37 headed `Sensitive information not to be included in public reports', which is the section we are debating, subclause (2) sets out a series of definitions of what national security or nationally guarded material should be. I am grateful that Senator Murray read that subclause. The one he seemed to raise most concern about—and I acknowledge that he did not address himself to each one of these items but raised that one as a question mark in parentheses on his way through—was paragraph (e) of clause 37(2), which reads:
it would unfairly prejudice the commercial interests of any body or person.

We do have a rule of commercial-in-confidence such that, if information is given to the government which is commercially sensitive—that is, if it were released publicly it would disadvantage the provider of that information and advantage the competitors of that company—we guard that information so that the supplier of it can have their secrets protected but so that it can be disclosed to the Crown—I would like to say the president of a republic but under our constitutional system the Crown—what the particular material is.

I do think that, from time to time, things are deemed to be commercial-in-confidence when they are hardly that sensitive. That is an area of some discretion. In this bill, it is the Attorney-General that has to make that finding and issue a document to the Auditor-General. The Attorney-General can be called to book in this parliament and, irrespective of whether he or she is inside or outside of the cabinet—I just note in passing that all of our Attorneys-General were inside the cabinet— nonetheless, as the first law officer of the Commonwealth, there are still specific obligations on the Attorney-General so that he or she conducts himself or herself in conformity with the bill. It is not their status or rank in cabinet or in the outer ministry that is important, the important consideration here is the role of the first law officer in giving legal respect to his or her obligations under the bill in the proper and appropriate way.

If I can summarise what may have been a somewhat tortuous explanation, in the end it comes down to this: it is the Auditor-General's role to report. There are occasions in which we all acknowledge sensitive material may be disclosed in those reports. There is a way of protecting the national interest when it might have been disclosed, and that way of protecting the national interest puts the Attorney-General in the role of being accountable to the parliament rather than the Auditor-General. In those circumstances, that is sufficient protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —What I believe I have heard just now is a defence of two-party executive government, and I do not think it is acceptable. If people cast put their minds back to about two years ago near the end of the term of the previous government, there were documents that the parliament was after and it wanted accountability from the government. On quite a number of occasions the answer was, `No; what was the question?' When you want to talk about the first law officer of the land, you would have to be blind, deaf and dumb not to see that any minister is going to act according to their political programs and the desire of executive government. That is the way it is within the ministry.

SPEECH.PARA: There are ways of protecting the national interest. There are elements within this amendment which deal with protecting the national interest. There are also elements within, say, the ASIO act which protect the national interest. I cannot imagine there being a one‐line statement saying, `The TA for a spy is X.' However, there are other ways of dealing with this issue. The explanation given by Senator Cook, and we have not heard an explanation from the government yet, that somehow or other this is the only way to protect the national interest—that is, continuing to give unfettered power to executive government to hide information from the community—is not good enough. It really is not good enough. Unfortunately, the rest of the package of this bill may well be marred by this collusion, if you like, between the two major parties so that the unfettered power of executive government will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook has put a number of reasons as to why the opposition is not supporting these amendments. The government will not be supporting them either. I think it is important that the reasons in this regard are placed on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: First I want to respond to Senator Margetts. It seems in this place that whenever the opposition supports the coalition it is a conspiracy. It was alleged that there was a conspiracy of silence before question time because I chose not to respond to one of her amendments. Perhaps it is a conspiracy of rhetoric now that both Senator Cook and I are responding. The reality is that this package has been subjected to eight years—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the committee said the same thing each time—don't do it—and you are just ignoring the committee.
—Senator Margetts, perhaps that is true, but certainly the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee—
—The majority.
—Majority—
—Coalition.

—Well, either the committee supported your position or they did not. By interjection we heard, `But the committee said every time that we should support 37.' I am about to quote one instance—so perhaps you will correct the record—where the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee did not support the acceptance of clause 37. You say, `That is a majority,' as if it is a terrible thing that the majority view might be the important view.
—Be honest—it is the government.

—The government is a majority. That is how this place is run. We actually have elections every few years, and every now and again a government is formed. Usually in democratic systems the people who have the most votes win.
—That is what we said. It is executive government. It is not about accountability at all; it is about using your numbers to squash out accountability.

—Senator Margetts, perhaps when we have a vote on this and see 60‐plus votes versus seven plus two votes you will realise that democracy is at work. Sometimes you have to accept that. Every now and again we lose things as well, and it hurts.

BREAK.PARA: There are some good reasons for not supporting the amendment. To say that not agreeing to the amendment proposed by Senator Murray and supported by you, Senator Margetts, is to diminish the accountability to parliament and therefore it would diminish the benefit of this entire package is patently wrong. Firstly, these provisions have been in the existing act for around 20 years. You have an identical provision in the existing law. So to say that to leave that existing provision in this new package is to diminish accountability is demonstrably wrong. If you can contradict that, then good luck to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —So let's keep things for 50, 60, 80 years—no change.

—This government, as you know Senator Murray, is not of that view at all. If it can be changed for the better, then we will support it, as we have supported many of your amendments. But we happen to think you are wrong on this one. The Australian Labor Party, as represented by Senator Cook in this debate, happens to think you are wrong as well. The second point is that only once has it ever been used.
—Well why need it?

—Senator Cook has already given you some very good reasons why you should do it. Thirdly, the reasons, set out under subclause 37(2), that the Auditor‐General should act are not broad. It does not just say that the Auditor-General can act if he thinks it is in the public interest. That would be very broad. It is quite circumscribed. It is quite clear.
—Oh rubbish! It is as wide as it is long and you know it.
—Read (e). How is that circumscribed?
—I am going to get to (e), if I am allowed to. With this barrage of disorderly interjections coming from down the other end of the chamber, I can hardly get a word in edgewise.
—It has never stopped you before.

—I will struggle on, Senator Conroy. I know you would never interject. Paragraph (a) talks about national defence. Senator Cook gave a very good example of our man in Baghdad. But what he did not say—and it supports his argument even more strongly—is that the Auditor-General under this act will have absolutely unfettered powers as far as looking into his TA forms and looking into all of the other aspects of our operations, covert or otherwise, in Baghdad are concerned. What we are allowed to do here is ensure that they are not revealed—for very good reasons, as Senator Cook pointed out to the Senate—and therefore put at risk our man in Baghdad and indeed our entire operations in the Middle East.

BREAK.PARA: Paragraph (b) goes into the deliberations of cabinet or cabinet committees. I do not know whether Senator Murray thinks that they should be revealed or if that is indeed in the public interest. Paragraph (c) talks about prejudicing relations between the Commonwealth and the states. Paragraph (d) talks about divulging a matter which was communicated in confidence by the Commonwealth to a state.

We come to your favourite—(e). You would have it that again it is some sort of conspiracy that we should protect something that is in the public interest for reasons of commercial interest, as if to protect something of commercial interest is always in the inter ests of either the government or the commercial operation. I say now that one of the good reasons for protecting something that might unfairly prejudice a commercial interest is indeed that it is in the public interest, or it can be. It is not always in the interests of the business.

On a number of occasions, it is in the Commonwealth's interest and the public's interest to ensure that business can come to the Commonwealth and say, `By the way, here is a range of contractual undertakings that we will give you,' or, `Here are some commercial agreements that we can put before you, but we can put them before you only if you protect that confidentiality.' If the Commonwealth were unable to grant that sort of commercial confidentiality, one wonders how much competition the government would get for contracts, tenders or a range of other information that might be important to the Commonwealth.

I think Senator Murray would accept that there are reasons why the Commonwealth should offer confidentiality for these matters. He would say that commercial‐in‐confidence can be, and is, abused. The Auditor‐General has on only one occasion said that it is in the public interest, and I am not sure that even on that occasion it was for commercial confidentiality. I am told it was for national security. So the only time it has ever been invoked is for national security reasons. Surely even Senator Murray in this matter could foresee that that potentially is in the public interest.

Finally, we are looking at matters of sub judice which I do not think Senator Murray would argue about. Senator Murray would seek to put these matters in the hands of the Auditor-General. We say that, as the ultimate responsibility for protecting the public interest from damage lies with those of us who are the elected members of the government sitting in the parliament—that is, the elected officials and not the appointed official—we are answerable for any failure relating to that. The Auditor-General clearly is not answerable through that mechanism.

I think that is a very important point, although I am sure you will regard that as not a solid argument. I think there are different lines of accountability. Ultimately, just as are ministers, the Attorney-General is responsible to the parliament; and the government, through the parliament, is responsible to the people. In these matters where you make a declaration, where you issue a certificate, which I think is what is required, that is made known to the parliament.

So, if the Attorney-General is seeking to abuse 37(1) as circumscribed by the reasons set out in (2), that will be a matter that is put before the parliament. It is not something that is likely to be abused. It is something that has only been used once in 20 years. It is not a diminution of accountability to the parliament because it is an identical, or virtually identical, provision to that which prevails in the existing law.

I just add this as a final reason why the coalition government will not be supporting the amendment and, indeed, will be supporting the legislation as it stands: the reality is that the staff of the ANAO already have unfettered access to all Commonwealth information. What we should understand is that not only would it be impracticable for the Auditor-General or his staff to have their reports itemise the exclusions—which would be the effect of your amendment; that is, to itemise all the exclusions—but also it would risk devaluing the audit reporting process itself by playing to those who would seek to sensationalise those items left out of a report, rather than concentrate on the substance of what has been included.

That is the third reason. I do not think that reason was covered by Senator Cook. But, clearly, to itemise all those matters, regardless of whether or not they were germane to the thrust of the Auditor-General's main area of interest in the audit, again, could diminish the importance and value of the reports. Again, these matters have been considered over many, many years. The government remains unconvinced that your amendment has merit, and I would urge the Senate to support the bill and clause 7 as it stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not speak at any length; I can feel the numbers against me. But I would point out that your response, Senator Campbell, was a little manipulative of the actual situation. What we require in our amendment is the same thing you require through your bill, and that is, that the Auditor-General's powers be dealt with.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not proposed open slather on all the things which you believe should remain secret—although I must tell you that, from this side of the chamber, we would have a much shorter list than you of things that should be secret. What we have said is that the Auditor-General should not be constrained by the executive from reporting to parliament in the fullest manner possible and from using his or her judgment in terms of the high authority and high responsibilities of his or her office appropriately.

When we talk about democracy, if we are going to talk about numbers, we do understand that your government for a period of time will run this country—and we accept that. But never confuse power with percentage, as we do not. We get 11 per cent of the vote, we get a few per cent of the seats of parliament. In the lower house, you get 47 per cent of the vote, you get 65 per cent of the seats of the parliament. You have to be sensitive—and some of your members are, indeed, sensitive—to the views of the other 53 per cent which did not vote for you.

We have not produced this amendment out of some desire to thwart your ability to run government. We have produced this amendment to advance the cause of accountability; to advance the cause of the Senate; to advance the cause of the people versus the power of the Crown, the power of the executive. This is what parliamentary power is about, this is what the separation of powers is about: of limiting, of balancing, of checking the powers of the executive—those powers you give to yourself, which you describe in a manner which is akin to that of those who used to advocate a benevolent dictatorship. I do not mean by that that you are a dictatorship; I am simply referring to those who used to say, `Well, you can trust me with these powers.'

Just remember that when you are no longer in government—and there will come a time when that will be so—somebody else will have those powers, and we believe they are not appropriate. We believe in checks and balances. We believe in restraints. We believe in advancing the cause of the independence and non-partisanship of the Auditor-General—not open slather but an independent watchdog which is our most important watchdog as a nation. That is all. Minister, you know my character well enough to know that, if you bring the Auditor‐General Bill back, we will continue hammering away at this issue. In the meantime, I think we should move to the vote.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the taking of the vote, I put to the table on sheet 676 two alternative amendments to clause 37. I deliberately did not put these alternative amendments up earlier—and I apologise to those whom it might have inconvenienced—because, despite writing extensively to Labor over a period of a month or more, I did not know until the vote was taken or until Senator Cook gave his speech where Labor would be going with this, and I did not want to provide them with the opportunity to take a lesser amendment as an out.

SPEECH.PARA: I had hoped that the sweet accountable face of Labor would have prevailed over the hard executive face—but regrettably it did not. I am proposing to deal with the two amendments separately. The first deals with clause 37, page 23, lines 13 to 17. We would omit subparagraphs (e) and (f) from the bill before us. Subparagraph (b) allows the Auditor‐General and the Attorney‐General in concert not to include particular information in a public report if there is a certificate saying they should not. Subparagraph (e) says not to do so if `it would unfairly prejudice the commercial interests of any body or person'.

Treason is always a much less likely action of any person in government than is improper or corrupt behaviour. My assumption is that if you have a bad egg that bad egg will be dealing more with money than with treason. It is in subparagraph (e) that any risk of a bad egg appearing in government and using their situation improperly would reside. That is why we have chosen that as the part to be emphasised. Subparagraph (f) says not to include the information for `any other reason that could form the basis for a claim by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth in a judicial proceeding that the information should not be disclosed'. It is our belief that matters in which liability could prevail and in which the Commonwealth and the people of the Commonwealth would therefore be at risk should be capable of being exposed to the parliament if it is the opinion of the Auditor‐General that that should be so. Accordingly, I move:
Clause 37, page 23 (lines 13 to 17), omit paragraphs (e) and (f).

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment to delete subparagraphs (e) and (f). Senator Cook has given his secrets story and it would be very hard for him to then come up with another story for (e) and (f) which would have the same emotional pull. I support our ability to be able to access information under the normal restrictions that would apply for instance under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I think it is reasonable to delete (e) and (f).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just say that when I referred to the Green‐Democrat view about commercial‐in‐confidence and commercial interests earlier I sought to paint the opposition and the coalition's view in government of needing to protect commercial‐in‐confidence things from time to time. The previous government did that as well. It can be, and often is, in the public interest because if the Commonwealth is to receive valuable information it needs to be able to offer that.

SPEECH.PARA: Subparagraph (e), which this amendment seeks to strike out, says the Attorney‐General must seek to stop the disclosure of information that would be contrary to the public interest for specific reasons. It not only relates to the prejudice of commercial interests of any body or person but it also quite clearly puts in the words `unfairly prejudice'. So it is a very high bar that the Attorney‐General needs to jump over to do that. In relation to (f), I begin to wonder what is the motivation for this action. One could only really wonder why someone would seek to remove a provision that allows the Attorney‐General in the public interest and for a reason that could form the basis for a claim by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth in a judicial proceeding not to allow the information to be disclosed.

The coalition regards that these provisions have been in the law for in excess of 20 years and have not been abused, and that to keep them the way they are in no way diminishes accountability. In fact, it could prejudice it. It is widely regarded amongst the most informed commentators and certainly amongst members and senators who have been pushing for over eight years for this package as a massive in crease in the independence of the Auditor‐General and accountability within government generally. To remove this provision would be counterproductive and could, indeed, defeat the purpose for which this package has been put forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very interesting amendment. The first thing I have to say about it is that it is a pity the opposition were not given notice of it. It just appeared before me a moment or two ago. It is very hard, on the spot, to tease through all the variations of what the significance of this amendment might be. It is unsatisfactory, I think, to be in a situation where, nonetheless, I am required to respond. After all, this is the Auditor‐General's act; these are serious matters; this is an important issue that we have been debating in these amendments and this thing has been consulted about to death over a hell of a long time—I forget how many years. To get an amendment like this at the last gasp, with a minute or two for consideration, is not in my view a satisfactory situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me register my unhappiness about that. On the face of it, it seems like an amendment that I could support. But I say those words carefully. I am a stopgap shadow minister in this debate and I do need to get better and clearer instructions on this before I can commit the opposition to it. I am not quite sure of the procedural way I might be able to do that without in any way inhibiting this debate.

I can think of a number of circumstances where various committees of the parliament would be seeking information and where `perhaps' an attorney's certificate with respect to that might close down an avenue of inquiry which should be pursued in the public interest. If they were the circumstances, the two subclauses in the bill are the ones one needs to look at. They are subclauses that are not to do with national security; they are subclauses to do with commercial-in-confidence matters and to do with what I take to be the sub judice subclause. I am not a lawyer either. When questions are sub judice—that is, when they are before a court of law being dealt with between a plaintiff and a defendant—the information or resources of the parliament need to be considered lest they be used in a way which might somehow unhinge the normal processes of government. One has to be careful about that.

All I can say at the moment is that this does appear to me to be a provision that I am inclined to support but I am not prepared at this moment to say that we will support it. I do require some better and further particulars to be explained to us about this. I would be grateful if the mover of this amendment could say more about what is on his mind and how he would see this applying in particular circumstances. Please appreciate the situation we have been put in. I do think it is reasonable for us to say that, before we vote on a matter as important as this, we would like a better explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, I do think you are in an awkward position, having to stand in. However, overall, these matters have been before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, which met in May 1997 and focused just on clauses 35 and 37, and, of course, before the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. As the parliamentary secretary has drummed home to us, this has been discussed over a period of some eight years. I do not feel as sorry for you as I might if it was genuinely new. It is not that new.
—Please don't feel sorry for me.

—Yes, it might be to you. Frankly, it is a fall‐back position. Recognising that the arguments which we have heard—I will not repeat them—would be put to subclauses (a) to (d), we thought that we should focus on those areas which most particularly related to venal matters. That is why I began my remarks by illustrating that, if you were afraid of politicians or of members of the bureaucracy acting in a way which was not in the public interest, you would probably fear corruption and improper behaviour more than you would treason, because I think traitors are few and far between but thieves are many. We know that by what goes on in our gaols.

BREAK.PARA: We focused there on matters which refer to commercial interests. We think it is appropriate since the Auditor-General's primary task is on financial matters, that they should be excluded from the ability of the Attorney-General to instruct the Auditor-General not to look at those matters. I think that is fairly easy to understand, unless you have a view that I have not explained sufficiently. It certainly does not prevent matters being withheld because they are genuinely commercial‐in‐confidence. It certainly does not prevent matters being withheld because they would genuinely and materially unfairly prejudice the commercial interests of any person or body. That would be within the powers of the Auditor-General to make that decision. It is not that it would get out into the open. He or she would make that decision, but the Attorney-General could not instruct them to make that decision. That is the critical issue. Subclause (f) states:
any other reason that could form the basis for a claim by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth in a judicial proceeding that the information should not be disclosed.

It is our view that judicial proceedings primarily and most fundamentally deal with issues of liability which extend over the terms of government. Those issues can put a liability on future taxpayers which deserves to be explored. The only restriction here once again is not that the Auditor-General may not make a decision of this kind; it is that the Attorney-General may not instruct the Auditor-General. It is in these matters of claims by the Crown that the Attorney-General is most likely to be partisan because in those roles not only does he or she behave as a politician but as a law officer on behalf of the Commonwealth. Subclause (f) would allow them to put a certificate in which goes directly to their personal, political or cabinet interests. It would be a directly partisan act.

I say to Senator Cook that it is for those reasons that we have identified subclauses (e) and (f) as being completely different in character from subclauses (a) to (d). I trust that satisfies your question.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the return to order of recent date in relation to SPCL, South Pacific Cruise Lines Ltd, I table three booklets of documents. The documents include all the documents that answer the understanding of both me and my department as to the documents described in the return to order, except that parts of documents that are considered commercial-in-confidence have been struck out or otherwise obliterated to protect that confidence. I have not been able to produce documents that are no longer available.

SPEECH.PARA: The advice I have at the moment is that there are only two categories of such documents. One is e-mail messages that have been deleted, e-mail messages that I am advised were of no particular substance. The second category is blank forms that are now no longer in use, although I query whether such blank forms still exist. I put the caveat on that I have asked the department to check that there is nowhere one of these blank forms that we could produce. I understand that it is not of any particular significance, but nonetheless.

I have not produced any documents that are subject to legal professional privilege. In accordance with what I understand to be the usual conventions in this regard, I have not included preliminary or working drafts or comments on the same that the department holds. Nonetheless, there are three files of information. I understand that more than one copy is required. I indicate to the Senate that there was a problem with the printers and I do not have any more than this one particular copy at the moment. As soon as I do have more copies, which should be soon, I will make them available to the relevant personnel.

PROCTEXT.PARA: AUDITOR‐GENERAL BILL 1996
Consideration resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray for the outline of what he is seeking to do. It is in line with what I understood from reading the amendment. I concur with Senator Cook that it would have been helpful, obviously, to have had it previous to that. As I understand it, at the moment we are debating the first amendment, which has one effect and one effect only, and that is to scrub out subparagraphs (e) and (f). I spoke about that previously. We will be debating the second amendment when the vote on this one has been put. Is my understanding correct?
—Yes.

—The government's position remains that it will certainly not support striking out (e) and (f,) as we have debated for the last hour. We believe in the reasons that are put down in the bill for why the Attorney-General can issue a certificate and our position is unchanged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a chance to gather my thoughts too. When I spoke earlier I was speaking to both amendments 1 and 2. What is before the chair is only amendment No. 1, which simplifies my task considerably. That strikes out both paragraphs (e) and (f) in subclause (2). They are the paragraphs dealing with commercial-in-confidence and legal proceedings. I see no reason why they should be excluded from a fair list of what are matters of national significance. We will vote against the amendment that is currently before the chair. I will save my fire for dealing with amendment No. 2 when we come to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (2) Clause 37, page 23 (after line 17), after subclause (2), insert:

(2A) The Attorney‐General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Auditor‐General by a House of the Parliament, a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament.

This is my ultimate fall-back position. This really is the final stone on which I want to make a stand for the parliament, for Australia. This is the stone which allows the people of Australia, if it is necessary, through the parliament to require the Auditor-General to report to them. They would have to do so by a motion of a house of the parliament, a motion of a committee of a house of the parliament or a motion of a joint committee of both houses of the parliament. This is the absolute core minimum requirement which would allow this parliament to retain its powers, its rights and its authority. I have spoken at length and with some passion because I feel very strongly about issues of accountability, issues of the rights of parliament. I can do no more than condense all that I have said into those three lines and say that this, at least, will protect much of the substance for which I have been arguing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is opposed to this. We do not think that in principle it is different from the arguments that were put in relation to the Attorney-General issuing certificates in relation to any other matter. To use Senator Cook's Baghdad example, let us say that a Senate committee, for example, which was not controlled by the government, ordered a report into Australia's activities in the Middle East, and the Auditor-General was going to make a report on that matter. And this is no reflection on opposition senators; the report could be supported by a mix of senators, regardless of which party they came from, from all around the chamber. For the Attorney-General not to have the—very much—reserve power to issue a certificate in relation to these matters would compromise the national interest.

BREAK.PARA: I am advised that the committees of the houses of parliament can request information by way of tabling of documents or a range of other means. The Senate in particular has enormous powers to try to find information out. We saw an example of that today when, a few minutes ago, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) came into this place and tabled a rather large wad of documents.

Senator Murray calls this his `fall‐back position' or his `stone'. I put it to Senator Murray that it is not a stone; it is indeed a lechstone, an imaginary stone, that he has in his mind. The coalition cannot support this. All the principles that stood in our defence of clause 37 stand here. All of the principles that the Labor Party have supported I hope will be supported again in relation to this fall‐back stone which I believe is a lechstone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter
