TALK.START.PARA: —We will support this amendment, and I will say a few words as to why. Reading closely the words of this amendment and bearing in mind all that I have said in the previous debate on clause 37, none of which I retreat one whit from, I nonetheless draw from the remarks I made earlier the observation I made that this is a complex issue and finding the balance is indeed a difficult matter. What this motion means is that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney‐General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Auditor‐General by a House of the Parliament—
I leave that part of it aside for a minute—
a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament.

Let us just deal with this. In the case of a committee of the parliament from the House of Representatives—when you look to the future these things may always change; there may be a minority government in Australia at some point or other—the committee basically reflects the composition of that chamber, which is the government controlled chamber. So when we are talking about a house of the parliament we are seriously talking here about the Senate.

A joint committee of both houses in my experience is usually—invariably—a committee that is controlled also by the government. Committees of the Senate are not necessarily controlled by the government and in that case may be pursuing some line of inquiry for which there needs to be some balancing protection as to their rights to proceed along that line of inquiry in the public interest against the executive wing of the government acting to prevent a legitimate line of inquiry.

When I first looked at this I read it in conjunction with the clause 1 above and took it to mean that it referred only to (e) and (f). Of course it does not. It refers to all of the subclauses in clause 2, which means that in supporting this amendment—I draw attention to this—it is possible to construct scenarios in which some matter may be being sought to be inquired of by a parliamentary committee which does border on the national interest or directly impinge on the national interest or some state secret. What balances against that is the obvious composition of parliamentary committees and the fact that you have a majority on parliamentary committees of the government or of the party that seeks to be the government and that majority will therefore act to protect national interest issues.

This is not an easy decision by us but, in the circumstances of this provision, for the foregoing reasons and not in any way to act capriciously but to act in terms of the right of the parliament to know, we will vote for this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not surprise the Senate to hear that the Greens (WA) will be supporting this amendment. I hope that the government will also accept it once it goes to the House of Representatives because it is always possible for a minister to give a confidential briefing to a committee, perhaps, or to representatives of parties if there are issues or if one wants to express issues that might be of national interest in advance of a vote being taken. This is always possible. It is always important to make sure that there are some means by which the parliamentary process can be protected and by which access to information in the parliamentary process can be protected. This is one way to try to make sure that there is that check and balance in the withdrawal of information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I am somewhat amazed and alarmed at the Australian Labor Party's position on this. It is indeed in contradiction of the principles that they have supported, particularly in the debate on clause 37 as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I do not think that seeking to look at the make‐up of the committees is necessarily some sort of inherent protection against—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not exclusive.

—Yes. It is simply not any sort of protection. As I understand it, you are saying that, because you have a majority of government senators, all of a sudden there is more inherent respect or even understanding of what the national interests may be. I put it to the Senate that it is possibly not until the information arrives at the committee that there may even be any alarm bells ringing.

SPEECH.PARA: We are saying here that the Attorney‐General is not allowed to issue a certificate. One wonders whether the Auditor‐General could even bring to the Attorney‐General's attention the matters that may jeopardise or put at risk the national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense! That is not mentioned in the bill. You are making that up. There is no prohibition of that.

—I am not making it up. It seems that when you hypothesise, you hypothesise, but when I hypothesise, I am making it up. Can I just say that it is a matter of concern to me and it is a matter of concern to the government, and I am hypothesising about the framework this hypothetical committee of the parliament will have, what information it will receive or seek to receive and how it will judge the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not saying that a committee is any greater or lesser a judge of the national interest than the Attorney‐General or the Auditor‐General. In fact, the government has always said that the Auditor‐General is fallible in these things. Clearly, the Attorney‐ General is fallible in these things but they do have a range of advice and advisers at their fingertips that a Senate committee or any other committee may not have on occasion.

All I can say is that I am alarmed and amazed at the Australian Labor Party's position on this. I realise that it has had to make a decision on the run. Senator Murray has used this tactic, which I am sure that he has thought long and hard about, because he wanted to corner the Australian Labor Party into making a decision on the run. I will not pre‐empt the decision that the government will make on this in the lower house when this amendment goes there, but I certainly see enormous problems with this amendment, and the government will certainly not be supporting it in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1996
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 5, page 3 (lines 21 and 22), omit the definition of bank , substitute:
bank means:
(a) a person who carries on the business of banking, either in Australia or outside Australia; or
(b) any other institution:

PARA.TAB: (i) that carries on a business in Australia that consists of or includes taking money on deposit; and
(ii) the operations of which are subject to prudential supervision or regulation under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to the definition of bank within the framework of these proposed laws and the kinds of financial institutions it is to cover. The existing definition in the bills was intended to cover the spectrum of deposit taking financial institutions. A legal doubt has recently been raised, however, about whether that intention would be fully met in the Australian context by the definition as it stands. These proposed amendments are therefore being pursued to place beyond doubt the extent to which non‐bank financial institu tions in Australia are free to compete for the banking business of the Commonwealth agencies and entities.

There is a range of deposit taking institutions in Australia, such as building societies and credit unions, which under the financial institutions scheme are subject to a similar degree of prudential supervision or regulation via state, territory or Commonwealth laws as that which applies to banks themselves, and the government has no wish to unnecessarily and inadvertently constrain such institutions from competing on the same footing as banks for the Commonwealth sector's financial business. To do so would be at odds with the government's commitment to the principle of competitive neutrality.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are supporting the amendment. It is appropriate to include credit unions, and we support it.
—I wonder if you could spell out a little more clearly, Parliamentary Secretary, what you are meaning about the competition neutrality principles.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should have dropped those last few words. I knew that would get your hackles up, Senator Murray. We just think, to put it in plain English, that building societies, credit unions and other deposit taking bodies should be able to compete for the Commonwealth's business on the same basis as the banks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we had expressed it a little differently, because we think the amendment is consistent with the opening up of the banking industry to competition from credit unions and we think that is a reasonable thing to support. It is specifically casting the net widely, which once again we think is a reasonable thing to support. We think that overall your amendment is a positive step, and we will support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 24 (after line 16), after clause 36, insert:

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding anything contained in any other Act, no grants of financial assistance may be paid to a State unless the responsible Minister is satisfied that:
(a) amounts paid to the State will be audited by the State Auditor‐General; and
(b) the State Auditor‐General is not subject to any direction from any person in relation to any aspect of the audit, including the planning and conduct of, and reporting on, the audit.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to that amendment, Senator Sherry will recall that, when we put the amendment to the states grants bill which attempted to deal with this matter, he advised us that it was the opinion of Labor that that was not the appropriate time and perhaps not the appropriate place to introduce that. We might agree that the timing and the rushing of it all made it difficult to consider it fully, but we did believe it was the appropriate place. However, Senator Sherry said to us that this package of bills was coming before us and that we should consider putting it there. I do not want to put words in your mouth, Senator Sherry—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are. I am listening very carefully, and you are.

—I think you said you would favourably consider the matter when it was put before you with these bills. Accordingly, we ascertained which was the most appropriate bill to put it in, and this is it, and we therefore look across to you with our baby blues and say, `Would you please favourably consider this amendment?' That is a light‐hearted way of dealing with a very serious issue, and I am sure that my colleague from Victoria, Senator Allison, will put some meat on my proposal to you to support that amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate knows, I put forward an amendment to the States Grants (General Purposes) Amendment Bill 1997 three weeks ago now which would have ensured that Commonwealth moneys were audited by state auditors‐general who were independent. Of course, that would have simply maintained the status quo in terms of what the states currently do. The wording which was used then and now by Senator Murray in this amendment was actually suggested by the Australasian Council of Auditors‐General, who are particularly concerned about threats to the independence of auditors‐general. As the Senate will also recall, the Victorian state government commissioned a review of the Auditor‐General Act some months ago and it came up with a proposal, not yet decided on by the Kennett government, which would effectively nobble the independence of Victoria's Auditor‐General.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to go over all of those arguments again today but I do want to say that the ALP in Victoria has made a great deal of their support for this question of opposing the threats to the independence of the Auditor‐General. In this regard, Mr Brumby, Leader of the Opposition in that state, sent out circulars which said:
A Labor Government will implement the following reforms:
* The independence of the Auditor‐General will be enshrined in the state constitution.

* The office of the Auditor‐General will be re‐established under the direct control of the Auditor‐General, who will be responsible for staffing the office and other resourcing decisions within the office.

* The Auditor‐General will have the sole power to carry out or designate an auditor to carry out the external audit on all public sector agencies over which the government has control, significant influence or to which it has financial exposure.
* The Auditor‐General will not be subject to any direction on how to carry out audits.

* The Auditor‐General will be free to determine the audit program, including the bodies to be audited, the nature and scope of auditors who will carry out the audits, the priorities for audit and what external expertise will be utilised for any performance audits.

The ALP has shared platforms with me on a number of occasions, decrying the actions of the Kennett government. As Senator Murray has already said, the ALP chose to vote against our amendment last time round. Senator Sherry said that, in principle, there was some opposition support but made the excuse that the bill was urgent and that another piece of legislation, which is the one that is before us today, would be more appropriate. Today, not only does the opposition have the option of supporting amendments which would protect the independence of the Commonwealth Auditor‐General but Senator Sherry can also demonstrate that his party is not hypocritical, that his party cares about open and accountable government and that his party is not afraid of the scrutiny that that most important watchdog in this country can provide. My colleague Senator Murray has, as suggested by Senator Sherry on 4 September, prepared this amendment which will do what Mr Brumby in Victoria would have us do. It will put in place not just a promise that Mr Brumby might make for some stage in the future but it will actually stop that ideological experiment likely to be imposed on Victoria. I want to recap on what the Victorian Auditor‐General said about this ideological experiment. He said:

I am more convinced than ever that the direction proposed by the review team will lead to a situation in which a future parliament, if confronted by either an oppressive or a corrupt government, would be relatively impotent and not privy to information which would allow it to call such a government to account. The team's model has been postulated in a report which is devoid of empirical evidence and is characterised by unsubstantiated assertions, textual inconsistencies, uncertainty as to the likely outcomes and recommendations based on minority views.

The Senate will recall that, when this went to the vote on 4 September, Senator Carr and Senator Conroy spoke with some passion about their commitment to the independence of the Auditor‐General. They then proceeded to absent themselves from the chamber at the time of the vote.

Senator Conroy said that a more appropriate place for this debate would be during the debate on the bill that is before us now. Here is the chance to have that debate. Here is the chance for the ALP to demonstrate that it has the strength to act on its rhetoric. Time is running out in Victoria. If the ALP does not support our amendment this time we can only conclude that it likes the idea of the nobbling of the Auditor‐General if and when it eventually comes to power either here or in Victoria. If this is the case then I think the ALP should say so to all Victorians and not pretend to continue to take this high moral ground.

Senator Sherry said that we should perhaps have a Senate inquiry into this matter, yet when I moved that the ALP voted against that amendment too. I wonder when we can expect to see the terms of reference drafted up by the ALP for an inquiry. We would certainly be happy to develop them. But here today is an opportunity for real action on this question and it is my strong hope that we see the ALP vote where it really matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in response to Senator Murray, and to some extent to Senator Allison from Victoria, I did make it clear that, as part of the discussion we had in respect to the Auditor‐General in Victoria, our desire was to have an appropriate Senate inquiry. We have commenced drafting up the terms of reference, Senator Allison. I was actually having a look at them this morning but I did get somewhat distracted by some other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference obviously have to be discussed with all of the parties in the Senate chamber. I do not want to traverse over the grounds that I traversed over on the last occasion, and I do not want to be too unkind to the Australian Democrats, but we saw an attempted stunt a couple of weeks ago and there is an attempt here today to replicate what we think is a stunt. As I said on that occasion, we have concerns about the independence and the proper resourcing of an independent auditor‐general in Victoria, but we have that concern about a number of states and territories.

I hope that we can conclude some terms of reference during the rest of this week and get the inquiry under way, but I would say this amendment does not safeguard the office of state and territory auditors‐general. On the contrary, the passage of this amendment would severely put at risk the financial position of these other governments. The amendment would stop the making of all grants of financial assistance to states pursuant to all other pieces of legislation passed by the parliament if, either the Commonwealth minister is not satisfied that all of the money will be audited by the state auditor‐general, or the state auditor‐general is not subject to any direction from any person in relation to any aspect of the audit.

Since a Commonwealth minister cannot be satisfied about the future activity of state auditors‐general, there is a real risk that states may have all of their Commonwealth funding cut off. It would destroy the delivery of public services in this nation if this section were ever invoked. There may well be legitimate circumstances where the state auditor‐general does not audit funds provided to the state; for example, where the state government is just a post box which then sends on the money to local government or makes a grant to community groups.

For a party which professes to care about the level of public services provided in the community, we believe this is a poorly thought through proposal. If the Democrats are serious about examining the proper role of the auditor‐general in a national context, which we certainly are, we are interested in progressing the matter in a proper way. As I said when I commenced, I do not want to be too unkind. I am not in an unkind mood today and generally I am not in an unkind mood.

We do see this in the context of somewhat of a stunt. I recall listening to some media—radio, I think, Senator Allison, which you did on the last occasion—and you were very unkind. That does not perturb me in a personal sense, but it had all the elements of a last‐minute dash to try to get involved in a very controversial issue in Victoria which, quite rightly, Labor and our leader, Mr Brumby, have been making a very strong stand on, in principle, in the media and in the general community. The Democrats have been hooking on to that issue and hooking on to legislation in an inappropriate way.

We want to see the inquiry into those terms of reference concluded this week, and I am sure there will be discussions on that this week. Whatever the government chooses to do is up to them but, of course, we have to consult with people like Senator Harradine and, obviously, the Greens and the Democrats.

BREAK.PARA: There will be a very significant shift in state‐Commonwealth financial relations if this amendment is passed. As I said on the last occasion, we want to have a thorough, proper examination of all states and territories and, if that inquiry finds that there are grounds for punitive actions against states in respect of state auditors‐general—and I think, prima facie, there are grounds—then we want to introduce a mechanism to do it in a proper and workable manner.

I will conclude my remarks with that. Unless the Democrats are overly provocative, I will refrain from speaking again on the matter. I know that represents a summation of our position on this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the summation—if there has been one—that I would make of Senator Sherry's contribution might very well indicate that we really do need to have a debate about broader constitutional reform in this country. I keep saying it again and again but the examples clearly come up in legislation that we have a changed and changing situation between the Commonwealth and the states as far as funding is concerned, and we have a situation where, more and more, the states are saying, `We don't want to be accountable to anybody for what we spend.' That is really not good enough.
—What state said that?

—Senator Campbell asked, `What state said that?' My understanding is that the agreement between the states and the Commonwealth government in relation to such things as competition policy is that they receive more untied grants. That, to me, would indicate that they are saying they do not want to be accountable to the Commonwealth government for what they spend Commonwealth funds for. It seems to me that we have had debates within this chamber in relation to organisations like ATSIC, when the now‐government has called audits to the nth degree to make sure the money went where it was supposed to go. It is not unreasonable, if the states hold out their hands for funds for certain purposes and if the Commonwealth provides funds for the states for certain purposes, for those amounts to be checked to see whether they went for the purposes for which they were provided.

SPEECH.PARA: How many times in this chamber have we heard fairly substantial amounts of money being quoted in relation to Aboriginal health, Aboriginal housing and so on? A fair number of people in the chamber should realise that most of that money, which has been given to assist in the provision of those services, has been provided through the states and then through the states to local government. But what we are missing out on is finding out whether those funds actually went to where they were supposed to go. Instead, we have a constant battle beating up on ATSIC because there is almost no accountability in such areas as Aboriginal health, Aboriginal education and so on within this parliamentary process. The reason is that the states do not have to come back and say, `We have spent the money on where it is supposed to go.'

I do not think it is unreasonable that, with the financial assistance given to states, the states should then have to come out with an independently audited statement that says, `The money has gone where we said it was going to,' or `the money has gone where you have directed it to go to'—if it has been allocated for a particular purpose. This amendment highlights the need for a debate on broader constitutional reform. We are almost in a no-person zone in relation to the rights of states and the responsibility of states and certainly of local government because local government gets left off altogether. It is about time we as a community started talking about those issues; it is about time we put the debate about where we want the constitution to go in the future back on the agenda.

This is not good enough. The fact is that we know the states do not want the Commonwealth to watch over their shoulders to see where they spend their money. By the same token, people want to make sure that there is some kind of policy to make sure that certain goals are achieved. At the moment it seems as though everybody is putting their hands behind their backs and taking no responsibility to ensure that social goals, which many people think are important, are actually achieved in the expenditure of public money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting this amendment for a number of reasons, which I will put as quickly as I can. Senator Lyn Allison was doing her best to get both the government and opposition senators to support this amendment. But when she made the plea—I will try to paraphrase, not quote, but the Hansard will show what she said—that this might put in place a promise that Mr Brumby might make in the future, she just about lost me. It is pretty much a `let's get Jeff' amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this amendment goes a lot further than that. Firstly, it would seek in both its intent and its effect to enact a law of the Commonwealth which would absolutely enshrine preferential treatment between states as to their access to Commonwealth revenue. On the face of it, that appears to the government to be in breach of section 99 of the constitution, which reads:
The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade, commerce, or revenue, give preference to one State or any part thereof over another State or any part thereof.

There are also clear technical amendments with the amendment: it ignores entirely any mention of the territories; it does not seek to define `financial assistance'; it does not seek to define `responsible minister'; and there is no recognition of the fact that state Auditors‐General do not personally conduct audits. Moreover, the amendment—buried away as it is in the FMA act but which purports to apply to the broad range of states grants acts—might in any case be rather pointless since, if it were apply at all, it might well only apply to existing laws and might not be able to apply to the laws that future parliaments make. So it is technically seriously flawed and it is unconstitutional.

But, most importantly, it seems to me rather preposterous—certainly against the interests of federation and certainly against the concept of having government responsible to its elected citizens—for the Commonwealth to presume to intrude into the role of state parliaments and their power when it comes to making laws over their own affairs. There is a very big debate going on in Victoria at the moment—it is a very healthy debate—over the role of that state's Auditor-General. I regard having the Commonwealth seek to interfere in how any state government, be it Victorian or any other state government, runs a state and seek to interfere in the accountability measures that are put in place by that state as absolutely presumptuous.

We in this government, contrary to the view of Senator Margetts, believe that more accountability is important. That is why we have put federal‐state financial relations firmly on the tax reform agenda. We believe that, with increasing vertical fiscal imbalance and increasing dependence on Commonwealth revenues, states do become less and less responsible for the moneys they raise and spend.

None of the state premiers whom I have listened to or spoken to support Senator Margetts's proposition that there should be less accountability. All of the states are pushing for more responsibility in terms of raising the revenues that they spend; they are all are actually asking for more accountability. It is entirely contrary to what Senator Margetts says. If Senator Margetts's proposition that there should be less tied grants is supporting the proposition that there is less accountability, I put it to her that she is wrong.
If one looks at this question logically, one must ask: where does the money come from; where do the taxes that are handed by the Commonwealth back to the states and territories come from?

TALK.START.PARA: —The taxpayer.

—Where does the money come from that goes back to Western Australia? A large whack of the money comes from Western Australian taxpayers and industries based in Western Australia. To say to Western Australians—or, Mr Deputy Chairman Calvert, to say to the taxpayers of Tasmania who also make a contribution to the Commonwealth taxpayer—that we will have Big Brother in Canberra saying, `Sorry, we know better. We will take all your money from you. We will give it back to you. We will tie the grants, tell you how to spend it and then further insist that you will comply with our audit measures,' is most presumptuous.

SPEECH.PARA: I think most Australians would believe that state parliaments should be responsible for the money that they spend—be it raised through their own taxes, levies or fees or be it sent to them by way of either tied or untied grants from the Commonwealth—because they are closer to the sorts of decisions being made. You can only have democracy in a nation the size of Australia if you have those sorts of responsibilities at that level, a level which is much closer to the people.

There are three reasons why the government will not be supporting this amendment. One, it is presumptuous of the Commonwealth parliament to seek to do this. Two, we believe that it is in clear breach of section 99. Three, there are significant technical flaws in the bill: it does not mention the territories; it does not define most of the terms in it; it ignores the roles of state Auditors-General; and it is complicated and confused in relation to what legislation it will apply to. The government will not support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —It is at times like this that I particularly enjoy the Senate. Premier Richard Court several times has publicly called for federal and state financial relationships to be reviewed, particularly the constitutional arrangements which affect those relationships. I happen to agree with him. So I put a motion to the Senate proposing such a review by the Commonwealth, state and territory governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Who would support the motion? Senator Margetts has supported the motion; Senator Harradine has supported it; Senator Brown from Tasmania supports it; and, of course, the Australian Democrats support it. We have just heard the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell) saying how wonderful he thought the coalition was for wanting to have these matters up. But who voted against it? It was Senator Campbell and the other coalition and Labor senators from Western Australia, as well as many others.

BREAK.PARA: I am afraid there is often a huge gap between your rhetoric and what you actually do. If you look at the Senate records, Senator Campbell, you will see that you have voted against it.

It is one thing is to attack the amendment in the manner in which it has been attacked. We agree that this measure, which is an amendment about the principles of accountability relating to the dispersal of Commonwealth money—I would have thought that that is something we are all pretty concerned about—might have been better placed in the bills where it was rejected previously, in those Commonwealth‐state legislation bills. But it happens to be in this package specifically because Labor asked us to put it here. Let us have no misunderstanding about that. It is here because Labor wanted it here.

I turn to the actual construction of the amendment. I would remind you that this is based on the amendment we originally put forward. I do not recall in the debate—perhaps Senator Allison can refresh my memory—the government putting the counterarguments that they have put today. This particular amendment was drawn together by no less a group than the Australasian Council of Auditors-General. So let us get some substance and some power into this. Of course, if you agreed with it but you disagreed with some of the technicalities, it is always up to you to amend it appropriately. This amendment has been before the chamber since at least 24 September.

Senator Sherry has raised the issue of stunts. On 26 April—this is disregarding all the other interviews and so on that we have had—the Democrats announced that they would seek federal powers to try to ensure that Commonwealth money was not paid over to another government within this country which did not have an independent Auditor-General to make sure that the money was being properly spent. Gee! That is a terrible thing to do. That is the stunt on 26 April that Senator Sherry referred to.

On 6 May, in an adjournment speech, I spoke at length on the Victorian Auditor-General. On 14 July, Senator Lyn Allison participated in the public forum in Victoria on the position of the Auditor-General. So let us have no stuff here about us being opportunistic or performing stunts. We have spent a lot of time talking to the Australasian Council of Auditors-General.

You can criticise, if you like, the form and the content, but do not criticise the intention. If you disagree with the intention, then you leave yourself utterly exposed. The intention is to ensure the accountability for the dispersal of Commonwealth money. That accountability cannot occur if the persons who receive it are not subject to independent audit. That is the specific problem we have in Victoria. To my knowledge, we do not have it in any other state or territory. But in Victoria they wish to take away the independence of the Auditor-General.

It may be, Senator Campbell, that the government of that state is of the same complexion and has the same thoughts as you. However, this is not an ideological issue. This is about honesty. This is about watching to make sure money is properly spent. Knowing you, as I hope I am learning to do, I would find it odd and difficult to believe that you would not like to ensure that, as far as is humanly possible, Commonwealth money is appropriately spent.

There are no stunts. There is no malfeasance here. There is no ideology here. This is about good housekeeping. If you do not like the amendment, our suggestion to you and your advisers behind you is to come back with something which guarantees to this parliament that the moneys that belong to the people of Australia are going to be spent—whether it is by us, the states or the territories—in a manner that guarantees it is properly spent and is so audited by an independent person and not somebody muzzled, controlled or directed by a particular political party and their mates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be extremely brief because all the arguments have been put. I will be supporting this amendment, and I am disappointed that it obviously does not have the overall support of the Senate. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell) has mentioned the view of the govern ment that the amendment is technically faulty and also that it may well be unconstitutional.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the latter, I would point out that the founders and writers of the constitution were quite adamant. As you can see in section 97 of the constitution, they held to the view that the audit and review of colonial government expenditure should be maintained. If you look at what happened, the founders of the constitution, I suppose, made sure that the states themselves would establish their own auditing procedures, and until such time as that occurred, under section 97, the Commonwealth Auditor-General could exercise that particular power.

I think we perhaps have to look at this matter at some future time. There will be further opportunities no doubt, and no doubt advantage will be taken of those further opportunities by, presumably, Senator Murray, Senator Margetts, Senator Allison, or somebody else. I believe that we will be able to have another think about this. However, in the meantime I am supporting this amendment, though it has very little chance of getting through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly, Mr Chair: the minister had some very interesting words to say about the devolution of power. Anyone reading the documents of the Greens over time would realise that we are very big on devolution of responsibility in power and the democratic process. However, the minister's words do not ring true when you think of what currently is happening federally in relation to local government. Major issues are arising where the interests of local government, which, after all, represent all Australians, are being stomped on by a combination of state and federal governments.

SPEECH.PARA: If the government is saying that, in principle, they believe in the devolution of responsibility, perhaps they should be taking notice of what is happening with the democratic process in relation to a number of major issues being put forward by local government. The last representatives I spoke to from Western Australia indicated that they were very angry about the current situation on a number of very important issues such as financial accountability, responsibility and democratic decision making at a local level. These issues, as I say, are being stomped on by both state and federal governments at the moment. If the coalition believes in devolution, perhaps they should be looking further than at state government level. The teeniest grant given by state and federal governments to an incorporated body is usually required to be independently audited. It seems bizarre that the states are not accountable in terms of auditing, whereas the teeniest, weeniest grant at federal level has to be accounted for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested in the contribution by Senator Harradine. I have not had the opportunity yet to talk to him about the process by which we do progress his concerns, and the concerns of the Democrats, the Greens and Labor, about the Victorian situation and situations that exist in other states. But Senator Harradine is right. Just looking at legislation, or casting back and reflecting on the last couple of years, there will be, I think, adequate opportunity to address this issue very thoroughly in other legislation as it comes through the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Amendment (by Senator Murray) proposed:
(1) Page 38 (after line 24), after clause 61, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 61A Terms of contracts to be published

PARA.TAB: (1) Subject to subsection (2), the terms of any contract entered into by or on behalf of an Agency must be published in the Gazette .

(2) Before the terms of any contract are published in the Gazette , the Chief Executive may authorise the deletion of any details of costs under the contract which, in the opinion of the Chief Executive, would unfairly prejudice the commercial interests of any body or person.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government regards this as a matter of process that should not be in the principal act but in the subordinate rules. I am advised that the current regulations do provide for this—that is, the gazettal of details of contracts of more than $2,000—and that the regulations that will be made under this new law will do likewise for accountability reasons and to inform industry about the contracts let. So we do not think it should be in the act; it should be in the regulations, and the government will be putting it into the regulations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the government's assurances—and I was going to ask a question about it, but Senator Campbell has covered it—we will not be supporting the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting amendment No. 1, on page 679, by Senator Murray for the Australian Democrats in relation to the terms of contract. Basically, we think it is reasonable.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Vanstone tabled documents pursuant to a return to order. On behalf of Senator Vanstone, I now table a further document that the minister referred to in her tabling statement and which falls within the terms of the return to order.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the amendment moved by Senator Murray on sheet 679. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer at the commencement of my remarks to the indication from government that the regulations covering this area will allow the headlines or the characteristics of contracts to be published. I cannot recall the exact words used, Senator Campbell, but I do not think it will be the terms of the contract that you will be publishing. Until we see the regulations, we will not know what you will put in them. If you were to detail who won the contract and if you were to spell out the details of the contract in terms of its main terms, that would be helpful.

SPEECH.PARA: We have raised this issue because we think that the example of New Zealand and the United States in this regard is well worth following. The clause is intended to provide for the publication of all contracts, which would alter the current accountability mechanisms to ensure that the public interest is served on a regular basis by the government having to explain when a contract, or parts of a contract, fall within the exception to the rule that the contract is a public document and must not in this instance be disclosed.

The amendment is made in the interest of accountability and transparency, and the clause will ensure that, instead of applying for contracts to be disclosed, the government must indicate the circumstances when information ought to be excluded and not released because of commercial‐in‐confidence or in order to protect the public interest.

The clause provides the chief executive with the power to delete any details of costs under the contract which would unfairly prejudice the commercial interests of any body or person. The subclause should allay any fears because it guarantees that, while these contracts are to be considered public documents, there is a safety net in place.

This clause is consistent with accepted practice in New Zealand, where all contracts are public documents. The common practice in New Zealand is that only the detail of the schedule of costs is omitted from public disclosure. This, as a rule, would serve well both the interests of public accountability and the interests of those who are concerned with the government's relationships with the private sector. While it would ensure that the public is informed of how their money is being spent and on what it is being spent, business should have no reason to fear dealings with government under such a clause since the precedent already exists for that kind of practice in other countries where it is very acceptable and works very well.

I have heard both Labor and the government indicate that they will not support this accountability exercise. I know, from the point of view of our party, that there is always a long haul to get you persuaded to this point of view, so we will come back to you again and again until eventually the accountability practice is adopted in some form which is acceptable to the government of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of contracts in relation to contracting out and providing the services that many people rely on is very important. It actually becomes the pivotal document when services are put out to the private sector. It becomes pivotal because, when you have a government department or a government program, that program is accountable in terms of its stated aims and goals. In annual reports, in Senate estimates and in questions to the minister we have ways of finding out how and why public resources are used in achieving aims and goals or achieving the policies that are set down for them.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have the Auditor-General, whose role is not to criticise public policy but to see whether the aims and goals of a program or a particular enterprise have been achieved effectively and efficiently using the resources that have been given to them. However, with outsourcing you have this point at which you can virtually go no further, unless you have access to that pivotal document.

It seems reasonable that, if governments are using public funds, not their own money, and if they are outsourcing various aspects of programs or government entities, people should see be able to see exactly what has been asked. Again and again when we ask in estimates committees, `Where is this line of public accountability when it comes to privatisation,' we hear this response: public interest can be maintained through good tendering documents.

We are not necessarily going to provide the funds to make sure that the public entity can write good, clear, inclusive tendering documents. We assume that it can do all of that in the process of writing the tendering document and in the contract that is signed; the agreement between the Commonwealth body, the state and the contractor. It seems ludicrous that, in that scenario, given the reassurances about public interest and accountability that have been given to us about outsourcing and the use of private entities, there is no access to the basis of the agreement.

We cannot accept that everything is going to be in the public interest if there is no means of people knowing what it is that the companies have agreed to. Do we have to wait to see whether that company loses the contract? How does the wider community know whether or not that entity has in fact breached its contract—it is not just a contract with the government; it is a contract with the community, which is in fact paying those wages or costs—or whether the contract itself is in breach of the basic public interest requirements that we have all been given assurances are going to be the basis of all of these interactions?

It is undesirable that these contracts be private, secret documents. Of course, it is possible for the actual figures to be deleted from that public document, but it is totally appropriate, and I believe totally responsible, for any government to make sure that the terms of contracts be publicly available.
Amendment negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 5, page 4 (after line 23), after the definition of officer , insert:

public interest means the public right to expect the full range of relevant goods and services to be provided at least cost and in ways which are efficient, ecologically sustainable, equitable and consistent with community wants and needs, without regard to geographical location.
(2) Page 23 (after line 16), after clause 28, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 28A Commonwealth authorities to act in the public interest

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, Commonwealth authorities and their directors must at all times act in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 33 (after line 15), after clause 43, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 43A Wholly‐owned Commonwealth companies must act in the public interest

PARA.TAB: Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, Commonwealth companies and their directors must at all times act in the public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments insert, in part 3, reporting and other obligations for Commonwealth authorities and, in part 4, reporting and other obligations for Commonwealth companies. The requirement is that both categories of organisations act in the public interest. That would seem to be a fairly logical and reasonable thing to do. A definition of the public interest is incorporated in clause 5: definitions.

As I indicated in my second reading contribution, this issue of public interest has been a major concern of mine for some time. I have moved similar amendments with respect to the need to incorporate public interest provisions in legislation as diverse as the telecommunications package, the Trade Practices Amendment (Industry Access Codes) Bill and, one of my favourites, the Competition Policy Reform Bill.

This is a fundamental issue. It seems to me to be common sense that Commonwealth authorities and companies be required to act in the public interest. Why would you want them to act in any other way? In clause 28, for example, the directors of Commonwealth authorities are required to ensure that government policies are carried out. We know that if they are not required to do that they may be breaking the corporations codes if they act against the interests of other private interests. So we have problems, I believe, if it is not actually in the legislation. Our amendment inserts a new section 28A, which simply states:
Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, Commonwealth companies and their directors must at all times act in the public interest.
I commend my amendments to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the amendments of the Greens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposing the Green amendments for a number of reasons. Firstly, we believe that the concept of public interest is so subjective as to be meaningless in a legal sense. We also believe that directors would be, as a result of this, placed in a quite invidious position. They are certainly entitled to more legal certainty than this would provide them—certainly in relation to what is required of them.

SPEECH.PARA: The definition of public interest provided in the amendment is difficult to interpret. For example, a particular methodology may be efficient in terms of cost but be ecologically unsustainable. Finally, matters of ecological sustainability are too complex to be dealt with incidentally in an act such as this. They should be left to environmental legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Red rag to this bull! Ecological sustainability is about how you operate all sectors of your community so that you are going to be here in the future, and so that you do not destroy what you have now. To put that into environmental legislation does seem to be missing the point. If you do not have ecologically sustainable practices in your economic practice, you have missed the point altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that issues like ecological sustainability seem to be coming up in a number of pieces of legislation, and the government has not necessarily objected to them. A very recent amendment which the government accepted was in the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 . Being cynical, would that perhaps have been because the government expected it to be voted down? I wonder.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to answer that?
—You could do.
—We did not expect it to get voted down.

—Perhaps they thought they had to buy the bill and that was one thing about which they were prepared to go past their principles. Either way, it has been accepted in another bill. I just wondered why it is now so subjective as to be meaningless in the legal sense.

SPEECH.PARA: Public interest has been used on many occasions to indicate that somehow or other the market is it—that the market is what provides public interest. Is it not funny that the market, lease cost tendering and competitive neutrality are assumed to be in the public interest but when we want to indicate that a public interest might be broader than that, somehow or other it is meaningless in the legal sense. I do find this extraordinary. I would also like to find out how the Labor Party will be voting on this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are unlikely to support it. I want to raise a question, through the chair, with Senator Margetts about the very open meaning here of public interest. When we are looking at the meaning here, how do we define the full range of relevant goods and services anywhere in Australia? It seems to me that that is incredibly open. Does that mean that everyone has the right to a sealed road, for example, regardless of their location in Australia? I do not believe that you could deliver that in any economic sense even if it was desirable. What is meant by this full range of relevant goods and services? Does that mean TVs and computers? How would it be constricted in any way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond firstly to the proposition put by Senator Margetts that we only supported amendments to the Productivity Commission Bill 1996 because we thought it was going to go down. The government was absolutely appalled when that legislation went down. We spent three days debating it. In fact, we had full expectations up until halfway through the speech by Senator Murray at the third reading stage that the legislation was going to go through.
—What happened?

—We know exactly what happened. The point I make in relation to ecological sustainability—I will flesh it out because I was too brief previously—is that if you seek to so flippantly treat the concept of ecological sustainability that you build your green credentials by coming in here and slipping the words into every single bill, which makes the concept absolutely meaningless, you do the cause of trying to make the world more environmentally sustainable no good.

SPEECH.PARA: You keep running around saying, `We've got to be green; we've got to be sustainable' and you keep writing pieces of legislation where it will have no effect whatsoever. It will not have any impact. Putting them into something like the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill is interesting. I will read this to the committee. This is incredible stuff. No-one is listening to this debate but in the future some person may pick up a Hansard and read it. They will learn two things: firstly, what a lechstone is; and, secondly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us again.

—You will have to find out. You will have to ask Douglas Campbell that one. Public interest means the public right to expect the full range—this is incredible stuff—of relevant goods and services to be provided at least cost in the ways which are efficient, ecologically sustainable, equitable and consistent with community wants and needs without regard to geographical location. Hallelujah! Great policy. Well done. I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —What the parliamentary secretary has just read out and shown his ignorance about is actually a definition of access and equity, which on various occasions both sides of this chamber have indicated they support when there has been lack of access. It does say `relevant goods and services'. I point out to Senator Sherry that if you are in an area which does not necessarily get sealed roads, the relevant goods and services are access to the roads that other people in that area may have access to. It is about trying to put into words such things as access and equity. Perhaps we should have spelt that out. It is just a way of pointing out to you what access and equity are in a way that means that people cannot easily ignore them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that when you write this in anything to do with the dollar or private industry, the government finds ways of ignoring the words that have been put down. By putting it in words that are as clear as possible, we are hoping you will not be able to pretend they are not there—that the issues involved with people in regional and rural Australia and the issues involved with not wasting our resources for a quick buck now and making the future pay do not disappear off the page. If you have trouble understanding that, that is your problem, not mine.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 25 (after line 17), after clause 33, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 33A Application of Privacy Act to Commonwealth authorities

PARA.TAB: The Privacy Act 1988 applies to each Commonwealth authority that is not an agency within the meaning of that Act apart from this section as if it were an agency.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 35 (after line 15), after clause 48, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 48A Application of Privacy Act to Commonwealth companies

PARA.TAB: The Privacy Act 1988 applies to each Commonwealth company that is not an agency within the meaning of that Act apart from this section as if it were an agency.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to the application of the existing Privacy Act to Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies. My colleagues on the Democrat benches have spoken a number of times about extending privacy to the private sector. In recent months the level of support for a comprehensive privacy scheme has varied and we have no such measure in place for all Commonwealth authorities and companies.

As you know, we regard the issue of not extending privacy to the community as a whole as a backflip by the government on one of its election commitments. After releasing a discussion paper last year and a range of very positive comments from the Attorney-General (Mr Williams), the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) ended the government's commitment to what they had forecast would be an international best practice privacy scheme and, in the process, reneged on their election promise.

The reasons for this decision and the relevant information the Prime Minister relied on in making this decision have not been made available. Some senators in this place have suggested that submissions to the Attorney-General's discussion paper were the basis for that decision. They have suggested that the submissions show that business or sections of business did not want privacy regulation. Unfortunately, I have not been provided with access to those submissions to be able to draw that conclusion but I doubt it, frankly, based on my own understanding of the matter.

The amendments proposed here will go part of the way to making up for government shortcomings in the privacy area. We also think that it is consistent with the government's stated approach to fixing gaps in the privacy legislation. In other words, they have said that they will deal with it piecemeal, as and when it is needed in terms of the existing privacy regime.

Over the years the Democrats have been keen advocates of privacy. The Democrats have always supported extending privacy to all sectors of the Australian community. This recognises that managing personal information is central to accountability and confidence in the way private information will be handled. These amendments simply apply the provisions of the Privacy Act to Commonwealth authorities and companies by including them within the meaning of an agency for the purposes of the Privacy Act. With these two amendments, the Privacy Act will apply in its present form with all the existing complaints, investigation and enforcement provisions presently given to the Privacy Commissioner.

Privacy is materially affected by technology developments. Collecting, storing and exchanging information on electronic devices is much easier and many of the applications are dependent on that personal information. That was the reason privacy legislation was accepted by both the coalition parties and the Labor party in 1988 with the tax file number issue. Since then, the ability to collect data has expanded dramatically with the collection and storage of ever increasing amounts of personal information. We think the need for privacy is increasing, and not static. What we have proposed here is a step along that road. We hope that the committee will look favourably upon these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that if we have the private sector `competing' against government entities on the basis that they will not need to provide privacy to the public, which the public have expected from government for their personal and private information that they have to give from time to time, then that is not really competing at all; that is undermining the competitive process. It seems that then the community is giving a subsidy to the private sector. That subsidy is a very valuable subsidy. It is the subsidy of their privacy and the protection of their privacy. They know that if material is leaked about their private information to people who need not know it or should not have access to it, then at the moment at least they can make a complaint to the ombudsperson or whomever. Unfortunately, the ombudsperson is being stomped on by government. So the government does not really want to know about those kinds of complaints.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is the right of people to complain if their personal information at the moment is misused or passed on to another party. It may involve people being harassed or having information about them unfairly distributed to other people who should not have it. Or it may mean that their information is marketed by other people.

Why should we suggest that it is reasonable for the private sector to undercut the public sector on the basis that the privacy is the subsidy and the community pays it? If you were to ask the majority of the people in the community whether that was reasonable, they would say no. Therefore, I urge the committee to support Senator Murray's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting this amendment. I have just heard from the opposition that they have only just been given this amendment as well. We have certainly only just received it. You wonder how serious people are when they drop amendments like this on you after eight years of discussion of these bits of legislation. There is a very legitimate debate going on in the community as to how far the Privacy Act should reach.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: my instructions were that these were distributed a week ago.
—That is not a point of order.

—As I understand it, there might have been a communication breakdown, Senator Murray, and it might have been more helpful if that had not occurred. The coalition is not of a mind to support this. We believe, basically, that if you want to make alterations to the reach of the Privacy Act, those alterations should be made to the Privacy Act and not be made as the parliament considers each piece of legislation.

—We are having some trouble understanding the amendment. We are not sure of the implications of it. Unfortunately, we have only just seen the amendment and, even though it is very short by amendment standards, we are not willing to support it on that basis. I am not accusing you of not distributing it in time, Senator Murray. There may have been a legitimate problem in our obtaining it. It would appear on the face of it to have significant implications so I will have to err on the side of caution and not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to honourable senators if they did not get it in time. I repeat that I checked with the staff and my instructions were that it was distributed. That it was not done, I regret.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments relate to matters which we have discussed before under other bills. They deal with the question of gender specific language and gender amendments. Gender specific language is language which operates to exclude, at both overt and subtle levels, either men or women. Language, as you know, is a clear way in which social reality is constructed. If this was not so then there would not be so much concern at issues named as `politically correct'.

Re‐introducing masculinist gender specific language is a process of trying to wind the clock back and to, once again, make women invisible in legislation. This reflects a current phenomena in this parliament where women's issues have significantly dropped down the agenda, and it is contrary to the government's law and justice policy and the women's policy statement which highlighted this government's commitment to women's equality and ensuring protection of antidiscrimination measures.

Since we started moving these amendments, we have had various people once again claiming that the origin of the word `chairman' is Latin. There is dispute about that. The Oxford English Dictionary and the Random House Dictionary of the English Language make clear that the first use of `chairman' was in the 1600s and was specifically taken from `chair' and `man'. Personally, that is irrelevant. The fact is that it bothers a lot of people. If that is so then we should be careful to avoid causing unnecessary offence. The use of masculinist gender specific language is contrary to a matrix of established legal and policy principles.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to refer to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional affairs. In its 1993 report entitled Clearer Commonwealth law it unequivocally stated:

In recent years Commonwealth drafters have taken care to use both masculine and feminine pronouns when legislation is intended to apply to both males and females. Legislative drafters should ensure that women are not `invisible' in the law and the committee believes that interpretation of legislation should require phasing in of use of words and of appropriate gender in all legislation.

That was a cross‐party recommendation. The relevant recommendation flowing from this statement was that Commonwealth legislation should provide that words of the masculine gender do not include the feminine gender and words of the feminine gender do not include the masculine gender. This recommendation received cross‐party support in the House, including from committee members Daryl Williams, Peter Slipper, Peter Costello and Chris Miles.

Following that situation, the Acts Interpretation Act, which I deal with here in our amendments, was not, unfortunately, then amended to incorporate this recommendation but recent legislation implemented by the current government, before the lunacy that has started to prevail, clearly reflects this recommendation. For example, the Statute Law Revision Act 1996, which received royal assent on 25 October 1996, provides for the amendment of 58 acts to replace gender specific language with gender neutral language. The Attorney-General's second reading speech states:

Finally, the bill continues the process which has been going on for some years of altering gender specific language in acts. The main element in this process is the insertion of feminine pronouns to accompany masculine pronouns . . .
So you have to ask, `What is going on here, where the Prime Minister can pursue an agenda which is not shared by his subordinates?'
Section 23 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, which refers to rules as to gender, states that:
. . . words importing a gender include every other gender; . . .

That is the old fashioned way of thinking. That is an archaic section, and it is at odds with the above recommendation that I have quoted of the report on clearer Commonwealth laws and the practice of ensuring gender neutrality.

If the Prime Minister continues to insist on using gender specific language, the government may be seen to be making a backflip over its previous position. I am given to understand it is even possible that the Prime Minister's office has instructed draftspersons to pursue a line of argument in this area which is entirely contrary to the findings of cross‐party, unanimous bodies such as those as I have quoted earlier.

There appears to be no written policy instigating the shift in gender specific language. If there is, I would appreciate the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer tabling it because we would really like it exposed to the world. Such a policy would be contrary to the government's commitment to open and transparent government processes. If such significant policy decisions are to be made, they should be made open to public scrutiny through parliamentary debate. I record here that in the past I have had the pleasure of the unanimous and strong support of the two Green parties, Senator Harradine and the Labor Party in this matter, who between them just cannot see the point of the foolishness. This lengthy set of amendments will go a very long way to restoring the situation of gender neutrality in our legislative language.

SPEECH.PARA: I was sitting in a legal and constitutional committee hearing when one of the witnesses advised us that some important areas of the Acts Interpretation Act had never been amended by governments of the day simply because they never got around to them. However, this made the practice and operation of law in examining various bills very difficult. I asked the witness if she could provide me with some examples. She did so and, of the set of examples, there are two that I have put before you today because I think they are useful in helping advance the modernity and usage of drafting matters and so on.

Believing that the Attorney‐General's bill would be coming up the next day, I took the precaution of faxing him a letter on 28 August 1997. It was headed `Acts Interpretation Act 1901 via the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill' and it asked him if he would be good enough to respond by commenting on these amendments so that we could proceed to them without much debate or, if there were to be any changes, I could be so advised. To this date, I have received no reply. This is not unusual—I have written to him on a number of matters in the past and I have not got replies. Quite frankly, I want to record in this chamber the dissatisfaction that I have with the Attorney‐General's office in responding to correspondence from my office. I hope that is not a matter that is a problem for everybody else as well.

This particular amendment that I refer to concerns the marginal notes and headings to sections of section 13, and I will briefly advise you of what the problem is. Section 13(3) currently excludes from being part of an act any marginal note or heading to a section of an act.

The reason is historical. Both marginal notes and headings to sections were formerly notes added by way of explanation in the margin of legislation after it had been passed or made. As such, the words lacked the authority of the parliament. Today marginal notes and headings to sections are on the bill as printed for discussion by parliament, and it is anachronistic that they are still excluded. The contrary intention clause there has been added for certainty, because some acts specifically reverse the rules in subsections (2) and (3). It is relevant to these bills because these bills are affected by such rulings but it is also a technical amendment. I do hope that the government will support the amendments.
