SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the committee making further amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) in relation to the sale of mineral rights.
It is my understanding, from consultations that have occurred in this chamber, that the government does not intend to vote against this motion. I will therefore be very brief.

The carriage of this motion will enable me to move two amendments which I have circulated. The first amendment is numbered on the amending page 681. It is an amendment which I will explain at the appropriate time, but it essentially enables the Senate to vote on a substantial element of what has become a key issue here in debate: the question of retrospectivity on prospectors' taxes for mining.

The second amendment would be moved in the event that the first one was not carried. That amendment would be consequential upon a decision made by the Senate when this bill was last before the Senate. At that time, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) was the minister representing the government and he—and I think this is fair—belatedly advised the chamber that there may be a need for a further amendment if the amendment the chamber was then considering was carried. In response to his assertion, I said that I was not entirely sure that that was true but, if it were the case, we would move the further amendment.

In summary, if the first amendment that I would move upon the carriage of this motion were lost, I would move the second amendment, which would in fact repeat the decision of the Senate in another part of the bill as a consequence of an earlier decision of the Senate. I make that as an explanation to the chamber and I repeat my understanding that the motion will be carried to enable us to get on with this task rapidly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had indicated privately to Senator Cook that we would probably support the procedural motion, but I also indicated to him that we would probably be opposing—and, at the stage when we were having our conversation, would oppose—and vote against what in shorthand, for those who followed the debate, is effectively his old amendment No. 3, as it became known, to apply to the prospective 1997 act. As Senator Cook said, the previous amendment was only to an act which expired, effectively, on 1 July 1997, which is something that Senator Kemp very politely pointed out at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Could I therefore say that the effect of our voting for the procedural motion and then voting against the further motion, in respect of the outcome, is contradictory, and so I indicate that the coalition will oppose the motion that Senator Cook has now moved. I indicate that, in the event that the motion to reinstate this matter is in fact held in contradiction to our opposition to it, we will also oppose the putting in of his third amendment into the 1997 tax law.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Cook's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering message 352 from the House of Representatives.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the committee does not insist upon the amendment to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to speak, Senator Cook?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Chairman. I use those words despite the amendment that was carried in this chamber a moment ago. That, unfortunately, is the proper usage. I would like to recognise you in non‐masculine terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has moved that the committee not insist on the amendment. The opposition opposes that motion. We wish to persuade the Senate that it should insist on this amendment, on the grounds of, basically, fairness and what any reasonable Australian would argue is equitable.

The issue here concerns rollover relief. By not insisting on this amendment, the Senate would enable the government not to value the personal wealth of an individual taxpayer, along with their business accumulated wealth, when it comes to the question of rollover relief. That would create an inequitable position for those who are in a position of having considerable personal wealth compared to those who are in a position of having inconsiderable personal wealth—or to put it in plain English: the rich benefit and the poor do not. For those reasons, we think the Australian fair go mentality, the reasonable person, the look‐after‐the‐underdog mentality and straight‐out equity and fairness require that the amendment carried by the Senate now be insisted upon despite the government's disinclination to do so.

In a way, and in microcosm, the government's insistence on its position reflects the fundamental difference between the parties. We in the Labor Party—indeed, I have to acknowledge the Greens and the Democrats too—have argued directly and frankly that ordinary Australians should be protected here. The government is arguing a position which advantages wealthy Australians. When we talk about wealth, the level of wealth we are talking about is $5 million, which is not an inconsiderable amount. I expect that normally my colleague Senator Sherry would make this argument, but on his behalf I put those views to this chamber at this time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats think we should insist on this amendment. We had the debate last time. Since that time, there has been a lot of misinformation out there in small business land about what the Senate has and has not done for small business.

BREAK.PARA: We are talking about capital gains tax rollover relief for small business, but we have to note that the Senate has already supported the tax bill to allow proceeds of the sale of one business to be rolled into another. It has done that, which is a positive thing for small business. What we have been asked to do since then is to agree to a further tax concession to allow proceeds to be rolled into superannuation.

I remember we asked the government to provide some modelling on this. We asked: how does this measure add to or reduce national savings? The government has failed to provide that modelling. In fact, I think it might have even refused to do so, but I stand to be corrected on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray won't let us have the commission to have models.

—I do not think that is true; I think you have the whole Treasury over there—press the button. I think we have made the point before that a lot of tax breaks for savings, while good in theory, do not work because the cost of the tax break to the revenue ends up being higher than the increase in savings concerned.

BREAK.PARA: We have also said that we are prepared to support well‐targeted tax breaks, but we do not think this one is well targeted. I do not think it is genuinely small business. I do not think $5 million worth of business assets is really medium to big business masquerading as small business.

This bill actually proposes opening up a new loophole. It is the Treasurer (Mr Costello) who has made a big deal, since he has been Treasurer, of saying that he is going to seek out the riddlers and the rorters of the system. Yet, at the same time, the government wants to open up a new $250,000 tax break.

People who have business assets of up to $5 million are multimillionaires. For a lot of people in business that might not sound like much, but I can assure you that, to the huge majority of Australians out there trying to save for retirement, $5 million is something they could never dream of attaining. We have to ask: are the people who have $5 million worth of business assets the kinds of people who really need a new $250,000 tax break for retirement savings?

When we had this debate last time, the Senate moved an amendment to tighten this $5 million cut‐off by including personal assets within that cap. That is what we are arguing about. We said that that was the right thing to do because this prevents already‐wealthy multimillionaires from being able to take advantage of this new tax break that was designed to benefit small businesses. We argue that the number of people affected will be very small and they will be quite wealthy.

We should remember that what we are talking about is retirement savings—trying to ensure that a tax break is sufficient to ensure that small business people have adequate retirement savings. Retirement savings are not just business assets. Retirement savings include the family home or business properties. They include art. They include investment properties. They include collectables. That is the point we are trying to make. If we are trying to decide whether a new tax break for retirement savings should be made available, then we should look at all the ways a person saves for retirement.

I do not think this government is about a fair deal for PAYE taxpayers. I do not think it can claim to be serious about preventing rorts while at the same time opening up the possibility for this one. This is a government that cracks down on social security recipients; it is the same government that cracks down on public housing tenants, that cracks down on the unemployed who have a bit of superannuation put away but, at the same time, wants to give those who have $5 million worth of business assets a gift—a $250,000 retirement gift.

The government argues that this was an election promise. I looked in the fine print for the election promise which said, `We will give a $250,000 gift to multimillionaires on retirement,' and I could not find it. I did find election promises about maintaining Austudy, about maintaining job assistance programs, Medicare, child-care assistance, public housing funding, and rent assistance. But, as we have already said here, it seems that the government has misplaced these non-core promises.

This is a point of principle. Five million dollars is a lot of money. It is not small business we are talking about. It does not compare favourably with ordinary Australians who are trying to save adequately for retirement. I think the committee is right to insist on the amendment to tighten the means test to keep multimillionaires out of this tax break, and to stop this government from opening up a potential tax rort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the previous occasion this legislation was being considered, I understand that Senator Cook made some comments like those which have just been made by Senator Kernot; and I understand that such comments were made not just by the Democrats but also by the Greens and Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: We took the strong view that, when considering CGT tax relief of up to half a million dollars to be granted where the net business assets of the taxpayer do not exceed $5 million, we should take into account in that equation their personal asset wealth. I pointed out on the previous occasion that 97 per cent of small businesses have net business assets of under $1.3 million. If they have personal assets of something more than that $1.3 million then, under the government's proposals, they—this 97 per cent of small business—are still entitled to a substantial benefit.

Senator Kemp, I think in one of his deep criticisms of me in question time—and I say that somewhat sarcastically—said, `Senator Sherry, don't‐tax‐the‐rich Sherry'. That was his reference, and they were his direct words. Here we have an example of the government, in the guise of assistance to small business—and we welcome the assistance to small business—not ensuring that multimillionaires do not benefit from the proposed capital gains tax relief of up to half a million dollars where it is rolled over into superannuation.

The argument is that this measure is to assist in respect of retirement incomes, and that is fine. But the very small number of small businesses that will be affected by the effective cut-off by the inclusion of personal assets in calculating the benefits to be derived from this measure—a very small number of small businesses, indeed—I certainly do not believe are `battlers' in the true sense of the word. Certainly, the vast majority of small businesses are battling in a very difficult economic climate at the present time—that climate brought about, I would submit, by this government and the economic environment it has created as a consequence of its two budgets.

When considering these sorts of very substantial changes, we do have to weigh up what has occurred to other sectors of the community. We have debated on numerous occasions the introduction of the new social security provisions that really slug people at the age of 55 and take into account their superannuation assets—and, in many cases, they are not substantial superannuation assets by any manner of means—and the effective requirement to draw down on their superannuation assets on reaching the age of 55.

Senator Kernot has referred to attempting to find this extraordinarily generous commitment to, this promise for, the top end of small business, in wealth terms. Like Senator Kernot, we cannot find it either. There is a general commitment to assist small business. But, if these measures are to be passed by the Senate, they should be appropriately targeted.

The second argument, again, is one that Senator Kernot has touched upon, and it is this: if this government is serious about cutting out potential or existing rorts and rorting of the system, and bearing in mind the difficulties that most PAYE taxpayers face, we should have regard to the sorts of measures that pass through this Senate.

I would conclude my remarks by saying that Labor does not intend to change its position on this particular matter. As I said earlier, 97 per cent of small businesses have net business assets of under $1.3 million. Also, as a consequence of the passing of this legislation, there will be a substantial benefit to at least 97 per cent of small business. In fact, it will be somewhat higher than 97 per cent, but we have not been able to obtain the precise figures. For the reasons I have outlined tonight, and for those I outlined on the previous occasion when this amendment was successfully passed by the Senate, we believe that it should be maintained in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It is amazing in this place that, when you are really poor and when your only means of support is what the government can manage to provide for you, the government's response is that you are obviously going to cheat the system on every possible occasion and that you ought to be given no leeway at all. It is funny, however, that if you are very rich you will have the generous support of the government on the basis that regulation may be too onerous for you.

SPEECH.PARA: I would say that the stamp collectors of Australia are rubbing their hands in glee thinking that this might be a big boost year for them in terms of people putting their money into collections for perhaps up to $250,000 worth of stamps which will not be taxable. I think it is ridiculous for the government to suggest that this is too onerous. It is basically the reverse of Robin Hood. On behalf of the Greens (WA), I will continue to insist on this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to a couple of points. The first point is that raised by Senator Kernot and alluded to by Senator Sherry about the government's credentials in relation to tax avoidance and anomalies. One of the reasons that the government is insistent upon the $5 million threshold for small business—the definition of a small business for this measure—is that it wants to ensure it is consistent with the threshold that applies to the rollover relief that Senator Kernot has already spoken about.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other reasons which I will go into, but in 18 months this government has already taken action on R&D syndication, it has taken action on infrastructure borrowings, it has taken action on luxury car leasing, and it has taken action on withholding tax avoidance—a very strong performance in a short time. I think Senator Kernot would have to acknowledge that Mr Costello has not only talked hard about taking action where tax avoidance or aggressive tax minimisation is brought to our attention but we have also acted very quickly and have brought legislation before the parliament on all of those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trusts.
—Senator Kernot interjects and is very quick to criticise, but it would be against the Democrats' principles to give Mr Costello any sort of bouquet.
—I can show you the press release.

—You have done one, have you? Senator Kernot, send it to my fax, extension No. 3958, and I will withdraw that remark. You have given Mr Costello a pat on the back. This government has already brought a number of these measures to the parliament, and we are keen for a whole range of good reasons to ensure that tax avoidance, anomalies and aggressive tax minimisation schemes are stopped in their tracks.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with trying to change the $5 million threshold, which already applies to the capital gains tax rollover provisions which this government brought in, is that it brings in an inconsistency which is not sensible. Because the amendment would require people with amounts above $5,000 to be valued, it also puts an enormous compliance cost upon small business people, and we did not want to do that.

What needs to be said is that this government is absolutely unreservedly pro‐small business. We think that Australia's small business people are the foundations for economic growth and economic expansion. We believe that tomorrow's medium sized businesses and bigger businesses will come from today's very small businesses. Rather than saying that we are giving multimillionaires assistance, this government is providing $500,000 worth of capital gains tax relief. So less than half of that in terms of the benefit is being provided.

As I said in the initial debate, we are providing it to people who, in the main part—and I do not have the statistics at hand, but I think those of us who have spent a lot of time in small business or with small business people would know this—have put everything on the line in their small businesses. Many of them do not have other forms of savings. They invest whatever they have into their small businesses. They go through very rough periods. They had to go through Mr Keating's recession that he told them they had to have.

Senator Sherry has referred to the tough economic position at the time. I am sure he would have also regarded the period of Mr Keating's recession as very tough. At that time interest rates for a number of small business people at places like Custom Credit or AGC were close to 30 per cent. Things were a lot tougher. Certainly things are still tough for small business, but we believe that interest rates, a range of other policies and these tax measures are getting better for small business.

Small business people put all of their savings into their businesses. Their lifelong work is in small business. This is a small but important measure which will provide a very good incentive for small business people to build their small businesses and to reap some reward at the end of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a small contribution to this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1997 , which is currently before the Senate. I think it is quite appropriate to note for the record, as a range of other contributors to this debate have done, that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) as it currently stands provides for capital gains tax relief of up to half a million dollars to be granted where the net business assets of the taxpayer do not exceed $5 million.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition amendment that we are considering will extend this test by changing it to a net assets test to include all the personal wealth of a taxpayer. It does not harm us to stop at this stage to consider the significance of the proposal that is being put before us by the government. In any person's language, $5 million is a huge sum of wealth and it really would take a large amount of effort to earn it and to retain it.

The concession, the relief, that is the subject of the debate this evening, offering something in the order of up to $250,000 relief to that taxpayer from his or her tax burden at the end of each financial year, is a huge amount of dollars. It is particularly so when one considers the overall thrust of this government to reduce outlays, to pare back outlays in a whole range of areas that have been under discussion in recent months. So the quantum in terms of tax relief for savings that is being offered to one small sector of the community—in the order of $250,000—is, as I have said, not insignificant.

Labor does not believe that when individuals retire they seek to live only from the proceeds of business wealth. They will also, of course, access personal wealth. That being the case, it is the opposition's belief that all personal wealth should be included for the purposes of determining a taxpayer's eligibility for the half a million dollars capital gains tax relief. This is, as we are all aware, an identical amendment to that which was moved to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 earlier this year. As I recall, that was supported by the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine.

There is nothing before us this evening that has caused the opposition to reconsider its position, and later this evening when we go to a vote we will be taking the same position we pursued when this matter was discussed at first instance some months ago. We see no reason why, when a person retires with considerable business wealth, their personal wealth should be ignored in the determination of what is a very significant benefit that will be paid for by the broader Australian community and Australian families.

A number of concessions are means tested by the government. A few examples are the family payment, the family tax initiative and the spouse rebate. I do not think it is untoward to comment that a lot of the means tests which have been introduced in the last 15 years or so were introduced by the current opposition when we were in government. The principal position was that those who are going to receive a benefit from government through either the social security system or, in another guise, the taxation system should not be receiving that benefit when they have acquired, earned or retained their own considerable personal wealth over the years.

There is no doubt in my mind that, over the next 18 months, as this government continues, if it continues, down the same path in terms of the more recent amendments to the taxation act and the developing superannuation debate, concessions that are offered by government to particular sectors of the community—whether they be big business, small business, pay as you earn taxpayers or those who incorporate their own private and business arrangements in different forms under the law of the day—will be, increasingly, very targeted and very specific. Indeed, one suspects that, as the years go on, the ceiling that applies to a range of benefits is increasingly going to be reduced.

That is a trend that has occurred over the last 15 years and a whole range of reasons have generated cause for that trend. It is not something that is occurring in isolation in this country. It is occurring in the United States, in Western Europe and in Great Britain. Indeed, if you go to the United States, the ultimate means test was introduced in that country during the last session prior to the last election. President Clinton enabled a bill to be passed through Congress that had the effect that persons who receive welfare benefits—and welfare, of course, is widely defined in that country—after a maximum of five years are automatically deleted from the rolls, under the law of that country.

They are not entitled to receive future welfare benefits, no matter what may have been the justification. It applies to persons who receive food stamps assistance and family income support measures, particularly for single mothers. They have made the decision in that country to limit that benefit to a maximum of five years for recipients. That is a fairly radical change that overturns all established social security payments in that country that date from the days of the first Roosevelt administration in 1934 when the present social security system was devised in the United States. It has flown in one form or another particularly to the Anglo‐Saxon world and to a range of countries in Western Europe.

BREAK.PARA: That initiative has spread. It has certainly been picked up by previous governments over the last 15 to 20 years in this country and, undoubtedly, will spread further in this country in forthcoming years. The difference between the United States, when they introduced their elimination of welfare benefits for a whole range of persons, and this country is that they have effectively zero unemployment in about 90 per cent of the country. The notional unemployment rate is something in the order of 4.9 per cent in a whole range of areas.

If one looks purely at the statistics, there is over‐employment—that is, unemployment is down to one, two or three per cent. So forcing that bill through the Congress, removing hundreds of thousands of persons from the welfare rolls in the United States, has had minimal impact on the ground because there is full employment and plenty of work around. Those who have been receiving welfare benefits are receiving what some would describe as a very gentle introduction to the labour market in that for the next two years they receive a form of re-education or work training in a vocation or profession of their choice. So the harmful effects of cutting back on welfare will not have the disharmonious consequences that otherwise may have been the case.

One of the interesting consequences for United States companies will emerge in terms of the capital gains tax that is levied on profits derived by incorporated associations in that country. The move is already about. After reducing welfare expenditure by billions of dollars, the suggestion is that the central government in that country no longer requires the tax take that it did, say, two years ago. As a consequence of that, there is a serious suggestion emerging from the corporate community that capital gains tax be reduced from 37 per cent to 22 per cent as part of an interim step to eliminating all capital gains tax and all incorporated associations in the United States.

Of course, if that occurs, they will be able to keep as retained earnings something in the order of tens, if not hundreds, of billions of dollars that those companies would otherwise have paid to central government. Those retained earnings will be able to be invested in further capital expenditure in terms of technology or equipment or distributed to shareholders in the form of dividends. Either way, it will make United States companies incredibly cost effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Temporary Chairman. Could you draw to the honourable senator's attention the motion that we are debating at the moment. He is giving us a very good lecture on social and economic policy in the United States but I would like him to bring his remarks back to the amendment before the Senate at this time. My point of order is in relation to relevance. I think he should seek to have some scintilla of a wisp of relevance to the motion.
—I remind you, Senator Bishop, of the content of the motion that is before the committee.
—Thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman. (Quorum formed)

That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a very important issue—maintaining the basic pension at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earn ings. I think it is important to note that it was a Labor government that introduced this formula. It is Labor that made that commitment and has honoured that commitment throughout the entire period that it was in office.

SPEECH.PARA: On previous occasions, prior to that Labor commitment being delivered, pensioners looked forward to the budget with some degree of anxiety on many occasions and the increase in the pension that they could expect. It is a very important fundamental issue. I am sure that Senator Neal will be outlining Labor's position on this very important legislation in very thorough and intricate detail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1997 gives effect to the coalition's election promise to maintain the single adult pension and veterans' entitlements at a quarter of male total average weekly earnings. The importance of male total average weekly earnings must be emphasised as opposed to other indicators, such as the average earnings of people at large or the mean weekly earnings of males which, as a lot of people would be aware but some may not, are lower than the levels of male total average weekly earnings. If the maximum basic rate of indexed pensions falls below 25 per cent of male total weekly earnings it will be increased under this legislation up to that 25 per cent level.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure is to take effect as soon as it is carried through this house. Its effect will cease as of 20 September, 2002. So it will be in effect for a period of five years. It is worth noting that the way this bill is framed does not fully honour the government's election promise because this is not a measure that continues to take effect; it is of limited effect for a period of five years. This is ensured by the sunset clause, which only guarantees this rate for a period of five years.

The opposition has a further concern, and that is that there is no benchmarking of other benefits such as allowances. Allowances are generally those payments made to people who are of working age but who, because of misfortune, inability to obtain work or sickness, are not in employment. Therefore, they receive an allowance from the Commonwealth. This bill does not ensure that post the year 2002 pensioners can rely on the promise made by this government of pensions being maintained at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings.

It is of concern to know what the government's agenda might be on this issue. Why have they not seen fit to continue this measure past the five-year period? You do not need to look much further than the National Commission of Audit, which examined the benchmarking of pensions to male total average weekly earnings. The National Commission of Audit said about this measure that it is a risk to Commonwealth finances and that it weakens incentives for retirement and to find employment. They believe that the relevance of male total average weekly earnings should be assessed because of changes to the sex composition of the work force.

Further, the National Commission of Audit believes that the pension should only be adjusted on the basis of regular reviews in light of relevant circumstances. The National Commission of Audit recommended that the link between pensions and the rate of unemployment benefits and other allowances be reviewed. We know that for the period of the Labor government, though there was no legislative requirement, an informal arrangement, a link, between pensions and benefits was maintained.

Despite the government's election commitment to maintain pensions and veterans' entitlements at 25 per cent, it has asked the National Commission of Audit to examine the issue. You have to ask why. Why do this if the government is bound by a promise? It is clear to the opposition and to the community at large that the government is looking for an opportunity, looking for ammunition, to wiggle its way out of this promise, as it has wiggled out of so many. Certainly the government would like to implement the National Commission of Audit recommendations.

I have dealt with why it is important that we maintain the benchmark against male total average weekly earnings and I would like to reflect a little further on this issue. If this were not the benchmark that was applied, there would be a 16 per cent drop in the value of pensions if they decided to benchmark it against average weekly earnings rather than male average weekly earnings. During the time Labor was in government they maintained the 25 per cent benchmark. When we left government last year, pensions were 25.3 per cent of male average weekly earnings. In light of the audit and the great silence of the government on this issue, it is clear to me that they intend to remove the link between pensions and unemployment benefits that would ensure that unemployment benefits value is maintained. Certainly, the five-year sunset clause means that the length of the government's commitment is limited.

During the committee stage of this bill, or later in the second reading debate, I will be very interested to hear from the minister the justification for this sunset clause and whether a commitment given during the election is only a commitment to the elderly people of the Australian community for a limited time. Was this a promise made not so much to preserve the pension rate in real terms but to corral elderly people's votes and to trick them into voting for this government on the basis that their pensions would remain at the same level in real terms?

There are a number of other areas where pensioners have had a pretty hard time. In general business last Thursday a lot of these matters were raised. I suppose that many people in the government are tired of hearing about why elderly people and particularly pensioners are worse off under this government. It is worth while reminding you over and over again that not only their pension rate but also a lot of the benefits that they have obtained previously are under threat. Indirect benefits or services have been cut away quite seriously in a very short period. And I will remind you again.

The Commonwealth dental health program was abolished. Many people may recall that the federal government, during Labor's term, decided that many elderly people were not able to access dental health care. It is very unusual for a person on a pension having trouble with their teeth to be able to afford to go to a private dentist. This need was ascertained by the previous Labor government and additional funds were provided under the Commonwealth dental health program. The problem is, of course, that that program has now been abolished and, in many cases, the routine dental care that is needed for pensioners is no longer available. If you are a pensioner you may not be able to access regular care, and even if you have a severe toothache you may be waiting for three to five days before you even get to see a dentist, unless, as I said, you have enough money saved up to see a private dentist. Few pensioners have.

There have also been losses in the pharmaceutical area. There has been a 50 per cent increase in the co‐payment for those with health cards, which includes pensioners. In the last budget there was the new drug tax, estimated by the AMA to cost an additional $30 per month. Again, for those on a pension that is a major hike and it is going to mean that pensioners cannot afford the health care that I believe they are entitled to.

There has also been the removal of a number of standard items from the PBS list—many that are often used by our pensioners. They include medicines for stomach pains, diarrhoea, muscle pain, vomiting and fungal infections. This means that items will cost pensioners from anywhere between $3.20 and $10 more than they previously did—a pretty raw deal for people who have made a contribution to the community for their whole adult lives, in many cases, and have paid taxes. Now, in retirement, this government is belting them around the head. In fact, with these changes to aged care there is an effective marginal tax rate of 100 per cent for part-pensioners.

I outlined in some detail what this government has done in the area of nursing care where they have introduced not only an entry fee but also a daily charge. The eventual result of these changes will be that there will a two‐tier system of nursing care. There will be the haves and the have‐nots of nursing care. I have indicated to this chamber over and over again—I hope the message is getting through to this government—that the industry itself has indicated that, on average, they would be charging entry fees of $40,000 and that in some cases those entry fees would be as high as $100,000. That certainly is not a small amount. It is not an amount of money that a large number of people in the community are going to be able to afford.

It is particularly sad in light of the fact that, as we have reminded the government, entering a nursing home is not a decision you make because you feel like a change—you are a bit sick of your neighbourhood so you decide you might move into a nursing home. The reason people go into a nursing home is that they have become so chronically ill and so frail that they are no longer able to maintain themselves in their own homes. Generally, to take up a place in a nursing home is the last option considered by both the individual involved and their family.

It is particularly sad to see that this government is again singling out this particularly vulnerable group in the community for these sorts of additional charges and poor treatment. Even though, on the face of it, this bill takes up the government's promise to maintain pensions at 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings, there is in fact no such guarantee contained in the way this bill is framed. In putting this bill before the House of Representatives and the Senate, this government is taking the opportunity to break the nexus between pensions and benefits that has existed for many years.

There is another issue that I wish to mention briefly while dealing with this bill. It was indicated that there was some urgency over this matter and that it should be brought on as quickly as possible, but my understanding is that this bill was debated in fact in March in the House of Representatives. As it is now almost the end of September, I would like to hear the minister comment on that particular issue.

If this matter is so urgent and if it is to satisfy a promise made during the election, why has so much time elapsed between the debate of this bill in the House of Representatives and the debate here in the Senate? I do not believe that poor management by the government in ordering its business can be the real explanation why this bill has sat on the backburner for all those months while other bills, ones that this government has chosen to put on the list for debate here in the Senate and give a priority over this bill, have come through from behind it and overtaken it.

I would like to indicate that the opposition will move a number of amendments in relation to this bill. Those amendments should have been circulated. If copies have not been received by the government and other parties, perhaps they might indicate to me to that effect when they make a contribution in the second reading debate because the amendments deal with matters that are extraordinarily important to ensure that the promise this government has made to our pensioners is not only complied with in form but is also complied with in substance.

The amendments, which number from one through to 14, will have the effect of ensuring that this government meets its promise. They will ensure that this government guarantees that pensions are maintained at that 25 per cent rate, not retrospectively so that they are always falling behind but so that they keep pace with that promise over the period, and that they will be based not on the level of average weekly earnings in arrears but on the estimated average weekly earnings for males in advance.

We will also be removing the restriction that puts in place a sunset clause that ensures that this promise is good only for five years. We will also be doing that, of course, for the veterans payments, which are also pensions. We will also be ensuring that the connection between pensions for elderly people and benefits payable to the unemployed remains, and that those people who are on a benefit do not fall behind. In particular, we will ensure that the 25 per cent guarantee is maintained for couples—pensioners and also people who are unemployed.

As I have said, all these measures are meant to ensure that the promise this government made during the election is not only met in theory and in form but in substance. I would like to deal with these amendments in some further detail at the committee stage. I thought it would be worthwhile to highlight them at this stage to ensure that the minister and members of the minority parties can fully appreciate and observe the intent of them if they have not already had the opportunity of doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to address comments made by Senator Murray in the Senate on 26 June this year regarding land administration practices in the Northern Territory, which are clearly based on innuendo and supposition when read in conjunction with the facts. At best, his comments can be described as a grab bag of unsubstantiated allegations made by either uninformed political opponents or disgruntled idealists who would rather live in a museum than the dynamic, vibrant place that is the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murray questioned the effectiveness of a parliamentary system where my political party has been in power for its entire 23‐year life. The results of the general election of the Northern Territory, held on 30 August 1997, give a resounding response in support of the Country Liberal Party. Out of a possible 25 seats, the Country Liberal Party gained an astonishing 18 and the Labor Party a very poor seven seats. This is almost a three per cent swing to the CLP and a three per cent swing from the ALP—hardly the result to be expected if, as Senator Murray would have us believe, the lack of opposition has, to quote him, `led to a few arrogant and tired government members running to their own agenda and riding roughshod over people in the Territory'.

Nothing could be further from the truth. Let me inform the Senate of the exceptional growth of the Northern Territory economy and the growth in employment that people are enjoying there. The Territory has the lowest unemployment rate: 4.8 per cent, compared with 8.2 per cent nationally. Territory employment grew 2.7 per cent last year, which is well above the national average of 0.9 per cent. Average weekly earnings increased by 4.5 per cent in the Northern Territory compared with 3.6 per cent nationally, giving territorians Australia's third highest average salaries after the ACT and New South Wales.

The Northern Territory economy continues to grow at an exceptional rate. BIS Schrapnel recently predicted a staggering economic growth of the Territory of around eight per cent, helped by three oil and gas projects worth $2.5 billion, which are expected to come on line in five to eight years. The Northern Territory government forecasts of about five per cent growth would still be the envy of other states, and the partnership between the Northern Territory and federal governments on railway proposals and constitutional development leading to statehood will only complement the Territory's land administration regime.

I believe it would be extremely difficult for a government to achieve the exceptional record and statistics that I have just outlined without the support of its people and without being energetic, fair and open in its dealings. I contend that the Northern Territory has politicians who are the most in touch and closest to their constituents in Australia due to the small size of their electorates and to the very nature of the Territory and its politics. It is ridiculous to suggest that territorians would continually vote in politicians that they were familiar with if they ran roughshod over them and ignored their wishes, as Senator Murray claimed.
I would now like to address the specific allegations made by Senator Murray and to set the record straight. On the matter of town planning, Senator Murray says:
Open government means making the process of planning and approval transparent and open to scrutiny, but the Northern Territory scenario is apparently neither of these.

On what basis is this statement founded? The facts are that the Northern Territory planning act was completely rewritten and simplified in 1994 after 12 months of extensive public consultation. The current planning processes give greater opportunity than ever before for community involvement. Notwithstanding these advances, the Northern Territory Minister for Lands, Planning and Environment has recently announced further improvements to the act to even better reflect community needs and simplify processes. These include a review of the planning act, which will be carried out in close consultation with the community. One of the proposals foreshadowed is the appointment of a community representative for each division of the Northern Territory Planning Authority.

Senator Murray also refers to an announcement by the Darwin Lord Mayor, Mr George Brown, that he would resign from the Northern Territory Planning Authority over the Northern Territory government's contempt for residents' wishes. This was in relation to a specific proposal which George Brown voted for himself when it went before the Northern Territory Planning Authority, of which he was then a member. The hypocrisy would almost be laughable if it were not so serious.
With regard to land acquisition, Senator Murray has stated:
. . . the Northern Territory government has offered unacceptably low compensation to landowners in its drive to resume land for the Alice Springs to Darwin rail corridor.

The facts are that the Northern Territory Lands Acquisition Act is modelled on Law Reform Commission recommendations and is the only statute of this type in Australia to embrace these recommendations. In addition, the Northern Territory (Self‐Government) Act clearly prevents the Northern Territory government from acquiring land on less than just terms. It is also a fact that land acquisition can be very emotive for affected people and the value placed on land by owners in those circumstances does not always reflect the true market value. Offers of compensation made by the Northern Territory government have all been at the assessed market value plus any special value as determined by the Australian Valuation Office.

The principal objective is to try and reach a negotiated settlement. Departmental staff are authorised to negotiate within specific parameters in order to try and reach a settlement. Unfortunately, in some cases this cannot be achieved and compulsory acquisition becomes necessary. In these cases the level of compensation payable is assessed by an independent arbiter: the Lands Acquisitions Tribunal. Again, Senator Murray has not reflected on the facts.
Senator Murray also refers to the direct land sales and says:
. . . as the direct sale of crown land is not a publicly visible process in the Northern Territory it begs to be questioned.

He also infers that deals have been done with developers and questions why crown land is not sold by auction or public tender. The facts are, again, that the senator has got it wrong. He really should review the processes of his information. I table a public information brochure, published by the Northern Territory government, which outlines the methods of the sale of crown land. This document clearly states that the most common method of disposal of crown land is by a public competitive process such as auction, tender or the invitation of applications. It also clearly states that the direct sale of crown land is an opportunity only available when proposals satisfy strict qualification criteria. The most common proposal is the sale of adjoining crown land for consolidation with private land for expansion of existing development or a major new development. This approach accords with the commercial sector practices relating to the aggregation of land for major new developments and is an appropriate and proper activity.

Senator Murray has said the direct sale of crown land is not a publicly visible process. It is a pity he did not read the crown lands act before making this allegation. Section 12 of the act clearly specifies that the minister shall notify the details of the direct sale of crown land in the gazette within 60 days. I am advised this happens in every case.

Development of the foreshore and escarpment area is another issue. Senator Murray mentions the development of the foreshore escarpment area overlooking Stokes Hill wharf and the wharf precinct. Yet again Senator Murray has got his facts wrong. The Minister for Lands, Planning and Environment has formally declared land use objectives for the central Darwin area which clearly identify existing public open space and escarpment areas are to be retained. I suggest the senator obtain a copy of the land use objectives, which provide clear evidence of the Northern Territory government's stated objective to maintain significant open space in the central business district area.

In closing, I place on record my deep disappointment that Senator Murray should use this chamber to cast wildly inaccurate and denigrating allegations against the Northern Territory government. Perhaps he may care to explain his motives. The Democrats sanctimoniously sit in this chamber as the watchdogs of the two major parties. It is an unfor tunate analogy, particularly in this case as watchdogs are normally useful. If Senator Murray wishes to adopt the role of watchdog over the Northern Territory's planning process then that is up to him. But it would benefit all concerned if he attempted to get his facts right before alerting us to problems that do not exist. It is no wonder the Australian Democrats are not relevant in the Northern Territory. This is highlighted by their dismal showing at the last Territory election, where they managed to field a single candidate who performed very poorly against the electorate winner, the CLP candidate for Drysdale, Stephen Dunham.

Senator Murray also failed to cover any issues relating to the impact on Northern Territory land administration of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and the Native Title Act. The current federal government is conducting an important review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and amendments are now before the parliament to amend the adverse effects of the Labor‐Democrat‐Greens deal on native title imposed in their 1994 legislation.

Senator Murray's inaccurate and clearly unsubstantiated allegations are no more than an unnecessary carping at the positive leadership being shown by the CLP government. The Northern Territory government is rapidly progressing the social and economic wellbeing of all Territorians, with the strong support and approval of the vast majority of Territorians.

—The government of South Australia has made that effort to deny the publication of the Anderson report into Dale Baker's conflict of interest, even though when Mr Anderson was appointed he promised that the report would be published. —He rejected the allegation that there was any conspiracy between the three. The interesting point is that Mr Dale Baker believes the President of the Liberal Party was involved in a conspiracy against him.

BREAK.PARA: This shows you to what depths the Liberal Party of South Australia has sunk in its faction fighting. —As other senators may recall, I made a brief speech in this place on 28 August 1997 in which I tabled a request for a judicial inquiry into the events surrounding the sinking of the HMAS Sydney , together with statutory declarations and other documents in support of that call. Tonight I wish to briefly revisit that issue by seeking to table four photographs and a copy of a letter to the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) from the End Secrecy on Sydney group in relation to a judicial inquiry. I have circulated that letter to the acting whips.

SPEECH.PARA: Three of the photographs I wish to table tonight relate to the evidence tabled on 28 August and in particular to a declaration of Mr Reginald Lander, who was working with radar‐direction finding equipment at the time of the sinking of the Sydney. The photographs are of the exterior and interior of a radar‐direction facility that was used to monitor the movement of a German ship off the coast of Western Australia.

Mr Lander was struck by the fact that the HMAS Sydney was coming down from the old Dutch East Indies to intercept the German ship, and he found it unbelievable that the Sydney would sail straight into the track of the German ship, come under fire and be sunk. The fourth photograph is of a German ship carrying a midget motor torpedo boat of the type carried by the HSK Kormoran as part of her main armament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of great interest to me and to Australia and our economy. I am referring to the Australian tourism industry. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, Mr John Moore, recently announced his intention to develop a national tourism plan. It is this plan that I wish to discuss. Before I do, however, I want to refer to another recent government, or at least departmental, initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just had the pleasure of reading a small booklet recently published by the Office of National Tourism. The ONT is the Commonwealth's foremost tourism policy advisory body. The booklet is titled Today's consumer, tomorrow's visitor. This booklet gave me a great sense of hope. Here is a Commonwealth government agency that has recognised the central importance of the environment and sustainability to the success of the major industry that it services.

The booklet sets out in clear terms, backed up by the results of numerous surveys, the priority that tourists and visitors from all over the world now place on the protection of the natural environment and the adoption by the tourism industry of environmentally sustainable practices. It demonstrates that Australia has unique opportunities to secure its place as a premier world destination for the many millions of tourists who want to experience nature, wilderness, wildlife and living indigenous cultures.

That Australia still has so much opportunity in this regard is more in spite of, rather than because of, successive government and corporate policies and practices at both the federal and state levels. Indeed, as we increasingly recognise the enormous value of our natural environment and living indigenous cultures, we should pause to give thanks to the many thousands of Australians who have worked so hard, often in the face of strident opposition from governments and industry, to protect those values and attributes.

Since I became the Australian Democrats spokesperson on tourism, I have become aware of the strong and urgent call emerging from within the industry all across Australia for increased government attention to the protection of our natural environment and our environmental amenity—in other words, upholding and giving substance to our clean, green image.

In light of this, I am profoundly disturbed when I see, as we all do on a daily basis, decisions being made by this and other governments that are steadily eroding our environment and hence the basis of our tourism industry. Obviously, there are many questions that need to be asked and answered about the interaction between government and tourism.

Given this, it seems timely that the Commonwealth, through tourism minister the Hon. John Moore, has recently announced the development of a national tourism plan. The development of the plan is a welcome initiative. However, the government must be made aware that, on the basis of what we already know, as summarised in the Office of National Tourism publication, any meaningful plan will need to set out strong recommendations for the protection and sustainable management of Australia's environment and natural qualities. In other words, if the plan is to have any credibility, it will necessarily bring into sharp focus the conflict that currently exists within this government in relation to its policies on tourism, resource development and the environment.

BREAK.PARA: As part of the process of developing the national tourism plan, a discussion paper has been published which summarises the aims and scope of the plan. That discussion paper hints at some of the problems such a plan will, or should, confront the government with. I will quote some excerpts from the section of the discussion paper dealing with the role of government. On page 5, the discussion paper reads:

A wide range of Commonwealth portfolios, however, have responsibility for policy issues that have a significant effect on tourism activity. It is therefore important that a `whole of government' approach be taken in the formulation of the National Tourism Plan . . . It is important to ensure that industry sectors are treated equitably and fairly.
Reading further through the discussion paper, it is apparent that the environment and sustainability must feature prominently in the final plan. Page 2 of the paper reads:
[Tourism] is an industry which can make an important contribution to the . . . conservation of our unique natural and cultural heritage;
Page 4 reads:

The Commonwealth is favourably positioned to consider `big picture' issues. It has significant influence over . . . a range of policy areas that impact on tourism such as . . . the environment and international conventions and agreements;
Page 10 reads:

Many of Australia's tourism icons are environmentally sensitive natural attractions. The long term viability of these attractions depends on their conservation and careful management. As visitor numbers increase, greater pressure will be placed on our natural resources and appropriate management practices will need to be adopted.
If the government is true to its own core statements and the wider concerns of the industry, when the plan is finalised it will potentially present this government with a major dilemma.

How does one reconcile the clear and compelling information contained in documents such as the Office of National Tourism booklet with, for example, decisions to open up uranium mines in one of Australia's greatest tourism drawcards, to permit the ongoing clear‐felling of our unique old‐growth forests, to construct resorts on sensitive coastal environments adjacent to the Great Barrier Reef, or to dam the Fitzroy River in the Kimberley? At its most crude level, what we see are governments and corporations greedily seeking to have their cake and eat it too.

We see governments paying lip‐service to the concerns and recommendations of increasingly enlightened sections of the tourism industry at the same time as compromising the future of tourism by giving preference to inherently unsustainable industries and developments. But it is not true of everyone within government. There are people who understand the dangers of this approach.

What are the implications of current government commitments, written and unwritten, for tourism? Is this government prepared to reformulate its policies in relation to key environmental issues in order to facilitate the development of the tourism industry to its full potential? Will it be prepared to take a strong stand on key policy areas such as greenhouse and renewable energy, recycling and waste minimisation, air and water quality, wilderness and national parks, native title and the development of sustainable transport systems, including airports and rail?

Governments love to talk up, and benefit from, tourism—and so do the communities. But are they really prepared to restrain their developmental greed and adopt a longer term vision to allow for the long‐term viability and sustainability of that industry? When the government's response to the tourism plan is presented, it will tell us a lot about whether this government is serious about tourism or if it is being somewhat opportunistic.

Before I close, I would also like to point out that the tourism industry itself faces some hard choices about its own directions and standards. As the industry increasingly realises where its future lies, it has some significant sustainability and other policy challenges of its own. Some aspects of the industry will inevitably not be sustainable and, in some cases, are actively eroding Australia's environmental credibility. There are issues ranging from waste minimisation and recycling, the use of renewable energy and environmentally friendly products in the construction and ongoing operation of tourism facilities, right through to the issue of carrying capacity in natural environments and policies on the siting of tourism developments, which all need to be addressed and resolved across the industry. The industry also faces difficult moral and economic choices in relation to such issues as support for native title and acceptance of appropriate standards for employees' wages and conditions.

The next couple of years offer governments and the tourism industry the chance to get their respective houses in order. The benefits of doing so will be immense, long lasting and job creating. Failure to do so will see Australia lose its marketing edge and become another worn out and indistinguishable destination on the global tourism trail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to highlight the success of the Swiss heroin trial, technically known as the `medical prescription of narcotics trial'. One of the reasons for my doing this is to acknowledge the very successful referendum that has just been held on the weekend in which 70 per cent of voters in Switzerland supported the continuation of this trial. Indeed, it has been so successful that the Netherlands has now decided to go ahead with its own trial and at least three other countries—Germany, Belgium and Luxembourg—are also looking at similar trials.

SPEECH.PARA: I also rise tonight because of the enormous amount of misinformation still being spread about exactly what this trial involved. It was a medical trial. It was a detailed, scientific and thoroughly researched project which ran for three years. It involved some 1,146 patients.

The major aims of this trial were to measure the effects of the prescription of narcotics on, firstly, the health of the participants, but also on their social integration and what I guess we could call their `dependent behaviour'. It also was aimed at looking at the suitability of this treatment for heroin addicts who had unsuccessfully tried before to quit the habit. Indeed, most of them had failed on quite a number of occasions with other programs.

The program specifically looked at this particular narcotic compared with several others. There were, in fact, three drugs involved, three substances tested—morphine, methadone and heroin. They were used orally and intravenously. The minimum age of participants was 20 and, as I have said, they all had to have tried previous programs and, indeed, had to have a heroin addiction problem of at least two years. They also had to be able to show that their health, as well as their social integration, had suffered as a result of their addiction.

There were two double blind studies where neither the patient nor the therapist knew exactly what medication it was that the patient was on. There were three randomised studies, and there were 11 studies that had individual indications. Eighteen treatment centres across the country were used during the trial; and an international specialist group, appointed by the World Health Organisation, was set up to independently appraise the results. So what were the results?

If we begin by looking at the effects of the different narcotic substances: those patients who were prescribed heroin were more willing to stay with the program and adhere to treatment than those given either injectable morphine or methadone; injectable morphine and methadone were found to be of limited use, in fact, and heroin was described as being far more useful because it had fewer side effects.

On social issues, the participants' housing status improved. Indeed, by the end of the trial there was none that was described as homeless. Their job prospects rose considerably. Participants with permanent employment went up from 14 per cent to 32 per cent. Also, a large number of participants' debts were reduced considerably. A third of participants who had been dependent on welfare required no further welfare support. Most participants stopped or lessened their contact with the drug scene but, unfortunately, a lot of them did not establish the new social contacts that those involved with the trial had hoped would eventuate.

With regard to criminal activity, income from illegal or semi‐illegal activities dropped dramatically. Only 10 per cent were still involved in that sort of thing at the end of the trial, as opposed to the 59 per cent who were when the trial started. Both the number of offenders and criminal offences decreased by about 60 per cent in the first six months of the trial. This was substantiated by access to police records; it was not just on the word of the participants. Court convictions also decreased significantly, and that evidence was directly obtainable through court records.

On to the costs and benefits of the trial. There was a cost, and this was borne by the public and private sponsors. This added up to 16 Swiss francs per patient per day. But, when one takes into consideration the overall economic value of the program, it was found that there were savings in criminal investigations, prison terms, and in terms of the amount of expenditure on the health of the participants to the tune of 96 Swiss francs per patient per day.It was evaluated that there was an economic gain of about 45 Swiss francs per patient per day from the trial.

No matter what criteria you use to evaluate the Swiss trial, it was far from a failure, whether you look at the impact on the health of the patients—and I stress that, in the short time available to me tonight, I have only touched on a fraction of the health benefits—such as the reduction in infections from such things as HIV and also Hepatitis C, as well as a range of other improvements and indicators; whether you look at their improved housing status; whether you look at their increased social integration; or, indeed, whether you look at the economic benefits.

I would ask this government to consider again not only this particular program but a range of other alternatives to the `get tougher with drugs' scenario that, unfortunately, we hear particularly promoted on a number of our talkback radio programs. I certainly hope that, with the move now in Europe, we will find this government thinking again.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to Indonesian cancellation of officer training in the United States:

(1) Did the Australian government forward to the United States (US) or British Governments information that Major General Mohammed Yunus Yosfiah, current rank, an Indonesian officer who trained in the US and England, was the commanding officer at Balibo on 16 October 1975 where the order to kill five Australian‐based journalists was carried out.

(2) Is the Government aware that some East Timorese refugees in Australia today were witnesses to the events of the deaths of the journalists at Balibo in 1975 and that sending them back to East Timor would have dire consequences.
(3) Is the Australian Government aware that the Government of Portugal does not acknowledge any claims of Portuguese criminal jurisdiction over East Timor on 16 October 1975 at Balibo.

(4) With reference to the Sherman Report, which states at paragraph 2.2.4 that Australian criminal law does not apply relevantly in that jurisdiction: Given that jurisdiction over East Timor on 16 October 1975 was uncertain, would the Australian Government participate in an international investigation with the British Government to investigate new claims by witnesses not interviewed by Mr Sherman; is the Minister aware that these witnesses fear the department would send them back to East Timor.
(5) Why has the Australian Government failed to properly inform the British Government on events at Balibo on 16 October 1975, concerning the deaths of British nationals.

(6) Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs abandoned his previous stance on the East Timorese refugees, as well as his assurances to them that he was especially concerned for the plight of East Timorese women who were being given the drug depoprovera, and his concern for the human rights of East Timorese children; if so, why.
(7) Why has the Australian Government, in the face of international condemnation, continued to subject East Timorese refugees to statelessness.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government provided the British Government with a copy of the publicly available Sherman Report which examined the deaths of the Australia‐based journalists in East Timor in 1975. In that report, General Yunus Yosfiah was named in evidence to Mr Sherman as one of the Indonesian army officers present in the force which attacked Balibo. Mr Sherman drew no conclusions as to General Yunus's involvement in the journalists' deaths.
The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs provided the response to question 2:

(2) The Australian Government takes its obligations under the Refugee Convention seriously. All applications for protection visas are individually assessed, on the particular facts of the case, in accordance with Australian law. A threshold issue is whether an applicant is able to obtain protection in a country of which they are a national. Certain East Timorese are nationals of both Indonesia and Portugal. They therefore have the option of living in Portugal.

(3) Officials from the Portuguese Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Lisbon have informed Australian officials that Portugal continues to assert its jurisdiction (including criminal) over East Timor, though in practice it is precluded from doing so by Indonesia's integration of the territory.
(4) The Sherman Report, commissioned by the previous Government, was thorough and far‐reaching.

Mr Sherman offered confidentiality to all potential witnesses. The identities of the persons who took advantage of the offer of confidentiality are known only to Mr Sherman. There has never been any basis for concerns from East Timorese applicants that providing evidence to Mr Sherman would have in any way prejudiced their applications for refugee status.
Given the thoroughness of the Sherman Report, the Government does not consider there is cause for conducting a further investigation.

(5) The Government has kept the British Government informed of developments in relation to the investigation into the deaths of the journalists at Balibo. At the time of publication of the Sherman Report, and subsequently, the British Government thanked the Australian Government for its cooperation and provision of information both at the level of official exchange and to the British next‐of‐kin.
(6) The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, has portfolio responsibility for the refugee determination process in Australia.
The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs provided the response to question 7:

(7) The 1565 East Timorese applicants currently seeking refugee status in Australia are being processed in line with Australia's international obligations under the terms of the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees. The Australian Government is not subjecting East Timorese asylum seekers to statelessness.
