QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Roundup Ready soybeans or soybean products available for sale in Australia; if so, are they labelled as genetically modified.
(2) How many copies of the 5‐enolpyruvylshikimate‐3‐phosphate synthase (EPSPS) gene were in the Roundup Ready transformation vector
(3) What other genes were in this transformation vector.
(4) From what source was the EPSPS gene derived for the Roundup Ready soybeans.

(5) (a) What on the other structural characteristics are present in the transformation vector (eg CTP sequence); (b) what other bases are included in the insertion which do not have structural characters; (c) do these bases have other effects; (d) what tests have been undertaken to determine whether these bases affect the expression of the insert and surrounding genes; (e) are there any motifs in these bases which have or may have regulatory effects; (f) what data does the Government rely on to support this conclusion; and (g) is this data conclusive.

(6) (a) How many copies of the insert were introduced into the Roundup Ready soyabeans determined from the first field trials; (b) was the insertion from the transformation vector into an open reading frame, if so, what gene was the insertion from the transformation vector inserted into; and are there any pleotropic effects from this insertion.
(7) What were the expression patterns of glyphosate tolerance and GUS activity in the Roundup Ready soybeans determined from the first field trials.
(8) If there were differences in glyphosate tolerance and GUS activity in different lines, how can this be explained.

(9) (a) Is it possible for a gene to be inserted and fail to be expressed; (b) how many insertions from the transformation vector were inserted but did not express; (c) what data supports this answer; and (d) is this supporting data conclusive.
(10) Is it possible for a transformation vector insert to be inserted and fail to be expressed.

(11) (a) Does a Mendelian segregation ratio of 3 tolerant to 1 sensitive guarantee a single dominant gene; (b) does this experimental method identify unexpressed Roundup Ready gene(s); and (c) does this experimental method distinguish between very closely linked inserted genes.
(12) Can Roundup Ready soybeans be crossed with wild‐type varieties.
(13) Are there any limits in Australia on crossing Roundup Ready soybeans without the Roundup Ready gene(s); if so, what are they; if not, does the Government propose to introduce such regulation.
(14) Can Roundup Ready soybeans cross with weed plants in Australia; if so, which weed varieties; have tests been carried out to examine these crosses in Australia; and what were the results.
(15) Has the Government taken any steps to ensure Ready Roundup gene(s) do not enter gene pools outside harvested Roundup Ready soybeans.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, Roundup Ready soybeans are imported as a proportion of normal soybean imports from USA. It is not specifically labelled.
(2) There were two copies of the EPSPS gene on the transformation vector.

(3) The original transformation vector also contained two other genes. These encoded neomycin phosphotransferase which confers bacterial resistance to the antibotic kanamycin), and beta‐glucuronidase (GUS reporter).
(4) Agrobacterium (a bacterium).
(5) (a) The original transformation vector also contained a chloroplast transit peptide, or CTP, structural (peptide coding) sequence from petunia.
(b) Additional elements contained in the insert are a cauliflower mosaic virus promoter (or `start' sequence) and a nopaline synthase transcription terminator (or `stop' sequence).
(c) Promoters and transcription terminators control the rate of expression of other genes. No other effects have been ascribed to these sequences.

(d) Standard molecular methods were used to identify which sequences were integrated into the soybean genome and whether they were functional. Compositional, yield, breeding and phenotypic analyses were also carried out. The promoter and transcription terminator sequences have a positive effect on the expression of genes in the insert. A lack of effect on surrounding genes is indicated by the extensive compositional yield, breeding and phenotypic data showing equivalence with conventional varieties.
(e) Yes, the promoter ant transcription terminator sequences (discussed previously) which produce continuous gene expression.

(f) The supporting data package (including references to published literature was supplied by Monsanto Australia. It has been reviewed by members of Australia's Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC). GMAC issued a public information sheet regarding its assessment of the proposal to import Roundup Ready soybeans for processing.
The data on food safety aspects was assessed by the US Food and Drug Administration and by ANZFA.
(g) Yes.

(6) (a) The number of copies of the transgene on the selected transgenic line was determined by molecular methods. There was a single insert in the 40‐3‐2 line, which is the commercially released soybean line.

(b) No gene mapping was done to define the insertion point of the transgene. The insertion point is unlikely to be in an important open reading frame since the transgenic plants have been shown to have no significant difference in extensive compositional analyses from non‐transgenic soybeans or soybean products. No pleitropic effects were observed.
(7) There is no GUS protein expressed in the commercially available Roundup Ready soybeans.

The first generation of progeny from an original transformed plant expressed the EPSPS gene for glyphosate tolerance and the GUS marker gene. The GUS gene was lost by normal genetic segregation in the second generation, from which the commercial 40‐3‐2 line has been bread.

(9) While line 40‐3-2 expressed only glyphosate tolerance, the parental line had both glyphosate tolerance and GUS activity. This was determined, using molecular methods, to be the result of the presence of two inserts in the parental line, each insert being responsible for the expression of a single trait. The insert responsible for GUS activity was lost during normal segregation in the individual plant which produced line 40‐3‐2.
(9) (a) Yes.
(b) None.

(c) Molecular analysis of the transgenic line by PCR (polymerase chain reaction), and by restriction enzyme digest followed by Southern blot analysis. These are standard molecular methods of genetic analysis.
(d) Yes.
(11) (a) The ratio of 3:1 indicates a single dominant gene locus.
(b) No.
(c) Molecular analysis had shown that there were not two copies of the gene closely linked or otherwise.

(13) Yes. Roundup Ready soybeans have been approved not only in respect of import for process ing for use in soy oil and stockfeed. GMAC advice included conditions designed to guard against escape of viable seed.

A proposal for the planned release of a genetically modified organism would need to be submitted to GMAC for consideration if Roundup Ready soybeans were to be used for breeding purposes. No planned release proposals for breeding Roundup Ready soybeans have been received, therefore the question of restrictions has not yet arisen.

(14) Not known. Roundup Ready soybeans are not known to successfully hybridise with related wild perennial species which are found in Australia. No data on the potential for these soybeans to cross with other potential weed plants has been assessed by GMAC.

(15) Yes. GMAC approval for Roundup Ready soybeans is limited to importation for soy oil production and stockfeed uses and conditions are imposed to minimise escape of viable seed. Should planned release of the modified soybeans be sought, it would be assessed by GMAC where control of the gene escape would be considered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under the Council of Australian Governments' Water Policy Agreement, what requirements are placed on: (a) the Commonwealth; and (b) the States, in terms of proposed new water projects such as the damming of rivers and the supply of irrigation waters to private industry.

(2) In accordance with the Council of Australian Governments' agreement in relation to water projects, what involvement will the Commonwealth have in assessing the proposal to commence a major new irrigated cotton and horticultural industry in the West Kimberley, south of Broome.

(3) In accordance with the Council of Australian Governments' agreement in relation to water projects, what involvement will the Commonwealth have in assessing the related proposal to dam the Fitzroy River to provide long-term water to this industry.
(4) In particular, will the Commonwealth be conducting its own environmental, social and economic assessments of these related projects; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst noting that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has the responsibility for the Council of Australian Governments' Water Reform Agenda in the Commonwealth, I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1 (a) Water resources development is a State and Territory Government responsibility. The Water Reform Framework agreed by the Council of Australian Governments in 1994 places no direct requirements upon the Commonwealth in terms of proposed water resources development projects. The Commonwealth, however, is committed to working with the States to ensure that the Water Reform Framework is implemented in a timely, efficient and effective manner. The Commonwealth is assisting this through the provision of financial incentives to the States under the National Competition Policy, subject to satisfactory progress being made in implementing the reforms.

1 (b) Under the Council of Australian Governments' Water Reform Agenda, a number of requirements are placed on the States in terms of sustainable water resources development. In particular, States have agreed that future investment in new schemes or extensions to existing schemes will be undertaken only after appraisal indicates that such developments are economically viable and environmentally sustainable. In addition, States have agreed that, where significant future irrigation activity or dam construction is contemplated, appropriate assessments would be undertaken to, inter alia, allow natural resource managers to satisfy themselves that the environmental requirements of affected river systems would be adequately met before any harvesting of the water resource occurs

More generally, under the Water Reform Framework, States have agreed to work towards pricing reform based on full economic recovery; the reduction or elimination of cross-subsidies; clarification of property rights and enhanced trading arrangements for water entitlements; recognition that the environment is a legitimate user of water; implementation of the National Water Quality Management Strategy; and institutional reform and public consultation and participation.

(2—3) The Council of Australian, Governments' Water Reform Framework places no direct requirement upon the Commonwealth in terms of assessing State water resources development projects such as those proposed for the West Kimberley region and the Fitzroy River in Western Australia. The assessment of such proposals is the responsibility of the State concerned. In relation to the West Kimberley development proposal, the Western Australian Government has provided assurance that all legislative requirements pertaining to the proposed development will be met, and that the proposal will be assessed in terms of economic viability and environmental sustainability as required under the Water Reform Framework. The Commonwealth has sought to be involved in any State environmental impact assessment processes to ensure that Commonwealth environmental interests are fully taken into account.

(4) No. The Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 provides for the environmental impact assessment of proposals requiring Commonwealth decisions or actions, which are environmentally significant. There are currently no Commonwealth decisions or actions related to the proposal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on

QUESTION.PARA: 29 August 1997:

(1) With specific reference to the Telstra contract for W3, the south‐western region of Western Australia (WA), granted to E&E Distributors Pty Ltd: is the Minister aware that in WA Telstra has let contracts for the distribution of White Pages telephone directories to a commercial company, where previously these were handled by various community groups seeking to raise money for charity.

(2) (a) is the Minister aware that the new commercial contractor is in many cases subcontracting deliveries back to community groups who have made deliveries in previous years but at a much reduced rate; and (b) does the Minister appreciate the social cost of the loss of this community resource, particularly in rural areas, at a time when government policies are driving a dramatic increase in the call on charities; for example, in Mandurah a Lions club with almost a decade of experience delivering telephone directories calculated that the price they were offered equated to $6 per person per hour, before allowing for the costs of running a vehicle.

(3) Does the Minister condone this transfer of funds out of community groups pursuing charitable purposes, into the hands of a commercial organisation; and does the Minister endorse the driving down of prices paid for volunteer workers giving their time free of charges to community groups, in order to create a commercial return.
(4) Does the Minister believe that Telstra has any community service obligations; if so do they not extend to this situation.
(5) Can the Minister advise how widespread this situation is, across Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question based on advice from Telstra is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For some years Telstra had relied on contractors—many of which were voluntary organisations and community groups—to distribute its directories around Australia. Previously, more than one thousand local contractors were required by Telstra to ensure delivery of its more than 20 million directories. Whilst many of the community groups involved in directory delivery provided good service, when considered nationally, there were many instances where this service did not meet Telstra's or its customers expectations. Consequently, Telstra developed a more customer orientated and cost effective delivery process for directories throughout Australia.

With regard to the contract for W3, the south‐western region of Western Australia, Telstra received a large number of submissions from a range of organisations for directory distribution contracts which were evaluated on purely commercial grounds.
(2) (a) Sub‐contracting of directory distribution work is permitted under Telstra's directory delivery contracts.

(b) With a view to providing continuity of work and the benefits which flow from the consequent fundraising, Telstra invited former contractor groups within the W3 south‐western telephone directory area to contact the successful tenderer. Telstra understands that some of these groups accepted the terms and conditions offered by the professional contractor and others, like the Lions Club of Mandurah, decided not to participate.

(3) Whilst Telstra's decision to introduce a more efficient and cost effective delivery system for directories may have led to concern by some community groups regarding reduced revenue opportunities, Telstra considers that the opportunity still exists for community groups to continue to benefit from directory delivery.

(4) Whilst Telstra and other carriage service providers have universal service obligations under the Telecommunications Act 1997, such obligations do not extend to the delivery of telephone directories by community groups.
(5)Telstra has introduced the revised delivery process on an Australia‐wide basis.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 1 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration entitled Australians All, and in particular to recommendations 55 and 56 which deal with the issue of dual citizenship, and which had unanimous support:

(1) Does the Minister agree with recommendation 55 of the report, which proposes that section 17 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 (the Act) be repealed, thereby allowing Australian citizens to acquire dual citizenship.

(2) Does the Minister agree with recommendation 56 of the report, which proposes that former Australian citizens who have lost Australian citizenship under section 17 of the Act be given the unqualified right to apply for the resumption of their Australian citizenship.
(3) Does the Minister intend to introduce legislation to repeal section 17 of the Act in order to allow Australian citizens the right to acquire dual citizenship; if so, when; if not, why not.
(4) If the Government does not propose to repeal section 17 of the Act, what is the Government's proposed course of action to deal with dual citizenship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)—(4) Repeal of section 17 of Australian Citizenship Act 1948 is one of the issues that will be considered by the Australian Citizenship Council. The Council will undertake a comprehensive review of Australian citizenship in the lead up to the 50th anniversary of Australian citizenship on 26 January 1999. It is expected that an announcement of the membership of the Council will be made later this year.

Former Australian citizens who have lost Australian citizenship under section 17 of the Act currently can apply for resumption of their Australian citizenship under section 23AA of the Act. The current requirements to be met for resumption of Australian citizenship will also be examined by the Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 3 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) To whom is data from international passenger arrival and departure cards provided; (b) in what form and level of aggregation is it provided; and (c) to what use is it put.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Data from international passenger arrival and departure cards are provided to the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the travel and tourism industry, academic institutions and other agencies.

(b) Data are provided as records of individual movements (but without names) and as aggregated cross‐tabulations. For individual records, the full range of data items is provided for all permanent and long‐term movements but for only a sample of short‐term movements. The full range of data are provided in about 8% of cases with only a limited range of data items being provided in the other 92% of cases. The contents and format of cross‐tabulations are dependent upon user specifications.

(c) Passenger card data are used in many areas of public and business administration including for border management, law enforcement, public health, (including human quarantine) and policy planning, investment and management.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Salary Packaging

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 4 September 1997

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department negotiated or indicated a willingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees.
(2) Has the department informed any staff of its intention to offer salary packaging schemes to its employees.
(3) Can a copy be provided of the communication in (2) as well as information regarding: (a) when it took place; and (b) what developments have occurred regarding implementation of salary packaging.
(4) Can details be provided of any salary packaging arrangements which have been made available to employees of the department.
(5) Can details be provided of the number of salary packaging arrangements which have been entered into by employees.

(6) (a) Are salary packaging arrangements being offered to all employees or only selected employees; (b) if selected employees, what class of employee is being offered salary packaging; and (c) what are the salary ranges applicable to these employees.
(7) What percentage of an employee's total salary is allowed to be taken as non‐salary benefits.
(8) Please list the options or items that are allowed to be salary packaged under any department arrangement.
(9) Do any of the arrangements offered benefit from an employer exemption from fringe benefits tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) recently conducted focus group meetings with all staff in the context of negotiating a new certified agreement.
